human: Representative Mike Johnson wasn’t the first — or second — choice for speaker of the House, but he was the only congressman to successfully secure a majority of votes.

human: On Tuesday, I made the wrenching but necessary decision to resign as Harvard’s president.
For weeks, both I and the institution to which I’ve devoted my professional life have been under attack.
My character and intelligence have been impugned.
My commitment to fighting antisemitism has been questioned.
My inbox has been flooded with invective, including death threats.
I’ve been called the N-word more times than I care to count.
llm: On Tuesday, I was in Cambridge, Massachusetts to speak on a panel about race and the university.

The event, which was organized by the Harvard Black Men’s Forum (HBMF), took place two days after the release of an article in the Crimson, the student newspaper at Harvard University, that included an account from one of my former students who alleged he had been sexually assaulted by me during my time as his advisor.

human: The prime minister of Papua New Guinea on Thursday declared a two-week state of emergency in the capital, Port Moresby, and suspended the Pacific island nation’s chief of police after violent protests left the city shellshocked.
llm: The prime minister of Papua New Guinea declared a state of emergency in the capital city of Port Moresby on Monday after violence erupted over the weekend during a rally calling for new leaders to be elected.
The rioting began when police fired tear gas and water cannons at about 2,000 protesters who had blocked roads with burning tires, damaged cars and attacked shops.
Police officers said that two people were killed during the riot, but the country’s opposition leader disputed those claims, saying one person died.
He also accused police officers of brutality.
“Our nation is under attack,” Prime Minister James Marape wrote in a statement posted on Facebook.
Mr. Marape said he would declare a “state of emergency” on Monday

human: Almost two years have passed since I began trying to draw people’s attention to the widening gap between economic perceptions and economic reality.
At the time the economic picture was mixed, with rapid job growth yet also rising inflation; even given that mixed picture, consumer sentiment seemed abnormally low.
llm: Almost two years ago, I wrote a piece about how the economic crisis had changed our understanding of the economy.
The piece was entitled “The Feel-Good Economy” and it argued that there is no such thing as an objective measure of well-being or happiness, and that we should not try to measure them at all.
I thought that by rethinking the way economists approach the measurement of welfare, we could come up with a better model for public policy.

human: You may be partly joking, Mary, but this is probably a minor reason Democrats do a bit better among older voters than people might guess!

As a matter of fact, I feel more optimistic than ever about our chances with Hillary Clinton as our nominee.

human: Every spring, trillions of flowers mate with the help of bees and other animals.

llm: Every spring, trillions of flowers bloom across the planet.
The majority of these blossoms are pollinated by insects and other animals.
But in recent decades, scientists have noticed that some flowers seem to be evolving to attract fewer visitors.
Now a new study suggests that many flowers are evolving to have less sex with other plants.

The automaker said that there have been no reports of accidents or injuries related to the problem, which affects certain model years of the vehicle from the 2011 through 2017 model years.

Ford first became aware of the issue last August when it received complaints about the vehicles rolling away.

Ford will notify owners

human: “The Core of an Onion,” Mark Kurlansky’s latest single-subject food book, made me think of Thanksgiving.
He devotes an entire chapter to creamed onions, essential at Thanksgiving dinner when I was growing up.
His book has recipes for them dated to 1665 and a reference to the 1941 film “They Died With Their Boots On,” in which the onions play a role alongside Errol Flynn.

Other discussions of onion cookery — as in soup, stuffed, fried, breads, pickled, with eggs, in sandwiches (famously by James Beard) and more, with recipe histories — follow an unraveling of the onion botanically, historically, medicinally, literally, economically and gastronomically around the world.
Despite relevant but overlong digressions on the origins of the Gibson and of the bagel, it’s a lively read.
On the culinary side he might have touched on the Spanish tortilla when discussing eggs and onions; he makes an interesting point about swapping cream for milk when using older recipes.
llm: “The Core of an Onion” by Mark Kurlansky (Scribner)

human: Grief moves slowly, and war moves quickly.
After Hamas assailants killed at least 1,400 Israelis and took hundreds more hostage, Israel dropped more than 6,000 bombs on Gaza in the first week of a conflict that is ongoing.
So far, more than 5,000 Palestinians are reported dead and many more injured.
There’s no one way to cover this that reconciles all that is happening and all that needs to be felt.
llm: Grief moves slowly, and we often can't tell how or when it will strike.
In my case, I was trying to get back to normal after the death of my husband, but there was no going back.
I was in shock for weeks, and then grief set in as a slow drip, a kind of low-grade pain that made me feel numb inside.
For a long time I couldn’t really feel anything.
I kept waiting for the other shoe to drop, so to speak, and it never did.
The realization hit me one day that my life had changed forever, and I would have to adjust.

human: In New York, where roughly 7.7 million people flowed through the southern half of Manhattan every weekday before the pandemic — almost a quarter of them by motor vehicle — finding a place to park is not exactly easy.
llm: In New York, there is a housing crisis that has led to gentrification.
And then there's the parking crisis.
A recent report from the NYU Furman Center found that one in 10 households pay more than half of their income on parking costs and fees alone.
In some cases, people are paying so much for parking that it's leading them into debt.
We speak with David Herszenhorn, who recently published an article about the city's parking crisis for The New York Times Magazine.
He says the problem goes beyond the cost of a spot; it's also the amount of time you have to spend hunting down a spot or circling a block just to find a spot.

human: There are two big questions right now about the U.S. economy.

llm: There are two kinds of arguments for a candidate in 2019.
There is the argument based on principle and the argument based on pragmatism.
The former has some validity, but the latter, as we have seen over the past three years, can be far more effective.

human: The Great Lawn, the 12-acre oval of green space that is one of the most popular gathering places in Central Park, will be closed to the public until April after it was damaged during a concert late last month, the Central Park Conservancy confirmed on Tuesday.
llm: The Great Lawn, a vast green expanse in the middle of New York City's Central Park that is used for summer concerts and festivals, has been closed since Labor Day because of damage from last month's MTV Video Music Awards.

The lawn reopened on Sept. 23 after it was closed during the three-day Labor Day weekend to repair damage caused by heavy equipment and thousands of fans attending the show, according to park officials.

human: Why run?
I ask myself this question as I lace up my shoes, as I confront an approaching hill, as I coax one more lap out of my aching calves.
The obvious answer is that we run to be healthy, to improve our cardiovascular systems and our moods, to become fitter and stronger.
But sometimes it feels like the real reason that I run is to get better at running.
I run so that I can run more.
llm: Why run?
I'm running because my son is alive today.
My son, who has autism and seizures, had a medical emergency in 2013 that led to his being hospitalized, placed on life support, and put into a medically induced coma.
When he came out of the coma, he was non-verbal, blind in one eye, deaf in one ear, had no fine motor control or hand functioning, and suffered from frequent seizure activity.
His diagnosis also included epilepsy, cerebral palsy, developmental delay, cortical vision impairment, corticobasal syndrome, and global delays.
He was given a very bleak prognosis by many doctors: he would never

human: Another year, another amazing album from Igor Levit.

Like all this pianist’s recording projects, “Fantasia” is daringly yet elegantly programmed: Eight works from across some 200 years, with four meaty masterpieces each set alongside a smaller companion.
llm: Another year, another batch of classical albums that will make your life better.

human: The Supreme Court reiterated on Monday what it had said just two months ago: that the Biden administration may continue to regulate “ghost guns” — kits that can be bought online and assembled into untraceable homemade firearms — while appeals move forward.
llm: The Supreme Court declined Monday to review a ruling allowing the sale of unfinished guns that can be completed at home, a move that could help gun rights activists who say the Obama-era regulation was too burdensome.

The justices let stand a lower court decision that blocked an attempt by Vice President Joe Biden to stop the practice known as “ghost guns” — which is legal in more than 30 states and involves building the firearms without serial numbers or other features needed for registration under federal law.

The case centered on two men who had attempted to make their own AR-15 rifles using parts purchased online, but were stopped by agents from the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF).

human: Apple resumed sales of its newest smartwatches on Thursday, a day after a federal appeals court temporarily reversed an earlier ban on their import and sale in the United States.

human: In September, at Prada’s spring 2024 women’s show, models walked between translucent curtains of pink slime that dripped from the ceiling and pooled on the floor.
The brand referred to them as “fluid interruptions,” a concept that was echoed in the collection’s flowing organza dresses and fringed skirts.
Above all, though, it evoked the secretions of a snail, an animal that has recently been crawling into the realms of design and fashion.
llm: In September, at a conference in New York City, researchers from all over the world gathered to discuss their findings on snail shells.
The focus of the meeting was on the evolutionary changes that have taken place over time in these tiny creatures' shells, which are covered with complex patterns called sculptures.
These patterns help the snails camouflage themselves from predators and also assist them in catching prey by providing a better grip for their tentacles.

human: The Supreme Court is considering whether to take up the question of presidential immunity — that is, the idea that a president, by virtue of the unique nature of the office, is entitled to exceedingly broad protections from legal consequences for statements made and actions taken while in office.
If the court takes up that question in a case regarding Donald Trump, it will have profound consequences for both the 2024 election and the bigger question of presidential power.
llm: The Supreme Court is not a popularity contest, and it's certainly not a beauty pageant, so the president's latest antics are irrelevant.
It's not about how we feel about him; it's about how he feels about himself.
And that should be more than enough to give senators pause before they confirm someone who has already demonstrated an abiding belief in his own infallibility.

human: It’s the latest hot TV genre: a woman in a frigid outpost, bundled in puffy outerwear, trying to uncover truths buried in ice.

human: Around noon on Nov. 17, Sam Altman, the chief executive of OpenAI, logged into a video call from a luxury hotel in Las Vegas.

llm: Around noon on a recent Tuesday, the doors opened and about 200 people began filing into the auditorium at UCSF Mission Bay.

They were there for an event billed as a “town hall” meeting on artificial intelligence, where they could learn more about the cutting-edge research being conducted by one of Silicon Valley’s newest startups, called OpenAI, which is dedicated to developing a superintelligent AI system that would surpass human capabilities in all domains.

human: After a long day at work, I absent-mindedly boarded an express train.
What should’ve been an 18-minute commute home turned into a 50-minute journey from Manhattan to Brooklyn and back.
Sitting on that last train to my apartment, I felt a digital dreariness overcome me.
I’d spent all day responding to emails, Slacks and DMs.
I just wanted to not look at a screen.
I didn’t have a book with me, so I took out my notebook and jotted down everything I saw, heard or smelled: A backpack occupying a seat for a human.
A woman wearing a spiky hat.
Shoelaces, untied.
Shoelaces, tied.
An aggressively yellow ad for something called Mullvad.
“Do Not Lean on Door.”
Snoring.
The person next to me typing out in a text, “Dinner next week?” before quickly deleting it and locking his phone.
llm: After a long day, it’s tempting to just collapse on your couch and watch TV.
But take a moment to observe how you got home: Did you get lost?
Did you make it safely through an intersection that had been under construction all week?
Did you remember to grab your coffee before you left for work?
It can be easy to ignore these small miracles because they happen every day — but it's important to acknowledge them.
In this episode of The School of Greatness, I talk about why we should pay attention to the little things that go right.

human: The New York Police Department detained 34 demonstrators at the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade who were protesting Israel’s killings of civilians in Gaza, the authorities said on Friday.
llm: The New York Police Department on Monday detained and questioned more than three dozen protesters who had gathered outside the annual Thanksgiving Day parade to support Palestinians in Gaza, where a deadly conflict between Israel and Hamas militants has led to an international outcry over the mounting civilian casualties.

human: Even as Israeli tanks and ground troops continued to battle Hamas militants in Gaza, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Sunday outlined a postwar vision for the territory, one that he said would not involve the Palestinian Authority in its current form.
llm: Even as Israeli troops massed on the border with Gaza, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said that he did not see a role for the Palestinian Authority in a postwar Gaza.
"We are dealing with Hamas and we have to deal with it alone," Netanyahu told Army Radio Wednesday morning.
"There is no need to bring the Palestinian Authority into this equation."

human: House Republicans on Friday demanded that Hunter Biden, the president’s son, sit for a closed-door deposition in their impeachment inquiry into his father, rejecting his request to testify only in public and suggesting he could face punishment if he did not agree to their terms.
llm: House Republicans on Friday demanded that the House Intelligence Committee hold a public hearing before taking up a formal impeachment inquiry into President Trump’s efforts to pressure Ukraine to investigate his political rivals.

human: Several months ago, as a federal judge worked through a docket of smuggling cases in the bustling border city of Laredo, Texas, three people were escorted into the courtroom.
llm: Several months ago, I wrote about the practice of holding detainees in secret locations for prolonged periods without charge or trial.
The Obama administration has been criticized for this practice and many other human rights abuses committed under his watch.
In a speech yesterday, however, President Barack Obama attempted to defend his administration's record on torture and detention policies.
He did so by making reference to the Bush administration, saying that it had been far worse when it came to the treatment of prisoners.
This was an attempt to paint himself as a reformer with respect to interrogation methods, and to deflect attention away from recent revelations about the CIA's use of torture.

human: Inflation eased in October and price increases showed encouraging signs of slowing under the surface, according to fresh data released on Tuesday.
The report provided the Federal Reserve with renewed evidence that its battle against rapid inflation is working — and likely reduced the need for further rate increases.
llm: Inflation eased in March, according to the Consumer Price Index released today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
The monthly CPI is 0.2% below its level a year earlier (excluding food and energy), which is the smallest decline since December 2015.
This is good news for monetary policy makers, who will be relieved that inflation pressures have not become more intense as they consider raising interest rates from their current low levels.

human: Responses from a survey of 603 voters in Arizona conducted by The New York Times and Siena College from Oct. 22 to Nov. 2, 2023.
llm: Responses from a sample of 1,584 likely Arizona voters were collected through live telephone interviews conducted by SMS Research and Merrill on September 29th and October 6th, 2016.
Respondents for this survey were selected from a registered voter list that was stratified by gender, age, education, party affiliation and phone type (cell phone only or landline only).
The data were weighted according to voter registration information from the Arizona Secretary of State’s Office and voter turnout history from national, state and local elections.
For results based on the total sample, one can say with 95% confidence that the error attributable to sampling has a maximum margin of +/-2.5 percentage

human: On Oct. 25, Professor Nurit Peled-Elhanan, a lecturer at a college in Jerusalem, participated in a discussion in a faculty WhatsApp group about the horrific events of Oct. 7.

In response to another lecturer’s message, she wrote that “the massacre,” referring to the actions of Hamas, reminded her of something the French philosopher and playwright Jean-Paul Sartre once wrote about race relations, adding a paraphrased quote: “‘After so many years that the neck of the occupied has been suffocating under your iron foot and suddenly was given a chance to raise his eyes, what kind of gaze did you expect you would see there?’
We saw this gaze,” Ms. Peled-Elhanan wrote to her colleagues.
llm: On Oct. 25, a bomb exploded at the home of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Jerusalem.
The blast was so powerful that it shattered windows and damaged cars on the street outside.
Police arrested two suspects shortly after the attack and charged them with attempted murder and causing an explosion with intent to endanger life.
The suspects are being held without bail.
The motive for the attack is still unclear, but many believe that the perpetrators were Palestinians from East Jerusalem.

human: The Republican chairman of the bipartisan House Ethics Committee introduced a resolution on Friday to expel Representative George Santos of New York from Congress, citing the committee’s damning new report documenting violations of House rules and evidence of pervasive campaign fraud.
llm: The Republican chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, Rep. Mike Rogers, said that he's confident there will be a vote on an amendment to the defense bill that would force the president to explain his rationale for not expelling Russia's ambassador to the United States, Sergey Kislyak, and 35 other Russian officials.

The amendment is being led by Rogers' Democratic colleague, Rep. Adam Schiff, who has been a fierce critic of President Donald Trump over his ties with Russia and his decision to fire former FBI Director James Comey earlier this month.

human: Heavy rain and powerful winds stretched up the East Coast, flooding streets and buildings.
In parts of the South, apparent tornadoes tore through homes.
llm: Heavy rain and severe thunderstorms swept across a broad swath of the eastern United States on Monday, causing widespread power outages, flooding roadways and toppling trees in several states.
More than 3 million people were without power as of Monday afternoon, according to the Associated Press.
At least one tornado was reported in Virginia, and a possible tornado hit a mobile home park in western Pennsylvania on Sunday night, injuring at least five people.

human: The Biden administration said on Monday that it is looking into reports by Amnesty International and The Washington Post that Israel used white phosphorus supplied by the United States in violation of international law.
llm: The Biden administration is deeply concerned about the possibility that Israeli forces may be using white phosphorus in Gaza, according to several current and former officials familiar with discussions over the past week involving senior U.S. officials.

The use of the incendiary weapon — which can cause severe burns on exposed skin and emit a toxic smoke when ignited — would represent a possible violation of international law, according to legal experts who spoke with The Huffington Post.

human: Can magic illuminate a life that was far from magical?
llm: Can magic illuminate the elephant in the room?
That question is at the heart of “The Vanishing Elephant,” a new musical with book and lyrics by Jeffrey Hatcher, music by Michael Kooman and direction by Tony Award nominee Leigh Silverman.

The show, which had its world premiere at the La Jolla Playhouse on Tuesday night, tells the story of a young couple (Katie Thompson as Diana and Josh Young as Jim) who are trying to conceive a child — a task made even more challenging when they can’t find a baby elephant.
But when they discover a magician named Chad (Ted Deasy), their troubles begin to disappear.

human: Walking through New York City — America’s great harborer of people, culture and activity — can feel like strolling the world’s largest outdoor mall.

Opportunities to acquire are everywhere, waiting either around the corner or at the end of a subway ride: exotic foods, knickknacks, records, books, medicine, tents, computers, sunglasses and everything else.
It’s difficult to imagine a product one can’t buy in Manhattan, let alone the boroughs.
llm: Walking through New York's SoHo neighborhood, you might think the storefronts are lining up for a fashion show.
The sidewalks of this Lower Manhattan enclave are home to a bevy of high-end stores, including Louis Vuitton and Prada.

human: Ivo Dimchev, a queer performance artist from Bulgaria whose brash charm has been known to compel people to take their clothes off and join him onstage — it happened at Joe’s Pub last month — has questions.
And more questions.
llm: Ivo Dimchev, a Bulgarian-born artist who has been living in Berlin for almost two decades, is an internationally renowned performer and choreographer whose work is known to challenge audiences' expectations about artistic expression and performance.
The program includes his latest production, entitled "Warrior," which features the choreography of Dimchev and the music by composer Antonin Dvorak.
A few years ago, the Bulgarian embassy in Germany organized a series of presentations of Bulgarian culture in order to commemorate Bulgaria's 130th anniversary as a modern state.
One such presentation was a dance show with Dimchev that was held at the German National Theatre in Berlin, where he presented his work titled "The Dance of War

human: As Israeli troops moved toward the border with Gaza before a possible ground invasion to dismantle Hamas, a U.N. official warned of a humanitarian “disaster” in the blockaded territory.
llm: As Israeli troops killed 18 Palestinians in the Gaza Strip, the United Nations warned that a humanitarian crisis is looming for millions of people trapped by an Israeli-Egyptian blockade and under constant bombardment from Israel's air force and navy.
The UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) said it had received reports of more than 200 Palestinian deaths since Monday, including at least 37 children.
At least another 600 were wounded by Israeli forces, OCHA added.

human: Neanderthals were morning people, a new study suggests.
And some humans today who like getting up early might credit genes they inherited from their Neanderthal ancestors.
llm: Neanderthals were morning people, and that's a good thing.
They may have been responsible for the human tendency toward early-morning activity.
In a study published in Current Biology, researchers found that the genetic variations of modern humans with a preference for early risings are more common among Europeans than Asians or Africans.

human: A gritty crime thriller with a dreamlike tone and dense postmodern flourishes, the survival horror video game Alan Wake 2 is often weird and always unpredictable, veering off from its small-town murder-mystery setting to follow surreal and mind-bending digressions.
It has few, if any, video game precedents.
llm: A gritty crime drama is the last thing I'd expect from a game inspired by The Twilight Zone, but that's exactly what Alan Wake 2 could be.

human: Jeff Landry, the hard-line conservative leading the race for governor of Louisiana, surveyed the crowd packed into a small restaurant in Monroe, where his staff had covered the tables and a lone Halloween skeleton in his blue-and-yellow campaign merchandise.
llm: Jeff Landry, the hard-line conservative who is leading a pack of Republicans vying for his party’s nomination in the race to succeed outgoing Gov. Bobby Jindal, has made it clear that he does not care about Louisiana’s longstanding tradition of pragmatic politics.

human: When Michael Stipe was little, his parents called him Mr. Mouse.
He was a scurrier.
As soon as he could stand, he ran, and when he ran, he ran until he face-planted.

His mother would deposit him in a baby walker, but if Stipe scrambled as fast as he could and hit the threshold of a doorway with a running start, he could topple the walker and eject himself onto the floor.
Then he’d spring to his feet and run away.
llm: When Michael Stipe was in high school, he'd often go to the local cinema and sit through movies for hours at a time.
He'd watch the same films over and over again, so much that he memorized all of them.
And one day while watching _
The Great Escape_ , he realized something about himself: "I am not going to be like Steve McQueen or James Garner," he told me recently.
"I'm not going to go out and do anything heroic or daring.
I don't have those kinds of qualities.
But I can write songs.
So that's what I'll do."

human: The prosecution of Brett Hankison, the former police detective who fired 10 bullets through Breonna Taylor’s apartment during a fatal 2020 raid in Louisville, Ky., ended in a mistrial on Thursday after the jury said it could not reach a unanimous verdict on federal civil rights charges.
llm: The prosecution of former Memphis Police Department officer Michael Williams was a mess from the beginning, and it ended with an embarrassing setback for Shelby County District Attorney General Amy Weirich.

human: If you want a friend in Washington, get a dog, Harry S. Truman supposedly once said.
But what if the dog is not all that friendly?
llm: If you want to know how the Democrats are going to conduct themselves in 2020, just read this article.
It is a perfect example of what they have been doing for decades now - trying to destroy their political opponents with lies and misinformation.
I am not sure if the people who run CNN are complete morons or simply evil, but either way, they deserve each other.

human: President Biden is trailing Donald J. Trump in five of the six most important battleground states one year before the 2024 election, suffering from enormous doubts about his age and deep dissatisfaction over his handling of the economy and a host of other issues, new polls by The New York Times and Siena College have found.
llm: President Biden is a disaster.
He will lose in a landslide to Trump.
The only hope for Democrats are some kind of scandal that gets Trump impeached and removed from office.

human: Sidney K. Powell, who spun some of the wildest conspiracy theories about ballot fraud as a member of Donald J. Trump’s legal team after he lost the 2020 election, pleaded guilty on Thursday morning to six misdemeanor counts.
She is one of 19 people, including Mr. Trump, who were indicted in August for trying to subvert the election results in Georgia, and she has agreed to testify against any of the remaining defendants.
llm: Sidney K. Powell, a federal prosecutor from 1989 to 2006 who now works as a defense attorney, said she had not seen the evidence against Mr. Manafort and was not involved in his case.

But she said that given what she knew of the way the government handles cases like this one, she suspected that Mr. Mueller’s team might be building a case based on the same sorts of things she had been dealing with for years: false witnesses, fabricated documents, and other misconduct by government officials.

human: The 2020 presidential campaign was underway, and Anthony Pratt was doubling down on Donald J. Trump.
llm: The 2020 presidential campaign is in full swing.
Candidates are traveling the country giving speeches to supporters and fundraising for their campaigns.
This weekend, at least two Democratic candidates were in Los Angeles:
Senators Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders.
On Saturday, Sanders spoke before an estimated crowd of 18,000 people at a rally hosted by MoveOn.org near downtown LA.
The next day, Senator Warren headlined a gathering sponsored by the Progressive Democrats of America at the Westin Bonaventure Hotel.

human: In the 1970s and ’80s, when Rainer Judd was growing up at 101 Spring Street in New York’s SoHo with her father, the artist Donald Judd, she’d sit in the building’s open windows, “because no one told me not to,” she said, and because back then, SoHo was a “creaky, dirty, lovely place.”
In 1971, her father wrote that one day, the neighborhood might be invaded by “tourist shops and restaurants, bad art and high rents.”

And while this premonition has largely come to pass, his home, a cast-iron former textile factory where his family — which also included his wife, the dancer Julie Finch, and his son, Flavin — lived according to Judd’s influential ideas about art and architecture, is almost entirely unchanged.
llm: In the 1970s, after Donald Judd had moved his studio to New York City from Marfa, Texas, he took on a project that would change his life: He set out to design and build a house for himself in SoHo.
The result was an angular, concrete structure that would become one of the most famous homes in the city, if not the world, and that would influence generations of architects.
In this video, Mr. Judd is interviewed about the building by the author Adam Gopnik, who wrote a book about it.
(The two men have known each other since 1968.)

human: Former President Donald J. Trump’s rivals in the Republican race for president again lined up in his defense on Thursday after Maine barred him from its primary election ballot, the second state to do so.
llm: Former President Donald Trump's longtime lawyer and fixer, Michael Cohen, was sentenced Wednesday to three years in prison for crimes including arranging the payment of hush money to two women just before the 2016 election at the direction of his boss.

human: At the Taipei train station, a Chinese human rights activist named Cuicui watched with envy as six young Taiwanese politicians campaigned for the city’s legislative seats.
A decade ago, they had been involved in parallel democratic protest movements — she in China, and the politicians on the opposite side of the Taiwan Strait.
llm: At the Taipei airport, Mr. Liu told reporters that his visit had been a success: “I have visited many countries and I can say Taiwan is the most beautiful country,” he said.
“The people are very kind to me.”

human: Residents as young as 16 have been granted the right to vote in school board elections in Newark, New Jersey’s largest city, beginning in April, after the City Council unanimously approved an ordinance Wednesday lowering the voting age.
llm: Residents as young as 16 will be able to vote for school board members in the city of Newark, N.J., under a new law that will allow them to participate in the democratic process while still in high school.

human: Last week, a group of federal employees organized a protest of the Biden administration’s support of Israel in its war with Hamas.
Although a snowstorm in Washington complicated their plans, some federal employees from a range of agencies declined to work for a day.

Meanwhile at the Capitol, Republican members of the House of Representatives were once again threatening to throw their institution into chaos to prevent their leader from negotiating a spending package with Democrats.
llm: Last week, a survey was released by Pew Research Center that showed just how cynical the average American is about politics.
According to the survey, 75 percent of those polled believed that “politicians don’t care what people like me think.”
This number is up from 63 percent in 2014 and 48 percent in 1992.
Another poll conducted this year found that only one-in-four Americans has trust in our political system as a whole.

human: My first attempt at crunchy rice was not entirely on purpose.
I was a young, multitasking cook with a pot of rice left on low heat until … wait, was something about to burn?
llm: My first attempt at this recipe was a failure.
I had not read the directions thoroughly, so I forgot to add the sliced onions.
(Yes, I know.
What was I thinking?)
The second time around, I doubled the ingredients, added more spices, and used brown rice instead of white.
And it worked beautifully!

human: The first warning was a blip, a small anomaly picked up by radar scanning the skies over Ukraine.
Within seconds, it became clear that the blip was a Russian ballistic missile streaking in Kyiv’s direction at several times the speed of sound.
llm: The first warning sign came when the Ukrainian Navy received a report from its shore-based radar system, which detected an unidentified aircraft flying toward Crimea.
It was a Russian MIG 29 fighter jet.

human: The White House on Wednesday condemned Representative Rashida Tlaib for embracing a phrase used by some pro-Palestinian groups, a day after the House censured her for her statements regarding the Israel-Hamas war.
llm: The White House condemned Rep. Rashida Tlaib (D-Mich.) for her comments about Israel, saying in a statement Monday that the congresswoman's "callous anti-Semitic tropes have no place in the Congress."

human: Taylor Swift holds the top of the Billboard 200 album chart with her latest remake, while Jung Kook of BTS opens at No. 2 and a posthumous release by Jimmy Buffett lands in the Top 10.
llm: Taylor Swift holds the top spot on the Billboard Hot 100 for a third week, as “1989” earns a second consecutive week atop the ranking of streaming songs.
The track also leads digital song sales and radio airplay, according to Nielsen Music, which tracks the music industry.

human: One of the strangest episodes in the history of the tech industry ended as start-up events often do: with a party in San Francisco’s eclectic Mission District.
llm: One of the most important things I have learned in my 20 years as a software developer and entrepreneur is that you need to be able to deal with chaotic situations.
This is not something that you can learn from books or classes, it's something you have to experience for yourself.
The reason why people don't talk about chaotic situations they experienced is that the experiences are so traumatic that they want to forget them.

human: One by one, the inmates filed into a chapel at Sing Sing Correctional Facility in Ossining, N.Y. — past a line of security officers, past a sign reading, “Open wide the door to Christ.”
Under stained-glass windows, they formed a circle, introducing themselves to a crowd of visitors as composers, rappers, painters and poets.
Then they began to sing.
llm: One by one, the inmates at San Quentin State Prison file on stage.

human: I first heard the band Sleater-Kinney when I was a teenager, and it’s not an exaggeration to say it changed my life.

The early 2000s were a particularly macho time in rock music — all wounded emo boys and nü-metal aggressors — and even in the late ’90s it was difficult to find female musicians lauded for how well they played their instruments rather than the way they looked.
Then I happened upon a live recording of Sleater-Kinney playing its 1997 song “Words and Guitar,” and it blew my hair back like I’d entered a wind tunnel.
llm: I first heard Sleater-Kinney on a radio show called Sound Opinions.
They were playing “Dig Me Out” from the album of the same name, and I was instantly hooked.
It sounded like nothing else I had ever heard.
The drums pummeled your chest while Corin Tucker sang about being in love with someone who didn't know she existed, and it felt good to be alive.

human: Isabella de la Houssaye, a lawyer and prolific endurance athlete who continued to go on daunting adventures around the world with her five children after being diagnosed with Stage 4 non-small-cell lung cancer, died on Saturday in Hermosa Beach, Calif.
She was 59.
llm: Isabella de la Houssaye, Athlete Who Endured Against the Odds, Dies at 59

human: Over 50 actors, artists and other celebrities in France have issued a letter ardently defending Gérard Depardieu, the actor accused of sexual harassment and assault, calling him the victim of a “lynching” and arguing that he should be able to continue working despite a storm of criticism.
llm: Over 50 actors, directors and other French film industry figures have signed an open letter defending the Oscar-winning actor Gérard Depardieu after he was accused of sexually assaulting a woman in a plane.

human: Buying things in bulk at wholesale retailers can be an all-day affair.

Sam’s Club, the store chain owned by Walmart, is trying to make that time shorter: by using artificial intelligence to scan shoppers’ carts so they no longer have to show a receipt at the exit upon checking out.
llm: Buying things in bulk can save you money.
But is it worth the hassle?

human: Despite the chockablock ballroom full of Hollywood’s best and brightest, a jovial emcee in the comedian John Mulaney and honorees the audience seemed thrilled to celebrate, a pall of sadness was cast over the Governors Awards — an event created 14 years ago by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to shorten the Oscar telecast by relegating the honorary Oscars to its own untelevised confab.
llm: Despite the chockablock schedule, there was a lull in the action for the second year running.
But the crowd didn't seem to mind.

human: The political potency of abortion rights proved more powerful than the drag of President Biden’s approval ratings in Tuesday’s off-year elections, as Ohioans enshrined a right to abortion in their state’s constitution, and Democrats took control of both chambers of the Virginia General Assembly while holding on to Kentucky’s governorship.
llm: The political potency of abortion was on full display in 2018.

In the final midterm elections before President Trump takes office in January, the issue of reproductive rights figured prominently in races across the country—and with good reason: It's a topic that motivates Democratic voters like few others.

human: Three people, including a girl, were killed and three others were missing after a landslide struck homes in southeast Alaska this week, the authorities said.
llm: Three people, including a 6-year-old boy, were killed when a landslide struck the Alaskan town of Willow on Sunday night.

The National Weather Service in Anchorage said that the landslide occurred at around 7:30 p.m. local time and was caused by heavy rain from Hurricane Katrina, which made landfall in Florida earlier on Sunday.

human: There are many reasons to be horrified about recent events in the Middle East, and the prospect that attacks on shipping might undermine progress against inflation is way, way down the list.
Nonetheless, if you are trying to forecast inflation, disruption of a major choke point for global commerce — the Red Sea is how ships get to and from the Suez Canal — isn’t what you want to see.
But how big a deal is it?
llm: There are many things to consider when we look at the Red Sea.
First of all, it is a sea and a body of water and not just a plain stretch of land or an area of desert.
It was created by God as part of His creation.
The Red Sea, in the Bible, is called the Reed Sea (Exodus 13:20; Numbers 34:5).
It has been translated that way for centuries, but I have no idea why.
Perhaps because it seems like a reed-like sea.
It is also sometimes referred to as the Gulf of Suez, which is its modern name.
This sea is located on the east coast of Africa between Egypt and Saudi Arabia and extends into the southern end of the Mediterranean Sea.
The

human: Shining out from the Instagram slag heap, amid the endless A.I. selfies and reaction reels, is an account so quiet in presence and noble in intention that it is sometimes hard to believe it exists.
The account, @theAIDSmemorial, is an evolving testament, told in photographs, videos and user stories, to lives lost to a devastating and, it can occasionally seem, forgotten epidemic.
llm: Shining out from the darkness of the night, a young girl runs through the forest.
She is pursued by a group of dark-clad men who have guns.
One of them grabs her and attempts to rape her.
She fights back until she realizes it will not do any good, then gives up.

human: Punctuating a year of major gains for organized labor, Microsoft has announced that it will stay neutral if any group of U.S.-based workers seeks to unionize.
llm: Punctuating a year of intense union organizing at Microsoft, the software giant has agreed not to interfere with employees' efforts to form labor unions.

human: Across the U.S., roughly 6 million adults 65 and over have Alzheimer’s disease.
Almost two thirds of them are women — a discrepancy that researchers have long attributed to genetics and women’s longer life spans, among other reasons.
But there is growing consensus that menopause may also be an important risk factor for the development of dementia later in life.
llm: Across the U.S., a growing number of women are taking estrogen supplements to help ease some of the most common symptoms of menopause, such as hot flashes and night sweats.
But for many women, those benefits don't last long enough — or they have other side effects that make them uncomfortable.
Now, researchers say there may be another way to ease menopausal symptoms: by changing the brain.

human: Sometimes in this job I have a kernel of a column idea that doesn’t pan out.
But other times I begin looking into a topic and find a problem so massive that I can’t believe I’ve ever written about anything else.
This latter experience happened as I looked into the growing bureaucratization of American life.
It’s not only that growing bureaucracies cost a lot of money; they also enervate American society.
They redistribute power from workers to rule makers, and in so doing sap initiative, discretion, creativity and drive.
llm: Sometimes in this life, we have to take our health into our own hands.
But it’s not as easy as just telling yourself that you need to eat better and exercise more—you have to actually do those things.
And there are so many other little things that can throw us off track and derail all of our good intentions.
It’s these “death by a thousand paper cuts” moments that make it harder to maintain your healthy lifestyle.
The best way to avoid them is to be prepared for them before they happen!
Here are 5 of the most common “paper cuts” to watch out for:

human: Dave Chappelle waded briefly into the Israel-Hamas conflict at a show in Boston last week, drawing cheers from some audience members and causing others to walk out as he decried the humanitarian crisis unfolding at the Gaza Strip, according to news reports and a spokeswoman for the comedian.
llm: Dave Chappelle waded into a politically charged controversy about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, saying he was “stunned” by what he called “the level of hate” that led to the massacre of 50 people at two mosques in New Zealand.

human: Once upon a time, there was a princess in Denmark who aspired to become an artist.
llm: Once upon a time, I was an actress.
I'm not going to lie: It was a glorious life.
The hours were long and the pay wasn't much, but there are few things that bring me more pleasure than being in front of a camera or stage.
If you're curious about my acting resume, it is available for your viewing here.

human: Nikki Haley on Saturday blasted Donald J. Trump’s dishonesty and his relationships with “dictators,” questioned his mental acuity and dismissed his mounting stack of endorsements, sharpening her attacks on him as she headed into the final two days of New Hampshire campaigning.
llm: Follow for live updates as we watch the debate.
The first question is on energy policy.

human: When Meg Bellamy got the call that would change her life — the one telling her that after months of auditions, it was she, among thousands of hopefuls, who would play Kate Middleton in the final season of “The Crown” — she was already standing in the shadow of Windsor Castle.
But she wasn’t looking the part of a royal just yet.
llm: When Meg Bellamy was a little girl, her grandmother would tell her stories about how she'd met King George VI when he visited her hometown of York.
The king's sister, Princess Elizabeth (now Queen Elizabeth II), was also there that day.
And so were Bellamy's parents—Bellamy's mother had been working as an air hostess on the plane that brought the royal family to England from Canada.

human: Ukraine scored a major success on Tuesday when it struck a Russian warship at port in Crimea, one of the most significant attacks against Moscow’s Black Sea Fleet in months.
But in another setback for their ground campaign, Ukrainian officials acknowledged that they had all but retreated from the eastern city of Marinka after a monthslong battle to defend it.
llm: Ukraine scored a major success in its fight against Russia-backed rebels on Monday when it hit a Russian warship with a missile for the first time since the conflict began two years ago.

human: My mother and I disagree on a lot, but we often put our disagreements aside to enjoy a healthier relationship, even if it’s on a surface level.
She has been anti-abortion my entire life.
We now live on opposite sides of the country and see each other maybe twice a year.
When she visits, she often speaks of abortion as murder; her tone is visceral.
She is very aware of my pro-choice beliefs, but she does not know that I have had two abortions (neither of which I regret).
I am in my 30s, and each passing year my desire to be a mother decreases exponentially.
Recently, she has begun to complain about her lack of grandchildren.
I have chosen not to tell her about my abortions, because this information might be grief-inducing for her.
But as she continues to push her ideologies on me, I feel more and more compelled to share my life experiences and choices.
What do I owe her?— Name Withheld
llm: My mother and I have had a good relationship all my life, but she is very conservative when it comes to politics and religion.
She does not know that I am gay or that I have had two abortions (one of which was an elective procedure).
My boyfriend and I are going to get married this summer, and we would like her to be there for the wedding.
But I think she will disapprove of our marriage because we do not intend to have children anytime soon.
How can I tell her without hurting her feelings?

human: Taiwan’s defense ministry issued an urgent alert Tuesday about a Chinese satellite launched on a rocket flying over the island, an alarming message that interrupted the final days of campaigning before a major election and spurred accusations of a political ploy.
llm: Taiwan’s defense ministry said that the object was not a rocket but rather a “missile” and that the United States had “conducted exercises with an ally.”
China, however, maintains that it was a satellite.
The Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying told reporters on Monday: “What the U.S. side launched is actually a satellite.
It is not targeting any other country,” according to Reuters.

human: Almost everyone on the stage outside San Francisco’s City Hall on Thursday afternoon was a woman: the vice president, the former speaker of the House, the city’s mayor and more.
llm: Almost everyone on this list should be impeached, but you're right that she is in a class of her own.
She has been a disgrace to California and to the United States since she was first elected.

human: New York Times journalists have received many honors.
But recognition by way of U.S. postage stamps has proved elusive.
It seems that only two people closely associated with The Times have been the subjects of commemorative stamps.
llm: New York Times bestselling author Peter Lerangis is the co-author, with Stephen Gammell, of the classic Newbery Honor book The Ghost of Fossil Glen.

He has written over 100 books for children and young adults, including the #1 New York Times bestsellers The 39 Clues: Cahills vs. Vespers Book 4: Day of Doom, The 39 Clues: Cahills vs. Vespers Book 5: Shatterproof, and the Max Tilt series.
His other novels include Mythology: Timeless Tales of Gods and Heroes; Myth-O-Mania!; and A Penguin's World.
He lives in

human: One of the art world’s top magazine editors was fired Thursday night after the publishers of Artforum said that the staff’s decision to post an open letter about the Israel-Hamas war failed to meet the organization’s standards.
llm: One of the most interesting articles in this morning's New York Times was "Museums Take on Israeli Art, and One Another", by Randy Kennedy.
It describes a dispute between the Whitney Museum and the Jewish Museum over an exhibit of works by Israeli artists at the former institution.

The dispute is not really about content or even about political issues but rather about who gets to be the arbiter of what artworks are worth showing (and which ones should be shown) -- that is, which institutions can claim the role of expert curators and critics.
It also illustrates how museum directors can feel like they have to justify their choices to donors, boards, and other constituents.

human: [Here’s how to vote in Ohio, New York, New Jersey, Mississippi, and Kentucky.]
llm: [Here’s how to vote in Virginia.
The process is pretty simple.]

human: By striking Houthi rebel targets in Yemen with Britain on Thursday, Washington sent a searing message to both the Houthis and its Iranian backers that the United States has ended its longstanding defense-only posture in the Red Sea and is determined to stop the group’s attacks against commercial ships in regional waters.
llm: By striking Houthi targets, the United States is sending a strong message to Iran and its proxies.

human: Over the two weeks that dozens of Indian construction workers have been trapped in a Himalayan road tunnel, the authorities have reported meter-by-meter progress toward reaching them and offered hopeful timelines for their rescue.
Each time a breakthrough has appeared imminent, politicians have rushed to the scene.
llm: Over the two weeks I spent trapped in the tunnel, I couldn't help but wonder what was going on outside.
How could anyone go about their daily lives without noticing that the world had stopped?
I pictured the people who lived above me.
Were they even aware of my existence?
How could they be oblivious to this enormous hole in the ground right underneath them?
My mother and brother had been up in Boston visiting friends when all this happened.
I couldn't imagine how many times they must have driven past the construction site.
Didn't they see something was wrong?
Was it too much trouble to stop and ask someone about it?
I felt like I should have heard from someone by now; there were so many questions running through my head

human: It was a relief to learn of the arrest last week of a 21-year-old Cornell University student for threatening to rape and murder Jews on campus in reaction to the Israel-Hamas war.
It was also an easy case: Violent threats against specific people are illegal, and they are dealt with by the justice system, not school administrators.
llm: It was a bit of a shock to hear my name come up in the conversation, but I suppose it makes sense that someone who has written about how students live would have something to say about this issue.
In fact, I've been thinking about and writing about this topic for years now.
I think that what is being done here by some administrators is akin to taking all the food out of the cafeteria (and cutting off the heat and electricity) so they can make the school better.
It may be good for the soul of the institution, but it does nothing for the people who are actually living there.

human: Material from a binder with highly classified information connected to the investigation into Russian efforts to meddle in the 2016 election disappeared in the final days of Donald J. Trump’s presidency, two people familiar with the matter said.

human: The Senate on Tuesday confirmed Dr. Monica M. Bertagnolli, a cancer surgeon who currently leads the National Cancer Institute, as the next director of the National Institutes of Health, overriding the objections of Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, the chairman of the Senate health committee.
llm: The Senate on Tuesday confirmed Dr. Francis Collins, a former director of the National Institutes of Health, to lead the agency again after a two-year hiatus, despite opposition from some Democrats who wanted an outspoken supporter of embryonic stem cell research and gun control.
The 70-to-25 vote was largely along party lines; three Republicans joined all but one Democrat in voting against Dr. Collins’s nomination.
Dr. Collins is a geneticist with experience as director of the National Human Genome Research Institute at N.I.H., which he led when it completed its mapping of the human genome in 2003.
He also served as the head of the National Cancer Institute before

human: “Inspector Sun,” a computer-animated family film released in Spain last year and now arriving in an English-language dubbed version, is very clearly a product of the director Julio Soto Gurpide and the screenwriter Rocco Pucillo’s deep affection for motion picture history.
The movie draws on a range of classics, from silent adventure serials to screwball mysteries like “The Thin Man” to the swashbuckling epics of Douglas Fairbanks and Errol Flynn.
llm: “Inspector Sun,” a 10-part web series by New York Film Academy (NYFA) Instructor and Filmmaker Ching Wong, is currently streaming on Netflix.

human: On Oct. 26, the Department of Commerce announced that gross domestic product grew at an annual rate of 4.9 percent in the third quarter.
This growth rate ran well above even optimistic forecasts, leading to what can only be called triumphalism from a White House dead set on making Bidenomics a key to its 2024 presidential campaign.
President Biden issued a self-congratulatory statement, and the White House echoed it over and over — and Donald Trump’s relative popularity increased.
llm: On Oct. 26, 1987, the Dow Jones industrial average closed at a record high of 2,500 points.
A few months later, on March 13, 1988, it hit another all-time peak of 2,722.
Then, over the next year, stocks plunged more than 40 percent as the savings and loan crisis began to take hold.
The Dow didn't regain its previous levels until late 1991 — nearly three years after President Ronald Reagan left office.

human: A Minnesota doctor who the authorities said had worked as a poison specialist was arrested on Friday and charged in the death of his wife, Betty Bowman, who died in August from poisoning.
llm: A Minnesota doctor accused of killing his wife with poison is a nationally recognized expert on toxins and poisons who has written books about the subject.

human: David Chang is “pausing operations” at Momofuku Ko next week, according to a post on his company’s Instagram account.

llm: David Chang is a genius.
I can't wait to try this restaurant.

human: Which activities do you look forward to during the holiday season?
Putting up decorations?
Watching movies?
Building gingerbread houses?
llm: Which activities do you enjoy most during the holidays?

human: President Emmanuel Macron of France this week condemned what he called a “manhunt” targeting Gérard Depardieu, the embattled French actor whose worldwide fame has been tarnished in recent years by allegations of sexual harassment and assault.
llm: President Emmanuel Macron of France on Thursday strongly condemned the “manhunt” against Gérard Depardieu, a prominent French actor who has been criticized for his ties to Russia.
Mr. Macron said in an interview with Europe 1 radio that he had spoken about the matter with Mr. Depardieu and that they shared the same view: “The French Republic does not have manhunts.”

human: Growing up in Texas’ Rio Grande Valley, the Opinion editorial assistant Adrian J. Rivera was no stranger to processed food.
As a child, he relished a good Big Mac, a box of chicken nuggets and a cold, refreshing Sprite.
But after moving to the East Coast for college, Rivera’s socioeconomic circles began shifting, as well as his worldview around food.
In this audio essay, he reflects on his relationship with processed food, class and what it’s like to go home with a new set of tastes.
llm: Growing up in the 90s, I was a huge fan of McDonald's.
To this day, my favorite food at any fast-food chain is still the Filet-O-Fish sandwich (seriously, who can resist that creamy sauce?).
But even as a kid, I knew it wasn't exactly healthy to eat so much fast food.
And I always wanted to know what went into each and every one of those burgers, fries, shakes, etc.
So when I saw the following tweet last week, I couldn't help but laugh.

human: LONDON — The British Government will continue to make protests to Washington in all cases of seizures of suspected rum-runners outside of the three-mile limit until the reciprocal rum treaty is ratified by the two countries, the correspondent of The New York Herald was informed today at the Foreign Office.
llm: LONDON — The British and French governments today said they would continue to seize rum-ships until the United States Government agreed to a settlement.

human: Metro Bank, an upstart British lender, said on Sunday that it has raised 325 million pounds, or $395 million, in new capital to help ease regulators’ worries about its financial health.
llm: Metro Bank, an upstart lender that has been struggling to keep pace with its larger rivals in the United Kingdom, said on Monday it had raised £375 million ($480 million) from investors who will help shore up its finances.
The new capital comes at a time when Metro Bank is facing rising bad loans and competition from more established banks, including Barclays and HSBC Holdings.
It also follows news of losses at two other small British banks this month — CYBG, which owns Virgin Money, and TSB Bank, which was bought by Banco Sabadell last year.
Metro Bank, which specializes in consumer banking services, said the capital injection would help reduce its reliance on debt

human: An off-duty pilot who was in a jump seat in the cockpit of an Alaska Airlines flight on Sunday was charged with more than 80 counts of attempted murder after he tried to cut fuel to the engines, prompting the plane to divert to Portland, Ore., the authorities said.
llm: An off-duty pilot who allegedly tried to cut the engines of an airliner before takeoff at Los Angeles International Airport was arrested Saturday and is being held in lieu of $100,000 bail.
The unidentified man was removed from his seat shortly after the plane began taxiing toward the runway, according to the Federal Aviation Administration.
He had been seen tampering with the engine's cowling, or covering, as the jet sat parked near the terminal, said FAA spokesman Ian Gregor.
Investigators are trying to determine whether he intended to harm passengers or the aircraft, Gregor said.

human: A couple of weeks ago, a young crowd in Shanghai came out in force to celebrate Halloween.
The street where I live filled with revelers dressed in a range of elaborate costumes — as the white-clad enforcers of China’s Covid lockdowns, as Chinese courtesans or simply as a watermelon.
Halloween allows us to dress up as something that we can’t otherwise be.

It’s a strong impulse right now in China, which remains stuck in a postpandemic malaise marked by job shortages, a trend of disillusioned 20-somethings dropping out of the work force and society and a general yearning for a different way to be.
llm: A couple of weeks ago, the U.S. China Policy Institute at Tsinghua University in Beijing released a study entitled “The 21st Century Marriage between Aging America and Young China.”
The report was written by several Chinese scholars and one American (myself), and it was published on March 8, which happens to be International Women’s Day.
It is therefore timely to consider what its conclusions might mean for relations between our two countries in this century.

human: Krayzie Bone, a member of Bone Thugs-N-Harmony, one of the most influential rap groups in history, has been fighting for his life for several days, he said in a post on social media on Monday that included a photo of him in a hospital.
llm: Krayzie Bone, a member of the popular group Bone Thugs-n-Harmony, has shared his health crisis on social media.

human: It was one of New York City’s most enduring crises: For decades, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority had warned that it was teetering on the brink of financial ruin.
llm: It was one of those stories that seemed to sum up a lot about the city and its subways: an op-ed in The New York Times by Michael Miscione, a transit advocate who had recently left the Metropolitan Transit Authority, explaining how the agency had managed to reduce costs while improving service on some routes.

human: Maj. Gen. Roland Lajoie, who, behind the geopolitical scenes, played a leading role in coordinating U.S.-Soviet relations during the last decade of the Cold War, and who later oversaw the destruction of hundreds of nuclear weapons belonging to the former Soviet republics, died on Oct. 28 in Manchester, N.H.
He was 87.
llm: Maj. Gen. Roland Lajoie, a former chief of staff for NATO who helped plan military operations to counter Soviet aggression in Europe during the early years of the Cold War, died June 13 at his home in Fort Worth, Texas.

human: Downstairs at the Louisiana Museum of Modern Art, about 20 miles north of Copenhagen, a woman is urinating on President Vladimir V. Putin.

Balanced on a table above a black-and-white portrait of the Russian leader, her blonde hair and face shrouded in a bright-red balaclava, she hitches up her loose dress and answers nature’s call, drenching the photograph before kicking it to the ground.
llm: Downstairs at the Hideout, 1354 W. Wabansia Ave., Chicago (map)

human: In the era of modern consumer confidence data, there has never been an economy quite like this recent one — with prices rising so high and unemployment staying so low.
llm: In the era of Trump, this is a good time for Jewish organizations to rediscover their Jewishness.

This means understanding that the American Jewish community has always been an ethnic and religious minority, not just a civic or political one; learning how it used to deal with those realities; and figuring out what role its members can play in combating them today.

human: Ever since I was a little girl I’d dreamed of going to Darjeeling.
My imagination was captivated by this town nestled in the foothills of the Himalayas in the Indian state of West Bengal.

Surrounded by lush, terraced tea gardens that extend across rolling hills, with the majestic snow-capped mountains behind them, Darjeeling is one of India’s most stunning hill stations, known as the Queen of the Mountains.
llm: Ever since I can remember I've had this urge to explore the world.
As a child growing up in New Delhi, India my parents would take me on long walks through our neighborhoods.
They would point out things that I wouldn't have noticed myself - like the bark of a tree or the color of the sky.
My curiosity grew with every new thing they pointed out to me.
I still remember how excited I was when we moved from New Delhi to Bangalore (now Bengalooru).
The excitement wasn't because we were moving to a bigger city but because we were going to move into an apartment building near a park.
It was one of the best decisions my parents made.
I spent almost all my time in the park.
There

human: On May 20, 1964, on a hilltop in New Jersey, an unlikely little structure called the Holmdel Horn revealed telltale signs of the Big Bang, and the birth of the universe we live in.
The Horn has been much in the news this fall, as it survived a threat of demolition.
llm: On May 20, 1964, a Russian satellite named Zond 3 blasted off from Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan.
Its mission was to orbit the sun and take pictures of Venus.

But on its way out it snapped a few photos of Earth as well — including what would become one of the most iconic images of all time: a picture of the Earth, known as the Blue Marble, taken from space.

human: “Everything needed for the front,” Russia’s finance minister declared, echoing a Soviet slogan from World War II as he talked about the government’s latest spending plans.
llm: “Everything needed for the war is manufactured here,” said Vitali Yaroshevsky, deputy head of the Donetsk-based Center for Army, Conversion and Disarmament Studies.
“There are no sanctions.”

human: She flirted with Brando and even Prince Charles.
She has been romantically linked with a succession of Hollywood hunks — think Warren Beatty and Ryan O’Neal.
llm: She flirted with the idea of becoming a lawyer.
She considered studying drama, but her parents insisted she study voice.
It was the best decision they ever made.
Barbra Streisand has won two Academy Awards and earned 10 Grammy awards.
The singer/actress is also known for her style.
She has been photographed in everything from glamorous gowns to casual jeans and T-shirts.
A few years ago, Barbra shared some secrets about how she stays so youthful looking, how she keeps her hair shiny and healthy, and why she'll never retire from performing live.
Here are excerpts from that interview:

human: A few blocks from where the Cronut was born, a new pastry mash-up by a French chef is making its debut.

Gregory Doyen developed a cakelike confection inspired by brownies and cookies that’s round, about three inches in diameter, fairly dense and with a central opening where a ganache or fruit filling goes.
Mr. Doyen is calling it MOD, for multilayered original dessert.
It’s offered as a single serving ($7.50 each) and in fours ($29), and can be shared and personalized.
In a show of extreme confidence, it’s the only product sold in the bright white shop of the same name he owns with Edward Geyman, his business partner.

A native of the Burgundy region in France who studied pastry-making and has been a pastry consultant in many countries around the globe, Mr. Doyen, 38, arrived in the United States a year ago and began working on this project.
“I didn’t just want to reproduce French pastry,” he said.
The flavor and filling combinations are endless.

For now he has eight colorful examples, including peanut butter and jelly, matcha with white chocolate, walnut with dark chocolate, red velvet with dark chocolate and raspberry, and pecan caramel with milk chocolate chips and sea salt.
He has a featured flavor of the month, which for now is s’mores with a marshmallow topping that he torches before serving.
He said he’s working on a mini size.
llm: A few blocks from the Chelsea Market is the Chelsea Brewing Company, which opened in 2014 and brews its beers on site.
A former garage has been converted into a small, casual bar with seating for about two dozen customers, who can also take advantage of picnic tables outside when weather permits.
There are seven beers on tap at any time, including a rotating seasonal selection, but you'll find the same four core beers available year round: IPA, Pilsner, Honey Blonde Ale and Stout.
The Chelsea Brewing Company also offers growlers to go.

human: It will be a long time before any of us understand what happened after Oct. 7, but it seems important first to recognize how news of everything comes to us today.

Newspaper headlines aren’t fixed — they change over the course of a day; social media presents tragedies in fragmented shards, which are then contested and rejected and reaffirmed; television news, especially on foreign affairs, remains too hyper and flashy to take seriously.
Every single one of us had our own individualized experience of that day and the days after it.
No one can confidently say who knew what when.
llm: It will be interesting to see what happens when the next generation reaches adulthood.

human: Trader Joe’s, West Hollywood.
“Your total is $20.69,” announces the cashier at my register.
Seconds later, the cashier at the next register over says to a male customer, “Your total is $20.69.”
Wait, what?
The staff whoops.
Someone says, “No way!”
He and I grin sloppily in the sudden spotlight, paired so arbitrarily by groceries.
Bystander: “It’s a rom-com opening, baby!”
The other $20.69 meets my eyes, testing gently for truth in that idea.
For a moment, I entertain another universe — one where I’m not gay — and smile wide.
Then I say, “Good night.”
— Zoe Marie Bel
llm: Trader Joe’s, Westfield Montgomery Mall, 10300 W. Montgomery Road, Bethesda; 240-675-9388.
"Grapefruit with Fennel & Thyme Salad"

human: For this landmark biography, Tick, a music historian, leans on a rich trove of archival research — in particular, articles from recently digitized Black newspapers — as well as new material from Fitzgerald’s family, including a scrapbook the jazz legend kept when she was 18.
llm: For this landmark 50th anniversary edition, the authors have prepared a new introduction to provide fresh insights into their work and a special afterword that offers a glimpse of what is next for the field.
They also include an extensive list of suggested reading on related topics and links to videos that demonstrate key concepts from the book.

human: “It is up to us to write our own history,” declares the organizer of the desperate project at the heart of Lauren Grodstein’s latest novel, WE MUST NOT THINK OF OURSELVES (Algonquin, 304 pp., $34).
He’s speaking on a bleak afternoonomg in one of the bleakest places in Poland, the Warsaw ghetto in December 1940.

Those he will secretly assemble in the upstairs room of a library are intent on preserving the biographies of at least some of the hundreds of thousands of Jews imprisoned by the Nazis in three square kilometers of the city.
llm: “It is up to us to keep the spirit of democracy alive.
It is up to us to keep it strong and vibrant.”
-President Obama

human: Qatar is engaged in high-level discussions with Hamas to deliver vital prescription medicines to Israeli hostages in the Gaza Strip at the same time it is making progress with Israel about allowing more medicine into the enclave for Gazan civilians, officials said.
llm: Qatar is engaged with Hamas in talks to deliver medicine for Palestinian hostages held by the group, according to a senior official of the organization.

human: Young women from across genres — along with the Recording Academy’s favorite polymath spoiler Jon Batiste — reigned atop the nominations on Friday for the 66th annual Grammy Awards, to be held Feb. 4 in Los Angeles.
llm: Young women from different musical worlds came together to make a great record that got nominated for Album of the Year.
They also made an EP with one song (“Sunshine”) written by another woman, Julien Baker.
The other two songs on the EP are written by their producer, Phoebe Bridgers, who is a solo artist in her own right.
I can’t say it enough – boygenius is a triumph of female collaboration, something we need more of in this music industry.
So why was this group ignored at the Grammys?
Maybe because they didn’t conform to the traditional Grammy categories.

human: The final game of the playoff series between the Houston Astros and the Minnesota Twins on Wednesday lasted only two hours and 38 minutes.
It was a crisply played game — which the Astros won, 3-2 — that highlighted Major League Baseball’s biggest accomplishment this season.
Thanks to a 15-second clock that prevents players from dawdling between pitches, the average game lasted just two hours and 40 minutes this season, down a remarkable 24 minutes from last season.
llm: The final game was played at the Polo Grounds in New York City.
The Giants were defeated 3–1 by the Phillies, who won their second straight championship and fourth overall.
This would be the last time a team with a losing record would win the World Series until the 2016 Chicago Cubs.

human: We ask that no spoilers be posted in the comments.

llm: We ask that you take the time to review and respond.

human: There’s big news this week for tiny warriors.
llm: There’s big news for fans of Warhammer 40k and those who like their science fiction gritty.
Amazon Studios has announced that it is developing a series based on the popular Games Workshop IP with Man of Steel star Henry Cavill attached to executive produce.

human: A highly lethal form of bird flu that has been spreading across the world has now been detected in a dead polar bear in Alaska.
It is the first known case in the Arctic animals, which are listed as threatened under the Endangered Species Act.
llm: A highly lethal strain of H5N1 bird flu has been discovered in a dead polar bear on the northern coast of Alaska.
The strain, which is similar to one that caused an outbreak in birds in 2006 and killed some 400 people worldwide, marks the first case of lethal bird flu in polar bears.

human: Thousands of readers reacted to the articles in the Dying Broke series about the financial burden of long-term care in the United States.

llm: Thousands of readers shared their experiences with long-term care in a recent Reader Forum.

human: Filoli, a grand house and garden on 654 acres of rolling green grounds near the California coast, has been a supporting character in the 1980s television drama “Dynasty” and the 2001 romantic comedy “The Wedding Planner.”
It has been the venue for top-dollar nuptials of Facebook executives, and the public can tour the gardens.
llm: Filoli, a grand Italianate villa in Woodside, Calif., is one of the state’s most popular wedding venues.
