human: Last week, I asked you to submit a song that feels like fall.

So many of you responded with such evocatively autumnal suggestions that it became quite a daunting task to whittle them down to a relatively compact and cohesive listening experience — but I somehow managed, and I have that playlist for you today.
llm: Last week, I asked readers to vote for their favorite songs of fall.
It was a close race between the top two contenders, but in the end, I have to hand it over to Nirvana's "Smells Like Teen Spirit."
The song is the No. 1 pick with nearly 25 percent of all votes cast.
Readers also chose Bob Dylan's "All Along the Watchtower," the Cure's "Lovesong" and Hall & Oates' "Rich Girl" as runner-ups.

human: During the difficult months of 2020, a writer friend and I decided to read Willa Cather’s fiction together.
What a good antidote to despair that was.
Much of it was rereading, but I’d missed some stories and novels, and I’d never read them sequentially or with a clear sense of Cather’s life.
That spring I also delved into several of the biographies, which taught me something about how such books can vary.
llm: During the difficult months after the publication of her most recent novel, The Song of the Lark, in 1915, Willa Cather was living with friends in New York City.
It was a time when she needed support and encouragement—and also a way to escape from what she called “the world’s ugliness.”
She had always been drawn to small towns; now, more than ever, they offered her the solace that she craved.

human: Jeff Landry, the Louisiana attorney general and a hard-line conservative, trounced a crowded field of candidates on Saturday to become the state’s next governor, cementing Republican control of Louisiana after eight years of divided government.
llm: Jeff Landry, the new governor of Louisiana, is a former police officer and prosecutor who made his name as a state legislator by pushing for tougher sentences for violent crime.
He has been critical of the federal government’s response to Hurricane Katrina, saying that the “federal government needs to get out of our way.”

His first act in office was to repeal an executive order from his predecessor, John Bel Edwards, which would have allowed undocumented immigrants to pay in-state tuition rates at public colleges and universities.
He also vowed to abolish Common Core educational standards, calling them a “national curriculum” that puts too much emphasis on testing.
Mr. Landry won with 56 percent of the vote,

human: You didn’t have to be a financial wizard to get a safe return of more than 7 percent on your money for decades to come.
All you had to do was buy a 30-year U.S. Treasury bond in the last nine months of 1994.
llm: You didn’t have to look far on Wall Street this year to find the best-performing investment.
The U.S. Treasury market was up 10 percent in 2016, and that wasn’t even counting interest payments.
It was the third straight year of double-digit gains for government debt, which has become a magnet for investors seeking safety amid political turmoil at home and abroad.

human: Pee-wee Herman’s toys, Robert Gottlieb’s plastic handbags and other unexpected treasures.
llm: Pee-wee Herman’s toys, Madonna’s bedroom furniture and the last pair of socks that David Bowie ever wore are among the objects that will be displayed in a new exhibition at New York City’s Museum of Arts and Design.

The show, “Collecting Contemporary,” which opens March 10, features items from the personal collections of seven artists: Marina Abramović, Laurie Anderson, Glenn Ligon, Pee-wee Herman (a.k.a. Paul Reubens), Matthew Barney, Louise Bourgeois and Catherine Opie....

human: After winning major gains in wages and benefits from two of the three Detroit automakers, the United Automobile Workers union is looking beyond the Motor City to car companies operating nonunion factories across the South.
llm: After winning major contracts from General Motors, Ford and Chrysler this year, the United Automobile Workers union is turning its attention to nonunion auto manufacturing plants in hopes of gaining even more market share.
The UAW has already begun talks with several foreign automakers in Michigan and Ohio about organizing their facilities here.

human: On Christmas Eve in 2013, Elisa Stead, an American living abroad in Iceland, was ready to celebrate the holiday with her fiancé and his family.
But when she tore open the wrapping on his gift for her, she was disheartened to discover what lay inside: a car-window scraper.
Sure, she lived in a frosty place, but she didn’t own a car.
Receiving such a thoughtless gift made for an unhappy holiday, and the relationship ended within the year.
llm: On Christmas Eve, 2017, I was driving home from work in the dark.
The streets were lit up with twinkling lights and a slight drizzle made them sparkle even more.
The holiday season is my favorite time of year, so as I looked out the window and listened to the music on the radio, I felt happy and grateful for the life I have been given.
As I approached the intersection where I turn onto my street, I noticed a man standing by the side of the road with his hands outstretched toward me.
At first, he appeared to be holding something, but when I got closer I realized that it was an empty plastic bag.
When I reached him, he said, “I’m homeless.
Can you

human: Celebrities streamed onto the lush red carpet to pose in front of the floral backdrop for the Golden Globes on Sunday night as the awards ceremony made a return to television (it wasn’t broadcast in 2022, and was moved to a Tuesday evening last year).
llm: Celebrities streamed onto the red carpet for the 77th annual Golden Globe Awards on Sunday, January 5.
See who arrived to the ceremony at the Beverly Hilton Hotel in Los Angeles and what they wore on the red carpet!

human: Is there something you have read, watched, listened to, eaten, visited, played or otherwise experienced this year that you think is so bad that you want to discourage others from experiencing it?
If so, what and why?
llm: Is there something in particular that you would like to warn others about?
I'd like to know your thoughts.
Please comment below.

human: By Canadian standards, the 10.4 billion Canadian dollar military purchase announced this week moved at light speed, possibly within as little as nine months.
llm: By Canadian standards, the amount of money involved in this deal is not particularly large.
But to an American eye, it's a lot of cash.
The Canadian government announced on Monday that it will spend $10.4 billion dollars to buy Lockheed Martin F-35 fighter jets.
It will be the largest military procurement contract ever awarded by Canada, and one of the biggest deals in the country's history.

human: Less than 24 hours after condemning terrorism in the Middle East in one of the most powerful speeches of his tenure on Tuesday, President Biden was back before television cameras for another statement.
llm: Less than 24 hours after Vice President Joe Biden took a leading role in trying to contain an international crisis with Russia and Ukraine, he was back at his house in Delaware, where the family is vacationing.
Mr. Biden has had little time for himself since becoming vice president last year.
He and his wife, Jill, have been running the White House residence, entertaining guests and planning their daughter Ashley's wedding.
But as the world's attention has turned to the crisis between Russia and Ukraine, which involves a Russian incursion into Crimea, Mr. Biden has been called upon to step forward.

human: My wife became pregnant soon after we met, when our relationship was “fluid” and non-monogamous.
We agreed to raise the child together and, at my urging, to have an open relationship.
However, our relationship since has been monogamous.
My wife was injured during the birth of our second child and now finds sex painful and avoids it.
(We had a terrific sex life before the injury.)
When I broached the topic of having other partners and reminded her of our agreement to have an open relationship, she became irritated and said that having kids changed things.
Subsequent discussions resulted in a stalemate.
llm: My wife became involved with a man and decided to have him join us in our home for sex on the weekends, while she remained married to me during the week.
She has told me that she would like to do this for a long time now
and I agreed to it so we could work through some issues in our marriage.
Now, however, she is saying that she doesn't want to continue and wants to stay married only to me.
I am very hurt by this because I thought we had finally come up with a solution to what I felt was a failing marriage.
What should I do?

human: The ruins of Mitla sit about 30 miles from Oaxaca in the mountains of southern Mexico, built on a high valley floor as a gateway between the world of the living and the dead.
The site was established in roughly A.D. 200  as a fortified village, and then as a burial ground by the Zapotecs, the so-called Cloud People, who settled in the region around 1500 B.C.
llm: The ruins of Monte Alban are among the most impressive in all Mexico.
As you drive up to it from Oaxaca City, you can see the hill rising above the surrounding valley and the city of Oaxaca spread out below like a huge amphitheater.
When we arrived at the top of the mountain after climbing 1200 steps (no joke), I could not imagine that anything else was worth seeing once you've seen Monte Alban.

But then we turned around and looked back down the mountain at Oaxaca with its ancient buildings and narrow cobblestone streets winding through the central marketplace, and I thought I'd never want to leave this place.
It is one of my favorite cities in the world.
We stayed for four days,

human: Good morning.
It’s Wednesday.
We’ll meet someone who can laugh at Dracula because he’s like family.
We’ll also find out why grade inflation has become an issue at Yale University.
llm: Good morning.
It’s currently 7:20am
and I have just finished watching the above video with Mr. Mullaney, which was put together by The Hollywood Reporter.

human: For the two days after a gunman killed 18 people and injured 13 in Lewiston, Maine, Patrick Hynes and other residents in the area sat in their own homes, under a shelter-in-place order, facing their grief, their rage, in isolation.
llm: For the two weeks since a gunman killed five people in Portland and wounded several others before being fatally shot by police, Maine's second-largest city has been on edge.

human: Israeli citizens, barricaded in their homes in towns near the Gaza Strip, called into television stations as Palestinian gunmen crossed the border into Israel and invaded their communities on Saturday morning.
The Israelis spoke in whispers as they pleaded desperately for help.
llm: Israeli citizens, barricaded in their homes, have been forced to live for the last 30 days with the threat of rocket attacks.
On Thursday, one such attack killed three Israeli teenagers as they were hitchhiking on a road near the city of Kiryat Shmona.
The killing was followed by the discovery of two bodies of missing Palestinian boys who had gone missing from their homes in the West Bank city of Hebron.

human: “Put on your masks!”
llm: “Put on your own oxygen mask first.”
This is a mantra of flight attendants to ensure that passengers are safe and secure in an emergency.
Yet, the same principle does not seem to apply when it comes to public health organizations and their mission to protect and promote the public’s health.
Instead, as we continue to struggle with the impact of the Great Recession, many agencies have taken an “if you can’t beat ‘em, join ‘em” approach to survival.

human: Fuel shortages in the Gaza Strip have grown so dire that the U.N. agency that has helped feed, school and shelter Palestinians there for decades said Wednesday that it might have to start shutting down operations.
llm: Fuel shortages in Gaza have caused the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestinian Refugees to cut back on food rations for thousands of people.

human: The Safdie brothers, the filmmaking duo behind “Uncut Gems” (2019) and “Good Time” (2017), are splitting up.
llm: The Safdie brothers, Josh and Benny (who together are known as the "Safdies"), have decided to part ways after 10 years of working together.
The brothers directed their first film, "Daddy Longlegs," when they were just teenagers, which was followed by a string of smaller films before their feature debut with "Heaven Knows What."
Since then, they've had three more features under their belts, including their latest film, "Uncut Gems," starring Adam Sandler.
In an interview with IndieWire, the Safdies said that they decided to go separate ways because of creative differences.

human: Maine’s top election official said on Friday she intended to appeal the ruling by a state Superior Court judge this week that placed on hold her decision to exclude former President Donald J. Trump from the state’s Republican primary ballot.
llm: Maine’s top election official is appealing a judge’s ruling that she must allow President-elect Donald Trump’s name to be printed on the state’s November ballot.

human: The fate of the sons of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the man accused of being the mastermind of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, has long been a source of mystery and controversy.
llm: The fate of the two sons of Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, who was accused of masterminding the September 11th attacks on the World Trade Center and Pentagon in 2001, has become one of the most mysterious aspects of the 9/11 case.
Their mother and stepmother both claim they were killed by their father, but U.S. authorities have never confirmed that and say no remains have been found.
The latest twist: One of the brothers is apparently alive after all.
In an interview with Der Spiegel magazine published Sunday, Mohammed said his son, Omar, is alive — and he claims he's in Syria.
"He is still living," Mohammed told the German weekly

human: Nikki Haley ratcheted up her calls this week for the U.S. government to ban TikTok, the Chinese-owned social media platform, after some users, weighing in on the war between Israel and Hamas, promoted “Letter to America,” a text written by Osama bin Laden after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
llm: Nikki Haley ratcheted up her calls to ban the popular video-sharing app TikTok after a letter purportedly written by Osama bin Laden was found circulating on the platform, in which the terror leader called for “jihad” and described the Sept. 11 attacks as “a good thing.”

human: What books are on your night stand?
llm: What books are always in your handbag?

human: When a jury of military officers is assembled this week at Guantánamo Bay, it will be asked to choose a sentence in the 20- to 25-year range for two Malaysian prisoners who admitted to conspiring with an affiliate of Al Qaeda that carried out a deadly bombing in Indonesia two decades ago.
llm: When a jury finds someone guilty of murder, they are sentenced to death.
That is the law in this country.
The Indonesian court did not sentence them to 20 years each, but to life imprisonment.
If their sentences were commuted after five or ten years and they returned to Bali then what?
It would be like allowing someone who had been convicted of first degree murder out on probation!

It's bad enough that they can appeal their convictions in Indonesia for many years while doing nothing except writing letters from prison, but to allow them to return to Bali after serving only five or ten years is ridiculous.
I know that we have different laws here, but you cannot change the law after a verdict has been handed down by an Indonesian court.

human: A prominent cancer center affiliated with Harvard said it will ask medical journals to retract six research papers and correct dozens of others after a British scientist and blogger found that work by some of its top executives was rife with duplicated or manipulated data.
llm: A prominent cancer center is taking the unusual step of seeking retractions or corrections for dozens of its own published research articles, saying it needs to correct the scientific record after finding errors.

The move by the University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center in Houston comes amid an intensifying debate over how much importance to place on scientific papers that are later found to contain mistakes.
Such investigations can take years and often result in a correction being published months after the original paper was published.
(Begley, 8/10)

human: “I was delighted to learn from this charming song all about the qualities, habits and foibles of the unicorn, or ‘monoceron,’” a character says near the start of “The Hunt,” Kate Soper’s latest work of music theater.
llm: “I was delighted to see that the filmmakers had created a new character, the outspoken young woman of color, so rare in medieval stories,” writes Dr. Laura Lindenfeld, Professor and Chair of History at UMass Boston.
“They also chose an actor of color for this role, which is even rarer.
The storytelling does not lose sight of the fact that the protagonist, Lady Mercy, is the daughter of the Earl of Northumberland and the niece of King Edward III.”
Read more about her review here.

human: The future of OpenAI is in jeopardy after more than 700 of its 770 employees signed a letter yesterday saying they may leave the company for Microsoft if the ousted chief executive, Sam Altman, is not reinstalled at the high-profile artificial intelligence start-up.
llm: The future of artificial intelligence is at stake.
The technology that will determine whether AI is an instrument of good or evil rests on the shoulders of a handful of tech titans and their competitive, unregulated rivalries.

human: Aleksei A. Navalny, Russia’s most prominent opposition leader, who is currently serving a 19-year sentence in a Russian penal colony, missed another court date on Monday as his allies expressed concern at not having heard from him for more than five days.
llm: Aleksei A. Navalny, a leading Russian opposition leader who has been repeatedly jailed for organizing antigovernment protests, missed his latest court hearing on Monday after being hospitalized in the city of Kirov with an undisclosed illness, his lawyer said.

The absence of Mr. Navalny, 42, from a Moscow court hearing on charges that he embezzled money from a state-owned timber company during his tenure as its deputy governor, raised alarm among his supporters.
"It's very strange," said Vladimir Bukovsky, one of Russia's most prominent dissidents and a friend of Mr. Navalny's.
"I can't remember such a case where the defendant was hospitalized on the

human: We’re living through an era of collapsing paradigms.
The conceptual frames that many people use to organize their understanding of the world are crashing and burning upon contact with Middle Eastern reality.
llm: We’re living through a moment of unprecedented upheaval and uncertainty across the globe.
The conflicts that are roiling our world today, from Syria to Yemen, have left millions dead or displaced.
It is no exaggeration to say that we are witnessing the largest refugee crisis since World War II.
And it is easy to feel powerless when faced with these challenges.
How can one person make a difference?

human: Pakistan announced yesterday that it had carried out strikes against what it said were terrorist hide-outs in Iran.
A day earlier, Iran hit what it called militant camps in Pakistan.
The military exchange is the latest example of an expanding set of hostilities connected to the Israel-Hamas war.
llm: Pakistan announced yesterday that it had conducted airstrikes against militant targets inside Iran, retaliating for an attack on a Pakistani military base by the Jaish al Adl (Army of Justice) group.
The Jaish al Adl is a Sunni Islamist organization with ties to Al Qaeda and other groups fighting in Syria and Iraq.
It has been accused of killing Shi’ite Muslims and members of minority religious sects in both countries, as well as members of the security forces.
The attacks have led to hundreds of arrests in Iran since 2013, according to reports from Tehran.
In addition, the Iranian government recently executed two men accused of being members of Jaish al Adl.

human: “It all began with writing,” goes the first line of Adam Thirlwell’s latest novel, in which a young socialite named Celine is slandered in pornographic, anonymously authored pamphlets circulating in prerevolutionary Paris.

Four pages later, Thirlwell clears his throat — actually, Celine’s publicity troubles go back to the Big Bang: “The universe disintegrates into a cloud of heat, it falls inevitably into a vortex of entropy, but within this irreversible process there may be areas of order, portions of existence that tend toward a form, in which it might be possible to discern a design — and one of these was this story of Celine and her friends.”
This could have gone without saying, but Thirlwell can’t help himself.
In “The Future Future,” the English writer compulsively gestures to the biggest picture and decides it’s the gesture that’s profound.
llm: “It all began with a pair of socks.”
So begins David Wroblewski’s “The Story of Edgar Sawtelle,” which has been on best sellers lists across the country since its release in August.

The book, a historical novel that is also a mash-up of the centuries, has been praised by critics as original and spellbinding, but it is not without controversy: Some readers find the novel too slow to get started or too depressing; others think the prose is uneven, and some have called it pretentious.

human: Heather Sellers wrote her Modern Love essay in 2013, about reconnecting with her elderly, estranged father.
Although their relationship was painful, Heather made sure that her last words to her father were “I love you.”
And at the time, that felt like closure.
llm: Heather Sellers wrote an essay in the New York Times Magazine.
It's about plagiarism and the ethics of writing.
She was accused of plagiarizing someone else's work.
And she wrote a response, which is reproduced here:

human: The linen closet did not hold nearly enough sheets to blunt the vengeance of a late-May freeze that turned umbrella-like Astilboides leaves into alien life-forms.
llm: The linen closet is my office.
I've got a small table, some file boxes, and two shelves.

The floor is covered with papers--reprints of articles from newspapers, magazines and books; clippings from newspapers about the garden; copies of catalogs that have come in the mail (I'm afraid to get rid of them because there are so many good ideas); letters from people who have been helped by this column or from readers asking questions or giving me information about their own gardens.
There are also a few pictures of plants or flowers that I have taken on visits to other gardens.

human: The collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, the conviction of Sam Bankman-Fried, the reassertion of union power and the turmoil at OpenAI were just some of the big business stories in a year that was full of them.
llm: The collapse of the U.S. stock market in October 2023 led to a severe economic downturn, and it was not until April 2025 that the market recovered.
The stock market rally was driven by the rise in the value of technology companies, such as Amazon and Alphabet.
It also marked the beginning of the second stage of the technology boom, which was triggered by artificial intelligence (AI).
AI had begun to be used more frequently for tasks previously performed by humans, but it gained greater importance during this time due to the increased availability of computing power and data.
Increased automation began to threaten many jobs, especially those involving repetitive tasks.
This led to widespread unemployment, with nearly one-third of

human: The president of Harvard, Claudine Gay, will remain in her job, the university announced on Tuesday, despite demands for her resignation because of her testimony in a congressional hearing on campus antisemitism.
llm: The president of Harvard University is under fire from the faculty after a scathing investigation found that she did not manage her department as well as other top university officials.
Here are five things to know about Claudine Gay:

human: Talk to any friends of the writer Hisham Matar, and he has many, and soon they’ll bring up one of his more notorious pastimes: Have you ever seen how he looks at art?
llm: Talk to any writer about the perils of writing, and you will quickly find that this is a profession that loves to bemoan itself.
We are perpetually haunted by the specter of failure.

The question of whether or not we will ever be good enough plagues us, and even when we manage to put something down on paper, there is always the nagging sense that it could have been better—that somehow our talent has failed us again.

human: Q: I live in a co-op apartment on the Upper West Side.
There is a rent-stabilized apartment on my floor occupied by an older couple who have lived here for 50 years and have serious health issues.
This morning, one of the occupants, who has advanced dementia, opened my apartment door, which was briefly unlocked, and was standing in my living room!
I was able to gently escort her back to her apartment.
Building management said that they have spoken to the city’s adult protective services, which has investigated and declined to act.
This is a terrible situation — there are no interested family members, and the couple is often unbathed and walking the halls.
What can we do?
llm: Q: I live in an apartment building with four other families.
My elderly neighbors are so sweet and wonderful to everyone.
They always bring us gifts on holidays and share their produce from their garden.
Unfortunately, they also have a daughter who lives with them and is a drug addict.
She steals things around the house and has been caught shoplifting at our local grocery store.
The rest of her family doesn't seem to care about what she does or how she behaves.

human: In late 2016, when the private equity mogul Leon Black was trying to sell one expensive piece of art to buy another without incurring a hefty tax bill, he turned to the one man he knew who could help pull it off: his friend Jeffrey Epstein.
llm: In late 2016, a collector with a passion for art and an eye for value was looking to sell a piece of property that was not his primary residence.
He needed to raise cash quickly because the sale would fund part of a real estate transaction that he had agreed upon months earlier.
The piece of property was worth $57 million, but the buyer was only offering $49.5 million — and the seller wanted at least $63 million.
A big gap remained between what they were willing to pay and what the seller wanted to receive.
So the seller turned to someone who could close the deal.
That person was Jeffrey Epstein, according to two people familiar with the matter.

human: After the brass band packed up its instruments, Sergio Solano and two other food delivery workers walked a white bicycle to an overpass within view of the United Nations headquarters.
llm: After the brass band played and the crowd cheered, a man stepped forward to speak.

He had been a food delivery worker for 15 years — a job that many people disdain as unglamorous, but one he loved because it gave him the freedom to be his own boss, to work when he wanted and to take time off whenever he needed it.

human: What happened in the wake of those arrests would expose a juvenile justice system that was playing by its own rules.
For over a decade, this county had arrested and illegally jailed hundreds, maybe thousands, of children.
It would take years, but eventually one lawyer, a former juvenile delinquent himself, asked: Why?
The answer would lead back to a powerful judge, the jailer she appointed and a county that treated this astronomical number of arrests as normal.
llm: What happened in 1970?
You probably don't know, but we do.

human: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has long cast himself as a friend of Israel and the Jewish people.
llm: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Thursday offered a muted response to the Israeli air raids in Syria, saying that “everything” should be done to prevent escalation and avoid civilian casualties.

human: A New York City carriage driver was charged with animal cruelty on Wednesday in a case arising from a feeble horse’s collapse on a busy Hell’s Kitchen street in August 2022.
llm: A New York City carriage driver has been charged with animal cruelty after a horse collapsed and died in his care.
According to police, 62-year-old Michael Cohan was driving the carriage when he passed out at about 10:45 a.m. on Sept. 7 while turning onto East 38th Street from Second Avenue.
The horse fell over and began breathing heavily.
Cohan then allegedly attempted to push the horse back up using his foot.
After being revived by emergency personnel, the horse collapsed again.
It was later euthanized.
Police are now investigating whether Cohan, who was released on $1,000 bail, was suffering from a medical condition that caused him to pass out.

human: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau on Wednesday proposed a rule that would sharply limit overdraft charges at the largest banks and credit unions in the United States, a change that the agency estimated could save households up to $3.5 billion a year in fees.
llm: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) issued a proposed rule to implement Section 1075 of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act.
The proposal would limit overdraft fees charged by banks with assets over $10 billion, and require banks to allow customers to opt out of overdraft protection programs.

human: At the top of Mount Hamilton, near San Jose, Calif., Lick Observatory looks out over the dense sprawl of the San Francisco Bay Area.
On a clear day from the 4,200-foot summit, you can see San Francisco to the north, as well as the entrance to Yosemite Valley, 120 miles east, as the crow flies.
At night you can see even farther — millions of light-years into space.
llm: At the top of this page, you will see a list of links to articles about historic observatories.

We also have an article in the Journal of Astronomical History & Heritage (Vol 12 No 3, pp 175-180) on the history of the University of Arizona Steward Observatory, which is available as a pdf file from the following link: http://jahh.aas.org/content/pdfs/12/3/175.pdf.

human: “Two things are true: Israel must do something, and what it’s doing now is indefensible.”
So writes Zack Beauchamp, a senior correspondent at Vox.
llm: “Two things are happening in the Middle East: The Arab world is going through a revolutionary process and the Iranians are getting closer to their goal of having nuclear weapons.
The U.S. has been unable to stop either one.
So what should Israel do?
It’s not enough just to say ‘the Palestinians must make peace.’
That was said 20 years ago.

human: It was just after noon on an early September Saturday when the first call came.
llm: It was just one of those days, and I needed a break from my usual routine.
So when my cell phone rang on Thursday afternoon, it wasn't as big a surprise as you might think that it would be.

human: Apparently, some time in 1964, a professional ice skater and animal trainer named Dave Pitts, on the road with his chimp Spanky, picked up a young hitchhiker who was in the middle of a killing spree.
The story of Pitts’s encounter with Larry Lee Ranes, whose brother also became a serial killer, was fictionalized in Conrad Hilberry’s book “Luke Karamazov.”
That book is the source of “He Went That Way,” the picturesque feature directing debut of the cinematographer Jeff Darling, who died in a surfing accident in 2022.
llm: Apparently, some time ago, there was an American serial killer who would always go to his victims' homes and take their shoes.
He would then go home and use them as part of his ritual.
It is unknown if he did this with all of his victims or only some of them.
There are also different versions about how he would get into their houses (he would break in, or they would let him in).
What I know for sure is that it happened in America and that he was caught.

human: Donald J. Trump is showing surprising resilience on the abortion issue, appearing less vulnerable than fellow Republicans despite his key role in shaping the Supreme Court that overturned Roe v. Wade.
llm: Donald J. Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, has said he is “very pro-choice,” but his position on abortion has been vague and sometimes contradictory, making it hard to predict how he would govern if elected.

human: As the Kremlin reveled in the failure of Congress to approve new military assistance for Ukraine and President Biden railed against Republican lawmakers for “kneecapping” an ally in their hour of need, Ukrainian soldiers, political leaders and Kyiv’s allies were all left asking the same question on Thursday: What happens if the United States stops providing military assistance?
llm: As the Kremlin's troops have overrun eastern Ukraine, the Obama administration has been debating whether to continue supplying Kiev with antitank weapons and other military equipment.

The question is being weighed as American officials assess how much influence they can exert on a new Ukrainian government that is increasingly at odds with the United States over its pro-Russia policies and its efforts to investigate corruption by members of President Viktor Yanukovich’s party.

human: The math performance of U.S. teenagers has sharply declined since 2018, with scores lower than 20 years ago, and with American students continuing to trail global competitors, according to the results of a key international exam released on Tuesday.
llm: The math performance of 15-year-olds around the world declined in 2012, with only a handful of countries posting gains in math skills and only one country—China—making significant progress in math over the past decade, according to results of the latest round of the Program for International Student Assessment (PISA), released today by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD).
The report found that, in general, girls outperformed boys in every country except Turkey.

human: A man rented a room in an Atlanta suburb on Airbnb last week, and then robbed the host at gunpoint, the police said.
llm: A man rented a room through the home-sharing service Airbnb and then robbed his host at gunpoint early Monday morning in the Wrigleyville neighborhood on Chicago’s North Side, police said.
The 46-year-old victim was asleep when he heard someone knocking on his front door around 1:30 a.m., according to Chicago police News Affairs Officer Veejay Zala.
He went to answer it but saw that no one was there, so he closed the door and got back into bed, Zala said.
“As soon as he did this, he felt something hit him over the head,” Zala said.
“He turned around and (the suspect) put a gun to his chin.”

human: Since fleeing Syria a decade ago, Wafa Mustafa has spoken out for political prisoners at the United Nations, held vigils outside war crimes trials and chanted in solidarity with Iranians protesting their authoritarian government.
llm: Since fleeing Syria and arriving in Germany, he has been arrested at least 12 times for expressing his views.
He was charged with “inciting hatred” on social media for criticizing the German government’s support for Israel during the 2014 Gaza War.
In January, a court fined him €13,500 (US$16,897) after he called for “jihad” against Jews.

human: Vice President Kamala Harris, President Isaac Herzog of Israel, Elon Musk and other leaders in business and politics spoke on everything from artificial intelligence, economic tensions between the United States and China, and Hamas’s Oct. 7 attacks on Israel at the annual DealBook Summit in New York on Wednesday.
llm: Vice President Kamala Harris (D) speaks during the second night of the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia , July 26, 2016.

human: An elite hacking group sponsored by Russian intelligence gained access to the emails of some of Microsoft’s senior executives beginning in late November, the company disclosed in a blog post and regulatory filing on Friday.
llm: An elite hacking group tied to the Russian government appears to be responsible for a cyberattack that exposed the personal emails of top Microsoft executives, according to an analysis of the breach published Wednesday.

human: A plane crash that killed dozens of people in Nepal in January was caused by a pilot who pulled the incorrect levers while trying to land, the country’s investigators said Thursday.

human: Darryl George, the Texas high school student who earlier this year was removed from school because his hairstyle violated a dress code, was suspended again on Tuesday, the latest flashpoint in a monthslong dispute over a school policy that has spilled into the courts.

human: Javier Milei was first introduced to the Argentine public as a combative television personality with an unruly hairdo and a tendency to insult his critics.

human: When Scotty Scott was about 8 years old, his aunt Yvonne made him stem pounds and pounds of green beans for a big holiday dinner.

But Aunt Yvonne caught on quickly.
“What are you doing, man?”
she asked when she saw his pile of odds and ends.
“No, no, no, no — get back in there!
You know how to snap beans.”
llm: When Scotty Scott left his post as president of the National Restaurant Association to become CEO of Famous Dave's in 2016, he had a list of priorities that included expanding the company’s brand awareness.

human: When they look at Hunter Biden, many Americans don’t like what they see — and not just because of the images of the president’s 53-year-old son in the midst of wild-eyed benders, which were leaked from his laptop and published online, first piecemeal and then in a massive batch in June.
llm: When they look back on the Hunter Biden scandal in years to come, what will be most striking about it is not its sheer length or the fact that it has been going on for so long.

Nor will it be the way it was discussed by journalists and pundits in a manner more appropriate to a murder mystery than an actual investigation of corruption involving a major political figure (in this case, Joe Biden).
No, what will strike people in retrospect as most remarkable about the Biden affair is that it wasn't a big deal at all.

human: If you loathe cockroaches, you’re going to love the emerald jewel wasp.
llm: If you loathe cockroaches as much as I do, this will make your day.
Researchers from Australia have discovered a tiny wasp that preys on the pests by paralyzing them with venom before it eats their heart out.
The wasps use a stinger-like organ to inject victims with a neurotoxin that causes them to stop moving and go limp.
Then they lay eggs inside the still-living creature until it's time for the larvae to hatch.
The entire process takes about 10 days, during which the wasp feeds off the cockroach's blood through its mouth or via a tube connected to its body.
The researchers named the species Megaplatypus sp

human: The stretch of time that unfurls in the sublime Japanese drama “Monster” begins with a fire and ends during a monsoon.

These elemental disasters, and a fragile cluster of events that fall between them, are viewed from the perspectives of three characters entwined in a messy struggle for understanding: a boy, a mother and a teacher.
llm: The stretch of time between the 1950s and now has produced a wealth of films about monsters.

The genre’s evolution over the last half-century has been nothing short of remarkable; from Frankenstein to Godzilla, we have seen the creature feature evolve into something more than just the slapstick horror that was once its primary function.
Monsters are no longer simply creatures to be feared but rather metaphors for the evil within humanity itself.
This is certainly the case with “Monster,” a film in which three different perspectives tell the same story, yet each reveals a different truth.

llm: Anthony Vidler, an architectural historian who reshaped the field with a new way of looking at the history of architecture through the study of buildings as cultural artifacts and whose writings helped redefine modernism as more than just a movement in art, died on Aug. 10 in Los Angeles.

human: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who is running for president as an independent, announced on Tuesday that he had filed paperwork to create his own political party in six states — an effort to get his name on the ballot with fewer voter signatures than would be required for an unaffiliated candidate.

He made the announcement at an event in Washington where he introduced his running mate, Susan Collins, a Maine state senator.
Ms. Collins, whose Senate term ends next year, has said she would not run again.
Mr. Kennedy also announced that he had been appointed as presidential candidate by the National Committee of the Free Soil Party.

human: The history of Armenians in Nagorno-Karabakh was ended in the old manner of conflict resolution: siege, conquest, expulsion.

llm: The history of the world is a history of technology, and the 20th century has been the era of technology.
The 21st century will be the era of biotechnology -- when science fiction becomes fact.
As you read this book, keep in mind that every time you hear about something new being invented or discovered, just wait five years and it'll be available at Wal-Mart for less than $20.

human: For many years, Rebecca Chamberlain designed clothes for famous brands, mostly to make ends meet.
During the coronavirus pandemic, she started doing it for herself — by turning old garments into modern, sophisticated pieces.
llm: For many years, I have been a collector of discarded clothing and textiles.
I don't know why this is so, but when I see old clothes in the trash or on the street, my first instinct is to pick them up and take them home with me.
The second thing that happens after I bring these pieces of clothing into my house is that they get put into storage boxes for future use.
I like to think of myself as a recycler of sorts because I am not just putting items away for later, I am actually re-purposing them.
The majority of my wardrobe has come from thrift stores, garage sales, and even trash cans.

human: It was Nov. 17, 2022, and Kenneth Smith was lying on a gurney inside Alabama’s execution chamber, his arms and legs strapped down as he waited to be put to death.

llm: It was Nov. 15, 2016, and the state of Alabama was preparing to execute Domineque Ray for killing a police officer during a botched robbery in Birmingham seven years earlier.

human: Jasmine, one of two protagonists in Jean Kwok’s intriguing fourth novel, “The Leftover Woman,” reveals little to the reader at first.
Seeing her on the streets of Manhattan’s Chinatown, we quickly understand that she’s a woman with a complicated past.
But like the frumpy clothes she wears to disguise her appearance, her thoughts and words are meant to throw us off the track.

As Jasmine trudges from one job interview to the next, searching for work that will help pay off the “snakeheads” who helped her emigrate from China, she remains as invisible to readers as she is to her pursuers.
llm: Jasmine, one of the main characters in The Widows of Malabar Hill, is a widow whose husband was murdered.

When she meets Perveen Mistry, the novel's other central character, at court to discuss her late husband's will, Jasmine is already on edge: She has just learned that her husband, Asad, had been having an affair with another woman.

human: Kali Uchis basks in pleasure on her fourth studio album, “Orquídeas.”

The album begins with loops of laughter and ethereal oohs and ahs; it ends with Uchis thanking listeners with a “mwah” kiss.
It’s an album of breezy confidence and sly ingenuity, easily moving among futuristic electronics, 1990s nostalgia and Latin roots.

human: Born in Mulhouse, France, in 1907, Jean Schlumberger was constantly sketching as a child.

In his early 20s, he defiantly moved to Paris and opened a jewelry workshop on Rue La Boétie, where he handcrafted delicate floral brooches out of Meissen porcelain, antique cameos and decorative Victorian objects he found at the Marché aux Puces.
His fantastical creations soon captured the attention of the fashion world.
After spotting Princess Marina of Greece and Denmark in a pair of his earrings in 1937, the Italian couturier Elsa Schiaparelli commissioned him to design buttons shaped like fruits and insects.
llm: Born in Mulhouse, France, the artist studied at the Académie Julian and École des Beaux-Arts in Paris.
In 1908 he moved to New York City where he became a naturalized citizen in 1924.
He taught painting at the Art Students League from 1935 until his death.

His work is included in many public collections including The Metropolitan Museum of Art; Whitney Museum of American Art; Brooklyn Museum; Smithsonian American Art Museum; National Gallery of Art; National Portrait Gallery; Corcoran Gallery of Art; Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts; Newark Museum; Museum of Modern Art; Solomon R. human: Caboodle was a sweet but average cat.

When she died in September 1999, my husband and I buried her under a rose bush in our backyard.
That October, the month of my 50th birthday and long after the last rose had faded, a single bloom emerged.
For about 10 years after Caboodle’s death, a single rose would bloom in mid-October.
Pretty extraordinary, for an average cat.
— Judith Karp

human: Fifty years ago last month, Erica Jong published a debut novel that went on to sell more than 20 million copies.

Jong’s heroine, Isadora Wing, was a live wire.
She was also a dead end, certainly for Jong, and maybe for feminism, too.
llm: Fifty years ago, “Fear of Flying” by Erica Jong was published, introducing the world to a new kind of female protagonist: one who wanted sex but also had ambitions, an independent spirit and a fierce desire for her own life.
The book is as relevant today as it ever was, if not more so — especially when you consider that women still face sexual harassment in many workplaces.

human: At the risk of evoking unpleasant memories of high-school English, can we please discuss the word allegory?

I caught two shows last week — Dana Schutz’s and Tracey Emin’s — that represent the two extremes.
llm: At the risk of being accused of hypocrisy, I think it's fair to say that I have always been a fan of Dana Schutz's work.

human: Humans are a remarkably ambitious species.
We came to the edge of lands we could safely chart and built ships that would carry us to the unknown.
When travel by water and land no longer suited us, we took to the skies.
After journeying among the clouds could not sate our spirit, we turned our hearts to the stars.
llm: Humans are a plague upon the Earth, a cancer of unimaginable proportions.
I am as guilty as anyone and probably more so because I have seen through the illusion that is our civilization.
The truth is that we are destroying this planet and all life on it at an ever increasing rate.
The time has come for us to stop pretending that we can continue to live as we do now and still survive.
We cannot.
If we don't change course soon enough, we will be extinct before too long.
And I fear for my children's children in particular.
What kind of world would they have to grow up in?
It doesn't bear thinking about.

In one video, a tunnel was shown leading from a building atop Shifa hospital to a smuggling tunnel that led to Israel, apparently intended for use by militants to carry out attacks.
Another tunnel ran underneath the empty school compound where some 300 displaced families were living.

human: On a Cape Cod beach last January, I braced for my daily cold water plunge.
“Can I join you?” asked a stranger.
I hesitated.
But her red hair and wide smile reminded me of my younger self.
“Sure,” I said.
Ashley is 29.
For seven minutes in frigid water, we shared our stories: her chronic illness and career change; my failed marriage and struggles raising a child with cancer.
Every day since our first encounter, we’ve met to immerse ourselves in the ocean.
We bond in a daily baptism.
I now can’t imagine braving water, or life, without her.
— Amy McHugh
llm: On a Cape Cod beach, a couple is looking for a casual fling.

human: We could talk, I suppose, about all Taylor Swift’s done for the economy, friendship bracelets, seismology and Travis Kelce.

In short, Taylor Swift has experienced some of the worst treatment anyone should have to endure, which is why she was so vocal about not voting for Donald Trump.

human: The first large offshore wind farm in New England has started producing electricity, a milestone for an industry that has struggled to get off the ground over the past year.

The 130-turbine project has been a long time coming and was once derailed by lawsuits from neighbors who feared it would spoil their views of Nantucket Sound.

human: The Italian Alps are renowned for their stunning scenery, fine wine and good food.
But many travelers are unaware that the region also hosts exquisite Renaissance and Baroque art.

Nestled in the mountains and hills of northwestern Italy, just an hour’s drive from Milan, a cluster of Catholic sanctuaries brim with sculptures and frescoes by artists like Gaudenzio Ferrari, Tanzio da Varallo and Pier Francesco Mazzucchelli.
llm: The Italian Alps are a unique and fascinating part of Europe.

With its beautiful mountain scenery, rich culture and history, Italy’s mountains have been visited by many famous explorers throughout time including Marco Polo, Christopher Columbus, Cesare Beccaria, and the French writer Alexandre Dumas (who wrote The Three Musketeers).
For this reason, it is no surprise that there are many pilgrimages in the area.
From the Holy Land to Santiago de Compostela, the Alpine Mountains have long been a destination for travelers on foot from all over the world.

llm: The Israeli military’s strategy of eradicating the Hamas infrastructure in Gaza is working, according to a report by Jerusalem Post.

The paper reports that the number of tunnels leading into Israel has been reduced from 32 to just three, and the number of rockets fired at Israel has decreased from more than 1,000 per day to less than 50 since the start of Operation Protective Edge on July 8.

human: Bret Stephens: Gail, my attention these past few weeks has been devoted almost entirely to outrages and tragedies in the Middle East.
But I couldn’t help smiling for a second when Nikki Haley called Vivek Ramaswamy “scum” at last week’s G.O.P. debate, after he raised the subject of her daughter’s use of TikTok.
llm: Bret Stephens: Gail, you're so right about wishful thinking.

The problem with the Obama administration is that it has a lot of people in it who don't understand the world very well and are prone to wishful thinking because they think things can be changed by just saying them.

But I think the fundamental flaw in this administration -- and perhaps, unfortunately, all administrations -- is that their foreign policy seems to be driven more by what the president wants to say than what he should say.
And as you pointed out, the president has made some extraordinarily foolish comments when it comes to Iran.
So if you ask me, there are worse things in politics than wishful thinking.

human: Michael Bennett, the former N.F.L. player, started designing furniture as a way to reconsider architecture and the spaces that Black people occupy.

Inspired by his upbringing in Louisiana and Texas, as well as by trips to Senegal, where his ancestors are from, Bennett began to think about the objects that “bring Black people together in public spaces” as a way to deepen his longtime activism work focused on racial justice.
After retiring from football in 2020, he founded the design practice Studio Kër.

Bennett’s exploration of the Black home led him to create an 11-piece collection of sculptural furniture that he’s debuting this month in “We Gotta Get Back to the Crib,” his inaugural exhibition for the Los Angeles art gallery Marta, presented at Theaster Gates’s Rebuild Foundation in Chicago.
(In the spring, the show will travel to Houston.)

The collection reimagines objects of communal gatherings; pieces include the Gumbo lounge chair, a lush take on the stackable monobloc chair, and the Pew couch, a nod to the church bench, made of leather and ekki wood.
“For me, the show is about celebrating Black ingenuity and connecting back to that African diasporic design language,” says Bennett.
“We Gotta Get Back to the Crib” is on view from Jan. 12 through Feb. 10, marta.la.
llm: Michael Bennett, the defensive end for the Seattle Seahawks and a graduate of U.C.L.A., has become one of the most recognizable players in the league.
He’s also an entrepreneur who has found success with his company, MMB, which creates furniture and home decor items.

human: We know — 2023 isn’t over yet.

For the cookie swap, you’ll want to refer to our 2023 Cookie Week recipes, but any sweet treat would be perfect paired with a bubbly tinto de verano.
(Yes, summer is in the drink’s name, but this refreshing mix of red wine and citrus soda is delightful year-round.)
And you have several options for that family dinner: white chicken chili (above), shrimp tacos or this perfect eggplant Parmesan that’s already dressed in red and green.
llm: We know — it's only January, but we're already making predictions for the next decade.
In 10 years (and five more after that), will we still be eating burgers and fries?
Will we have cured cancer or discovered a new planet?
Maybe, maybe not.
But one thing is certain: the recipe list at Food52 will change dramatically over the coming years, as our audience grows and evolves with the food landscape around them.
To celebrate this exciting time in our community's history, we asked you to tell us what you want to see on our site, and you responded in droves.
Here are the most popular recipes you shared with us in 2023.

human: If you feel the need to shower daily, you’re certainly not alone: In one 2021 survey of more than 5,700 U.S. adults, over 60 percent of the respondents said that they showered at least once each day.

Some people find it helpful to take quick 5-minute showers instead of long ones.
Others have found it beneficial to cut back on shampooing as much as possible so they can get out of the bathroom faster.

human: In recent years, much of my life as a consumer has shifted to what I like to call background spending.
As I’ve subscribed to more apps and streaming platforms, significant sums of my money tend to drift away each month without my ever thinking about it.

It’s as if it were a tax being taken out of my paycheck, one spent on something silly or indulgent like a subscription box of international snacks instead of — I don’t know — basic public infrastructure.
llm: In recent years, there's been a growing trend in the entertainment industry to switch from physical media (like DVDs and CDs) to streaming services like Netflix and Spotify.
These services have made it easier than ever for consumers to access a wide variety of content without having to purchase anything up front — but that convenience comes at a cost.

And it turns out that those costs are getting harder and harder to ignore: According to new research, people who subscribe to multiple streaming music or video services end up paying hundreds more per year than they think they do.
The average person pays about $240 annually on these services, according to a report by the Wall Street Journal, which is around 65% higher than what most people would guess

in the night.

And so I do have some understanding of the issues that face young women in their formative years.

In fact, one of my most vivid memories is going into my daughter’s room at age 14 (she was 5′-3″ and weighed about 98 pounds) and finding her on top of her bed reading “My Secret Garden,” the famous novel by Nancy Friday detailing the sexual fantasies of teenaged girls.
It was pretty shocking to find this book among her other books.

human: The Biden administration announced new moves on Friday to curb the release from oil and gas facilities of methane, a potent greenhouse gas that is responsible for more than a quarter of the warming the planet is currently experiencing.

The plan calls for the administration to require power plants to stop burning coal by 2030, make new cars zero-emission vehicles by 2035, create a new national reforestation program, and set goals for public transit.

human: The future of OpenAI, the start-up that quickly became a titan of the artificial intelligence industry after its release of ChatGPT last year, is in doubt.

llm: The future of artificial intelligence is here, and it's being built by a generation that doesn't know what the word means.
The technology has been called everything from magic to a threat to humanity, but the reality is much simpler: It just makes computers smarter.
As Google, Amazon, Apple, Facebook, Microsoft and other tech companies race to build the best brain in the business, their algorithms are making breakthroughs that will reshape our world—and theirs.
And they're doing it with a bunch of 20-somethings who didn't know how to tell time when they started college.

If Hezbollah had been content with just swapping prisoners, then there's no reason why Israel shouldn't have been happy with it.

human: Africa has the fastest growing, youngest population of any continent.

human: The word exhortation has appeared in 30 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 20 in “One More Chorus of ‘Humm Baby’ for a Baseball Lifer” by Scott Miller:
llm: The word exhortation comes from the Latin verb exhorrare, meaning to call out.
In ancient Rome, exhortations were made by public speakers during political assemblies in order to inspire people and influence their decisions.
The term was later applied to any speech intended to encourage or motivate an audience.

human: On the day before my sister Julie died, I lay down on her bed and held her gingerly in my arms, afraid that any pressure would hurt her.

Her abdomen looked like the lunar landscape, with protrusions everywhere, the sources of her pain plainly visible.
llm: On the day she was scheduled for surgery, my sister decided not to have it.

human: For decades, Jada Pinkett Smith has been plagued by misconceptions: about the dynamics of her marriage to Will Smith, about her bond with Tupac Shakur and, most recently, about the Slap at last year’s Oscars.

llm: For decades, Jada Pinkett Smith has been a force of nature in Hollywood.
A child star who became a teen icon and then an adult sex symbol before morphing into the matriarch of one of America's most famous families, she has always managed to surprise us with her work.
Whether as a dancer on The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air or a singer on HBO's Girls, she has always shown that she is willing to explore and push herself.
But even after nearly three decades in show business, she was still struggling to find her voice—and to get it out there.

human: For months, Argentina has been consumed by a single question.

human: For decades, South Korea’s economy has been dominated by a handful of family-run conglomerates that hold outsize wealth and influence and factor into nearly every aspect of life in the country.
llm: For decades, South Korea's chaebols—the family-owned conglomerates that dominate its economy—have been at the center of political power.
But now, as they struggle with declining popularity and stagnant growth, their influence is starting to wane.
In the past year alone, Samsung Group founder Lee Kun-hee was indicted for bribery, while Hyundai Motor Co. chairman Chung Mong-koo was arrested over embezzlement charges.
In this podcast, Reuters Breakingviews columnists Jack Farchy and Kane Wu discuss how the chaebols have lost their grip on South Korean society and what this means for the country's future.
(Produced by Dan Murtaugh)

human: When a Swiss museum announced in September that it would be putting three paintings by Paul Cézanne, the Impressionist master, up for sale at auction, there was immediate protest by some who suggested the sale violated ethical guidelines on when institutions should sell off their works.
llm: When a Swiss banker who was also an art collector died in 1937, he left behind two of the most famous works by Paul Cézanne.
Now those paintings are at the center of a battle between the family that inherited them and the museum that houses them: the Cantonal Museum of Fine Arts in Lausanne, Switzerland.

The banker’s grandson, John Ganzoni, is challenging the museum over what he says is the institution’s failure to comply with a Swiss law requiring it to sell artworks when necessary for financial reasons.
Mr. Ganzoni has filed a complaint against the museum with the Federal Administrative Court in St. Gallen, which is expected to make a ruling on the case

human: The complex dance of doubt and religious faith is frequently cast in terms of a quest.

One might be “on a faith journey,” or be “a lost soul,” or be “searching” for meaning and the divine — all images derived from the idea of starting at one place, keeping your eyes open, and ending up, ultimately, in some final destination.
Small wonder that many human cultures imagine a wander in the wilderness, literal or metaphorical, as pivotal to one’s initiation into maturity.
Some fresh wisdom and revelation comes from walking around in circles for a while.
llm: The complex dance of art and commerce in the visual arts is not new, but it's always fascinating to see how different artists approach it.

human: When the Spanish singer María José Llergo talks about flamenco, it often sounds as though she is describing something springing from beneath her feet.

llm: When the Spanish-born María José Llergo first arrived in New York, she was 18 years old and full of ambition.
Her plan: to study music at the Manhattan School of Music, then join the Metropolitan Opera.
She knew nothing about flamenco, which had only recently become popular on this side of the Atlantic.
But when an acquaintance introduced her to a class of flamenco singers at the school, she immediately felt drawn to it.
“I discovered a whole new world,” says Ms. Llergo, now 35.
The next year she dropped out of the opera program, enrolled in a flamenco master class instead, and has been singing and dancing ever since.

human: The elected school board in Sarasota, Fla., took the rare step on Tuesday of calling for the resignation of one of its own members, the latest development in an ongoing scandal involving a power couple in state Republican politics.

human: A North Dakota woman has been accused of fatally poisoning her boyfriend with antifreeze in what the authorities say may have been a plot to claim part of his $30 million inheritance.

human: Former President Donald Trump won the New Hampshire primary, but Nikki Haley said the race is far from over.

human: The next few weeks of the war in Gaza may be especially important because the Biden administration is pressuring Israel to shift to a less intensive approach by late January.

human: Modestly scaled and tonally perfect, “Fallen Leaves” opens in a fluorescent hell-on-earth and ends with a vision of something like paradise.
In between, there are lonely nights, fleeting joys, ordinary degradations, laborious work, karaoke reveries, many cigarettes and more drinks.
A lot of the drinks are downed hurriedly and often furtively by a man, while elsewhere a woman listens to sad songs.
Outwardly, these two are leading lives of quiet desperation, though because this is an Aki Kaurismaki movie, their despair comes with great comic timing.
llm: Modestly scaled and unabashedly romantic, Fallen Leaves is a wry love story about a man and woman who are trying to make sense of their lives.

human: The Supreme Court declined today to decide whether Donald Trump is immune from prosecution on charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election.

llm: The Supreme Court declined to expedite the consideration of a case that would have decided whether President Donald Trump is immune from subpoenas by Congress.

The court action was expected after the justices agreed in June to temporarily block a lower court decision requiring Trump to comply with congressional subpoenas.
The justices are also weighing whether they should decide whether sitting presidents can be forced to testify or hand over documents to law enforcement officials.

The truth is that the first Thanksgiving was a celebration of white supremacy.
It was also an act of betrayal by the Wampanoags who invited their guests to sit down at the communal table with them only to be served up as dinner later on by the colonists.

human: Samantha Harvey features two famous artworks in her poetic fifth novel, “Orbital.”

Collins is literally the only person in the world not in the image.

A number of factors are thought to have contributed to its underperformance: The holiday season is notoriously difficult for films opening against bigger releases like “Star Wars” or “Frozen.”

human: Adan Canto, the Mexican actor known for his roles on television series including “The Cleaning Lady” and “Designated Survivor,” as well as for playing the superhero Sunspot in the film “X-Men: Days of Future Past,” died on Monday.

human: For soup enthusiasts across America, the post-Thanksgiving turkey broth can be as sacred as the holiday meal itself.
In many households, even before the dishes and the leftovers are packed away, the turkey carcass and trimmings are nestled into a pot of water for their hourslong simmer.
Leftover turkey soup is a cozy way to keep Thanksgiving’s bountiful spirit going for several more meals.
llm: For soup enthusiasts, leftovers are always a blessing.
And the more you have to work with, the better!

For this recipe, use 3 pounds of leftover turkey (or any white meat), and 10 cups of chicken broth, 2 cloves garlic, 6 sprigs thyme, 1/4 cup chopped celery, 1 medium onion, 1/4 cup red wine vinegar or cider vinegar, 1 tablespoon Worcestershire sauce, salt and pepper to taste, 1/2 teaspoon each ground mustard and paprika, and 1 teaspoon each dried basil and parsley

llm: Gov. Doug Burgum is not running for re-election, but that doesn't mean he isn't running at all.

human: A pivotal new study suggests that the weight loss drug Wegovy cut the risk of heart attack, stroke or death from cardiovascular issues by 20 percent among overweight or obese people with heart disease — a striking benefit that could change the standard of care for these patients.

human: When people ask me what my favorite horror movie is, John Carpenter’s groundbreaking shocker comes out on top.
Jamie Lee Curtis plays a high schooler who gets stalked on Halloween night by an escaped lunatic named Michael Myers.
Today it sounds like any old horror movie.

But Carpenter was prophetic with narrative choices that horror now takes for granted: a masked killing-machine villain, a strong-willed final girl next door, creatively depicted deaths, touches of dark comedy.
(And a score that sounds like a chase.)
Together they make “Halloween” my top Halloween treat.
llm: When people ask me what I want for my birthday, I usually say, “A time machine.
Then you can go back in time and give it to me.”
If that doesn’t work, though, here are some of the best horror movies on Netflix right now, all available for streaming.

human: Artificial intelligence has been a breakout star in the opening days of COP28, the United Nations climate summit in Dubai, United Arab Emirates.

llm: Artificial intelligence has a lot of potential to help us tackle climate change.

human: The campaign website for Representative Dean Phillips, the Minnesota Democrat mounting a long-shot primary challenge to President Biden, has a policy platform that signals liberal bona fides tempered by a Midwestern businessman’s practicality.

human: In a packed opera house on Tuesday night in Derry, N.H., Hannah Kesselring had a pressing question for Nikki Haley, one that many voters in the room appear to have been considering as Ms. Haley has climbed in the 2024 Republican presidential contest.

human: In 1988, Oprah Winfrey tugged a red wagon filled with fat across the stage of her television show to represent the 67 pounds she said she had lost on a liquid diet.

llm: In 1988, Oprah Winfrey was weighing in at about 200 pounds.

human: The U.S. State Department has approved a $320 million sale to Israel of equipment for kits that turn unguided bombs into more precise, GPS-guided munitions, according to a letter sent by the department to Congress that was obtained by The New York Times.

human: Poetry makes nothing happen, W.H. Auden said in 1939, when words must have seemed especially impotent; but cinema is another matter.

For several decades after the end of the Second World War, what’s come to be seen as its central catastrophe — the near-total destruction of the European Jews — was consigned to the status of a footnote.
The neglect was rooted in guilt: Many nations eagerly collaborated in the killing, while others did nothing to prevent it.
Consumed by their own suffering, most people simply didn’t want to know, and a conspiracy of silence was established.
llm: Poetry makes nothing happen, and yet it can make everything possible.
The work of the poet is to see more clearly what we already have in our possession: language.
The poet is not a specialist, but a generalist who uses all his senses in order to observe life from different angles.

And while he does that, he is also a philosopher, a historian, an anthropologist, an ethnographer, a sociologist, a psychologist, a political scientist, a biologist, an archaeologist, a linguist—and perhaps most importantly, a writer.
In this way, the poet sees the world with different eyes than the rest of us.
Poets are the first to recognize the value of a common language.
