I think it's just too busy, and I'd prefer more simple lines, like the classic look of 1950s EC Comics or Will Eisner's The Spirit.

human: This house is in Potrero Hill, about a 10-minute walk from Zuckerberg San Francisco General Hospital and Trauma Center.

It is also within walking distance of a public library, public elementary and high schools, and Potrero Hill Recreation Center, which sits in a park with a baseball diamond, tennis courts and a playground.
llm: This house is listed for $5,099,000 and has 12 bedrooms and 8 baths.
Located in Los Altos Hills this home sits on a beautifully landscaped .78-acre lot with a swimming pool, spa, outdoor kitchen, barbeque area, and putting green.

human: A Canadian court found that Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s use of the country’s Emergencies Act to end a truck convoy protest that had paralyzed the capital, Ottawa, two years ago was an unjustified infringement of civil rights, including the protection against unreasonable search and seizure, and, in some instances, the freedom of expression as well.
llm: A Canadian court has ruled that Prime Minister Justin Trudeau overstepped his authority when he invoked the country’s emergencies act to end a pipeline protest camp.

human: There were an estimated 249 million cases of malaria around the globe last year, the World Health Organization said on Thursday, significantly more than before the Covid-19 pandemic and an increase of five million over 2021.
Malaria remains a top killer of children.
llm: There were an estimated 219 million cases of malaria in 2015, with more than half a million deaths, according to the World Health Organization.
The disease is transmitted by mosquito bites and primarily affects children under five years old and pregnant women.

human: The Kenyan force tasked with leading a mission to take back Haiti’s streets from violent gangs that have overtaken much of the country’s capital will be made up of police officers who have a checkered history of their own at home, accused of killing more than 100 people this year and lobbing tear-gas into a school during anti-government demonstrations.
llm: The Kenyan force has been widely criticized as one of the most violent and corrupt in Africa.
The 19,000-member force is made up largely of former militias with little training and poor discipline.
Their brutality has become legendary:

In 2008, the United Nations issued an order banning them from wearing balaclavas after a U.N. investigator said some members had used them to hide their identity when committing crimes against civilians.

human: Amid the 1970s television landscape selling obvious sex and youth, Norman Lear understood the magnetism of older everyday women.
llm: Amid the 1970s sitcom revolution, when a new generation of women writers and producers were bringing to life characters like Mary Richards (Mary Tyler Moore), Maude Findlay (Bea Arthur) and Murphy Brown (Candice Bergen), Norman Lear was creating his own trailblazing female ensemble.
The cast of “All in the Family” included Edith Bunker, played by Jean Stapleton, and Gloria Stivic, portrayed by Sally Struthers.
And then there was Flo, who, along with her husband Mel, was a regular on “Sanford and Son.”

human: The Supreme Court justices seemed divided on Monday over a fiercely contested bankruptcy settlement for Purdue Pharma that would funnel billions of dollars into addressing the opioid epidemic in exchange for shielding members of the wealthy Sackler family from related civil lawsuits.
llm: The Supreme Court seemed split on Monday over whether the government should be able to impose a massive settlement with opioid maker Purdue Pharma LP over its alleged role in contributing to the U.S. opioid crisis.

human: Israeli hostages held in the Gaza Strip “will not be returned alive” unless Israeli forces leave, a Hamas spokesman said on Wednesday, highlighting the predicament facing the Israeli government: It has vowed to free the hostages, and to pursue the war and defeat Hamas.
llm: Israeli hostages held by Hamas were on Thursday in the 4th day of their captivity.
Their fate is unknown and it seems that they are being used as a bargaining chip for the release of terrorists.

We have to remember that Hamas was responsible for the deaths of three Israeli teenagers, Gilad Shalit (who was kidnapped while hitchhiking) and Eldad Regev and Udi Goldwasser who were abducted during an IDF raid into Gaza which was followed by a massive barrage of rockets fired at Israel.
The latter incident led to the IDF Operation Cast Lead against Hamas.
The three soldiers who were killed in the initial attack were Nissim Salem, St.-Sgt.

human: No sooner did Mayor Eric Adams of New York land in Washington, D.C., on city business Thursday than he had to turn right back around to take care of his own.
llm: No sooner did the first scandal involving his mayoral campaign erupt than another one surfaced.
This time, it involves a developer who was given favors by city government in exchange for political contributions to the mayor's campaign.
Mr. Adams had the audacity to say that this sort of thing didn't happen under his watch.
That is not only untrue but also an insult to anyone with common sense.
In fact, it seems as if he is trying to make light of what happened and blame the former administration for his current problems.
It's time for him to step up and take responsibility for his actions.
And we must be vigilant so that our tax dollars are spent wisely and honestly.

human: Ms. Haley, the former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, said that there would be no Hamas without Iran.
llm: Ms. Haley, the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, also said that Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas is “on the wrong side of history” and urged him to help bring about a peace agreement with Israel or “get out of the way.”

human: Hollywood horror often attempts to work out collective anxiety about the suburbs, that place full of pleasant-looking houses creaking with ghosts and terrors.
Suburban life is, admittedly, fundamentally strange, with neighborhoods full of atomized worlds and natural features turned into individual, highly-controlled assets.
A forest becomes manicured bushes.
A lake becomes a pool.
llm: Hollywood horror often focuses on the most uncomfortable of situations.
But rarely is it as intimate and emotionally honest as “Night Swim,” a psychological thriller written and directed by David Rueb.

This chilling tale takes place entirely in the confines of one house where two teenage brothers are forced to confront their relationship with each other — and themselves — when they are suddenly faced with an unknown force.
The result is a movie that may be more terrifying than any slasher flick.

human: Donald J. Trump has decided not to return to the witness stand to testify on Monday as he had planned, setting up an abrupt and anticlimactic ending to the defense’s case in his civil fraud trial in Manhattan.
llm: Donald J. Trump will not testify next week at a civil trial over allegations that he defrauded thousands of customers of his namesake real estate seminar by falsely claiming to be an expert on investing and the stock market, his lawyer said Thursday.

human: Zvi Zamir, who as the director of Israel’s Mossad spy agency led a violent campaign to crush Palestinian terrorism after 11 Israelis were killed at the 1972 Munich Summer Olympics — and who a year later relayed a warning to his government that Egypt and Syria were about to start the Yom Kippur War but was not taken seriously — died on Jan. 2.
He was 98.
llm: Zvi Zamir, who as the head of Israel’s Mossad spy agency was at the center of some of the most pivotal events of his country’s history and whose secret operations included assassinating a Nazi war criminal and helping to rescue Ethiopian Jews during an airlift, died on Sunday in Tel Aviv.
He was 98.

human: Strong winds damaged resorts along the coast of Acapulco, Mexico, near where Otis made landfall.
llm: Strong winds damaged some homes and a church in the southern Pacific resort city of Manzanillo on Sunday, but authorities said they were relieved that Hurricane Otis had not caused more destruction than it did.

human: Claire M. Fagin, a leading expert on, advocate for and change agent in the profession of nursing, and one of the first women to lead an Ivy League university, the University of Pennsylvania, died on Tuesday at her home in Manhattan.
She was 97.
llm: Claire M. Fagin, who led the American Association of Colleges of Nursing from 1965 to 1983 and was one of the first women elected president of the American Medical Association in 1980, died on Monday in Washington Heights, where she lived.
She was 97.

human: The rock band Rage Against the Machine is done touring and playing live shows, its drummer said in a social media post on Wednesday.
llm: The rock band Rage Against the Machine has been releasing statements against the Iraq War since 2003.
But the band's frontman, Zack de la Rocha, has never stopped touring.
In a new interview with Billboard magazine, he explains why: The United States government doesn’t want him to stop.

human: Nio, a Chinese electric car company that competes with Tesla, employs 11,000 people in research and development, but sold a mere 8,000 cars per month from April through June.
llm: Nio, a Chinese electric-car maker that went public in the United States last year, is losing more than $18,000 on each vehicle it makes, according to people familiar with its finances who were not authorized to speak about them publicly.
The company’s losses are larger than those of any other major automaker, and they are driving up its stock price even as investors question whether Nio can survive long enough to make money.

human: More than a year and a half after Amazon workers on Staten Island voted to form the company’s first union in the United States, the company appears to be taking a harder line toward labor organizing, disciplining workers and even firing one who had been heavily involved in the union campaign.
llm: More than a year after Amazon workers launched a public campaign to unionize the company’s warehouses and distribution centers, the online retailer has taken steps that some workers say are intended to stifle their organizing efforts.

human: With its wooded hills, winding roads and shimmering lakes and reservoirs, Ringwood, N.J., feels more like the Catskills than like a New Jersey suburb.
That rural charm was what attracted Linda and James Pentifallo when they decided to leave their longtime home in River Edge, in Bergen County.
llm: With its wooded hills and valleys, quiet country roads, open space and active recreational facilities, Ringwood is an ideal community for those who enjoy the outdoors or simply want to get away from it all.
The area offers the best of both worlds: a rural lifestyle with easy access to major metropolitan areas like New York City (40 miles), Philadelphia (50 miles) and Washington DC (100 miles).

In addition, Ringwood residents are within commuting distance of major corporations in New Jersey such as Pfizer Pharmaceuticals in Groton, Johnson & Johnson's World Headquarters in New Brunswick, and Merck Pharmaceuticals in West Point.
There are also several smaller employers that provide

human: Patrick Page and Paige Davis met in the mid 1990s, during New York rehearsals for the first national tour of the musical “Beauty and the Beast.”

But with Mr. Page working on his scenes in one studio (he played Lumière), and Ms. Davis, an ensemble member, singing and dancing in another, they didn’t really get acquainted until performances began in Minneapolis.
llm: Patrick Page and his husband, Danny, had no idea what they were in for when the designer Nate Berkus walked into their Los Angeles home.

human: Q: We live on the first and second floors of a brownstone in East Harlem, and we love the backyard.
Two buildings over, a neighbor in the second-floor apartment has put a litter box on the fire escape outside their window for community cats to shelter.
The neighbor also puts out food for them.
In the morning, there are usually half a dozen adult cats lingering around the box and the stairs.
Inevitably, they end up roaming in our backyard, peeing, pooping and fighting.
The odor in the summer is terrible.
We’ve had two female cats give birth in our backyard this year alone.
The kittens are cute, their cries not so much.
What can we do?
llm: Q: We live in a nice neighborhood, but I’m sick of the stench from our neighbors.
They have two cats that are constantly pooping all over their yard.
It smells so bad, it even comes into my house!
How do I get them to stop?
— A.C., via email

human: Conservatives thrust the House back into chaos on Wednesday, grinding business to a halt in protest of the spending deal Speaker Mike Johnson struck with Democrats to avert a government shutdown and leaving the funding package in limbo.
llm: Conservatives thrust the government toward a shutdown on Friday, blocking passage of a $14 billion bill to keep it open until September 30.

The conservative rebellion, which followed a series of Republican defections in recent days, was fueled by opposition from House Tea Party members to an agreement struck this week between Senator Harry Reid and Mitch McConnell that would lift the debt ceiling through mid-May.
That measure also included funding for federal agencies through next month.

human: Long before he was switch-hitting for the New York Yankees, a young Mickey Mantle was taking swings against his right-handed father and his left-handed grandfather in front of a shed next to his family’s humble 670-square-foot house in tiny Commerce, Okla.
More often than not, the young slugger would knock the pitches clear over the house’s roof.
Sometimes he’d smack line drives into the side of the rusted shed, where visible dings in the walls remain to this day.
llm: Long before he was the Mick, Mickey Mantle lived in a three-bedroom house on 218th Street in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn with his parents and eight siblings.
He played football and basketball at James Madison High School, which is where he met Roger Maris, who also lived in Bensonhurst.
They became best friends; Maris later said that Mantle was “the most important person” in his life.

human: In charting the flight of the battery-powered CX300 aircraft recently, The New York Times was back where it has spent a lot of time over the last 120 years: in the clouds.
llm: In charting the course of aviation history, John W. R. Taylor makes a bold statement about the way we perceive the past and its relationship to our present and future: "Aviation is more than the news."

human: Governor Sarah Huckabee Sanders of Arkansas is facing some of the sharpest scrutiny of her early tenure after a public records request revealed that her office bought a lectern for $19,000 — and a whistle-blower accused the office of altering records to cover up the spending.
llm: Governor Sarah Huckabee Sanders used her office’s credit card to buy a lectern worth more than $19,000 from an online auction house in February, but she did not disclose the purchase when asked about it during a state legislative session.

human: Have you ever spent quality time with a chicken?
I raised them as a teenager, and I do not particularly recommend it.
They can be smelly and dirty.
They’re honestly not very bright.
Yet they’re like living cartoons, weird and funny to watch, with spindly little legs holding up plump little bodies.
They cluck disapprovingly when you take their eggs, and they’ll eat anything you dump in their yard (including, uh, chicken).
llm: Have you ever seen a chicken nugget?
I have.
It is nothing to be proud of.

human: In frantic talks, and with an Israeli ground invasion looming, officials from the U.S. and Middle Eastern countries, including Egypt, sought to ease what Israeli officials have called the “siege” of Gaza.
After days of acute water shortages, Israel has agreed to restore water to a pipeline that served a southern part of the enclave, a top U.S. official said.
Read the latest from the crisis.
llm: In frantic talks, EU tries to save Iran deal from Trump's axe

human: Violence in the West Bank, where millions of Palestinians live under Israeli military occupation, continues to simmer amid the war in Gaza.
At least 128 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli security forces or civilians in the West Bank since Oct. 7, according to the United Nations.
llm: Violence in the Middle East has been ongoing since September 2015 when Israel launched its Operation Protective Edge campaign.
The conflict was sparked by the kidnapping and murder of three Israeli teenagers in the West Bank, which Israel blamed on Hamas; however, Hamas denied any involvement.
In response to the kidnappings, Israel arrested over 600 Palestinians, many of whom were accused of being affiliated with Hamas but none were charged or convicted of the crime.

human: After years of rising overdoses and an exodus of business from central Portland, Gov. Tina Kotek of Oregon said on Monday that state and city officials are proposing to roll back a portion of the nation’s most wide-ranging drug decriminalization law in a bid to revive the troubled city.
llm: After years of rising homelessness and drug use in the city’s downtown core, officials have decided on a bold approach: ban public consumption.
The proposed law would impose fines or even jail time for those caught using drugs or alcohol outdoors — a move that would be unprecedented in Oregon.
But some critics say it is an overreach that could push more people into the streets.

human: Nikki Haley, the former South Carolina governor seeking the Republican Party’s presidential nomination, appears to have weathered a holiday-season gaffe on the causes of the Civil War, but the controversy over her answer, which neglected to mention slavery, was a gift to a rival, former Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey.
llm: Nikki Haley, the former South Carolina governor who was elected to be U.S. ambassador to the United Nations by President Donald Trump last year, is in New Hampshire this weekend for her first swing through the state since announcing her 2024 presidential candidacy.

But some Granite State Republicans are questioning whether she should be so openly campaigning as a candidate while still serving as the nation's top diplomat — particularly on the heels of her controversial remarks about slavery at a Civil War event in Washington earlier this month.

human: A college student with a heart condition died after she drank a heavily caffeinated drink from Panera Bread, likely thinking it had a safe amount of caffeine, her parents said in a lawsuit filed on Monday.
llm: A college student has filed a lawsuit against Panera, claiming the company's Charged Lemonade was linked to her death.

human: The American ambassador to NATO said on Tuesday that U.S. military assistance to Israel after the weekend attacks by Hamas assailants would not come at Ukraine’s expense.
llm: The American ambassador to NATO, Douglas Lute, said Wednesday that the United States would not cut aid to its ally Israel in order to provide military assistance to Kiev, the Ukrainian capital, which is fighting Russian-backed separatists in eastern Ukraine.

human: Early in the pandemic, as in-person art fairs ground to halt, many art professionals proclaimed the financial, health and climate costs of shipping art and people around the planet were simply no longer sustainable.
But predictions of a major reset have proved premature.
llm: Early in the twentieth century, the first art fairs were held, and since then they have grown into a global phenomenon.
The New York Times recently ran an article about how art fairs are evolving and what we can expect from them over the next decade.
While the article mainly focuses on the international market, there is also mention of how art fairs have changed here at home as well.

human: Ten finance guys are drinking in a bar.
Nine of them are Masters of the Universe — wheeler-dealers who make many millions of dollars every year.
The tenth is what Gordon Gekko, in the movie “Wall Street,” called a “$400,000-a-year working Wall Street stiff.”
llm: Ten finance guys are sitting at a bar.
The bartender asks, “What’ll it be?”
One of them says, “A round for everyone.”
And then he leans over to his buddy and whispers, “See that guy over there?
He looks just like Joe Biden!”
So they all have a good laugh.
Then another one says, “I think he looks more like Dick Cheney.”
And they all have a good laugh again.

human: A Boeing 757 plane operated by Delta Air Lines lost a nose wheel as it prepared to take off from Atlanta’s main airport on Saturday, according to the Federal Aviation Administration.
It was the latest troubling episode involving one of the manufacturer’s aircraft.
llm: A Boeing 757 belonging to Delta Airlines had an incident at New York's LaGuardia Airport on July 29th in which the aircraft lost one of its nose wheels while taxiing for take-off, according to a report by The Wall Street Journal.
The incident was caused when a piece of metal debris broke off from a vehicle that was driving alongside the aircraft.

human: As a presidential candidate, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has said he would authorize the use of deadly force against people crossing the border, seek to end the practice of birthright citizenship and send the military to strike against drug cartels inside Mexico, a key ally of the United States, even without the permission of its government.
llm: As a presidential candidate, Donald Trump had promised to build the wall, deport millions of undocumented immigrants, and make Mexico pay for it.
As President, he has made little progress on that promise.
So, he's been looking for ways to take action unilaterally—and Florida Governor Ron DeSantis is helping him out.

human: A Black high school student in Texas who had been suspended because of how he wears his hair was removed from his school on Wednesday and transferred to a disciplinary school program, according to a letter from the school district shared by the student’s family.
llm: A Black high school student in North Carolina was suspended for refusing to cut his dreadlocks.
He was then sent to a disciplinary school.

human: I write these lines from Jerusalem, after spending time with the families of some of the 240 people kidnapped by Hamas terrorists on Oct. 7.
The hostages now held in Gaza include Jewish Israelis, Muslim Israelis and foreign citizens of different ethnicities.
llm: I write these words from the comfort of my living room in Jerusalem, surrounded by books and children.
But there is an eerie silence in the city.
The sound of sirens has ceased.
We are used to hearing them on a regular basis.
Everyone has a plan for what they would do if there was a siren.
My husband and I have ours ready as well.

human: Can you find Kyrgyzstan on a map?
What else do you know about this Central Asian nation with about 6.7 million people?
llm: Can you find the capital of Kyrgyzstan on a map?
What is its official name?
Can you identify these famous people who are from Kyrgyzstan?
Take our quiz to see how much you know about this Central Asian country!

human: Amid growing despair and rage, Arab countries including Saudi Arabia, Jordan and Egypt are intensifying their appeals to the U.S. to pressure Israel for an immediate cease-fire in Gaza.
Failure to do so, they say, risks sabotaging the security of the entire Middle East.
llm: Amid growing despair and anger, the number of asylum seekers arriving in Canada has increased dramatically over the past year.
In November 2017 alone, more than 6,800 migrants crossed illegally from the U.S. into Canada.
Many of them are fleeing the Trump administration’s policies on immigration.
Others have been deported from the United States because they lack legal status there.
This episode takes a look at the recent surge in migration to Canada and asks: What is driving people to make this dangerous journey north?
And what does it mean for the country that welcomes them?
We hear from Canadian officials who help assess newcomers’ claims to refugee status.
We also speak with a migrant

human: The moon stands alone.
It is unique in the known cosmos: a solitary rock one-fourth the width of its host planet, the only place life has ever been found.
And the moon is alone: It is a desolate, sunbaked and crater-pocked wasteland that harbors little except what we bring to it, either with our minds or with our spaceships.
But that is about to change.
llm: The moon stands out in the night sky for obvious reasons.
It's bright, it shines, and it's a giant, glowing ball of rock and metal that seems so close, you can almost touch it.
And we have been doing just that since 1969, when Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin became the first humans to set foot on its surface.
Since then, humanity has sent more than 500 spacecraft to the moon—with more on their way.
But what do we know about this neighbor that helps keep our planet spinning?
How did the moon form?
What is its composition like?
Why does it appear different colors from Earth?
And why are we still going there today?
In this talk, astrophysicist Emily

human: Eight years ago, just before the Iowa caucuses, Donald J. Trump crowed about his invulnerability.
llm: Eight years ago, when he was a presidential candidate and later as a senator, Mitt Romney repeatedly said that if President Obama were to order an assassination of an American citizen in the United States, it would be illegal.
He went so far as to call such an action “an abuse of power” that would make the president “akin to a dictator.”

And yet now, just one week after being sworn in as president, Donald Trump has ordered his new CIA director Mike Pompeo to create a process to legally justify assassinating Americans within the U.S. who are suspected of terrorist activity.

human: The first of the two shootings in Lewiston, Maine, took place at a bowling alley, interrupting an American pastime on an ordinary Wednesday evening.
llm: The first of two articles about the 2014 New England Patriots scandal.
This one was published in the Boston Globe on November 3, 2017 and is titled:
Tragedy interrupted an American pastime at a Maine bowling alley.
The article details how the death of Aaron Hernandez's friend, Odin Lloyd, impacted his life leading up to his suicide.

human: An Israeli airstrike hit near the entrance of Al Shifa Hospital in Gaza City on Friday, killing multiple people, according to Gazan and Israeli officials, just as Palestinians said a convoy of ambulances was preparing to leave the hospital carrying wounded people to the Gaza border, to cross into Egypt for treatment.
llm: An Israeli airstrike on Wednesday hit a crowded area of central Gaza City that included a children's hospital and a police station, killing dozens of people.
Palestinian witnesses said that 37 people were killed, including civilians, police officers and Hamas militants.
More than 100 others were injured.
The Israeli military said that the attack had targeted rocket launchers and other weapons caches belonging to Hamas.

human: Follow live updates on the 2023 ring of fire solar eclipse.
llm: Follow live updates from the path of totality during Monday's eclipse.

human: Following several productive days at the negotiating table, Hollywood studios are growing optimistic that they are getting closer to a deal to end the 108-day actors’ strike, according to three people briefed on the matter.
llm: Following several productive meetings between the studios and striking writers, WGA president Patric Verrone said that he was optimistic about a resolution.

human: When she arrived in Congress last year, Representative Anna Paulina Luna, a hard-right Republican from Florida, joined the rest of her party in staunchly opposing proxy voting, a practice adopted by House Democrats to allow for remote legislating during the pandemic.
llm: When she arrived at the polling place in her first election after giving birth, GOP candidate Sarah Chamberlain found it was closed.
She'd never seen a ballot before and had no idea what to do next.

human: Even though Claudine Gay’s resignation as president of Harvard was tied to plagiarism allegations, debate on a broader culture war’s role in the move is grabbing lots of attention.
llm: Even though Claudine Bouchard, a partner at Korn/Ferry International and co-founder of Women Get On Board, is not in charge of hiring at her firm, she says there are ways to show your value.
“You have to be able to articulate how you can contribute, what you bring to the table,” she explains.
She advises women who want to advance their careers to “get comfortable with speaking up, even if it’s not comfortable.”

human: More than a week after Tesla mechanics in Sweden began a strike to compel the U.S. automaker to accept a collective labor agreement, union officials said Tesla representatives would meet with the union on Monday.
llm: More than a year after the first wave of job cuts, a new round of layoffs is under way at Tesla's factory in Trollhättan, Sweden.
The U.S. electric carmaker has said it will cut 20 percent of its workforce by March and will eliminate around 400 jobs this month alone.
But not everyone is taking the news with equanimity.

human: A prominent Iranian human rights lawyer, Nasrin Sotoudeh, was arrested and severely beaten, her husband said on Monday — one of several activists taken into custody at the funeral in Tehran of a girl who was fatally injured after a reported confrontation with the enforcers of Iran’s strict dress code for women.
llm: A prominent Iranian human rights lawyer was reportedly jailed in Tehran on Tuesday, after authorities raided his office in protest against a recent U.S. Senate resolution urging the Islamic Republic to release him and other political prisoners.

human: “Renaissance: A Film by Beyoncé” is out today.
It’s a nearly three-hour documentary of the pop icon’s record-breaking summer tour and provides audiences with both a front-row seat and behind-the-scenes look at the show.
J Wortham and Salamishah Tillet discuss what the film means for the artist at the height of her powers.
llm: “Renaissance: A Film by Beyoncé” is an artistic film, which chronicles the singer’s recent global album release.
The film features Beyoncé performing her new song, “I Was Here,” in front of a live audience.
She also takes fans on a journey through the creative process behind her latest record, with exclusive interviews and behind-the-scenes footage from the studio and on tour.
In addition to the new music video, fans can watch “Renaissance” on TIDAL.com/Beyonce.

human: The Michigan Senate gave final approval on Wednesday to a bundle of clean energy bills, transforming a state at the center of industrial America into a leader in the fight against climate change.
llm: The Michigan Senate passed legislation today that will establish renewable energy standards for electricity generators in the state, provide $10 million per year for energy efficiency projects and require utilities to get 10 percent of their power from solar by 2015.

human: The election results on Tuesday made it clear that voters support Democratic policies and state politicians — but new polling shows they don’t love the president.
llm: The election results, however, may be more complicated than that.
Democrats won in states that were not the most populous, where Republicans had a better chance of winning.
In those states, there are fewer Democrats overall and thus less room for error.
In the swing states, where the Democrats could have lost, they actually increased their number of seats.
That means that their vote was more solid.

human: A three-bedroom, two-bath, roughly 1,700-square-foot co-op apartment with an open floor plan, a windowed kitchen, an en suite primary bedroom with a walk-in closet, a den or home office with a built-in desk, through-the-wall heating and air-conditioning, a washer/dryer and two basement storage lockers, on the third floor of a 17-story prewar Emery Roth building with a live-in super, a resident manager, a bike room, shared laundry and a shared garden.
Diana Devendorf Rice, 516-458-9389, Sotheby’s International Realty-East Side Manhattan Brokerage; sothebysrealty.com
llm: A three-bedroom, two-bath, 2,000 square foot townhouse located at 190 West 74th Street, #2, between Amsterdam Avenue and Columbus Avenue in the Upper West Side neighborhood of Manhattan.
The unit is being sold at $6,500,000.
It was first listed on May 3rd for $7,200,000.
The townhouse has four exposures.
There is a living room with fireplace, dining area, kitchen with breakfast nook, master suite, second bedroom, full bath, and terrace.
The third bedroom can be used as an office or playroom.
Other features include central air conditioning, washer/dryer, and two garage parking spaces.

human: The Bergdorf blonde is now taking meetings at the Regency Hotel.
llm: The Bergdorf blonde moves to Park Avenue, 1965.

human: Speaker Mike Johnson’s proposal to avert a government shutdown at the end of the week ran into increasing opposition on Monday from hard-line Republicans.
But with Democratic opposition softening, it appeared the plan could be headed toward bipartisan approval within days.
llm: Speaker Mike Johnson’s office is not commenting on the plan, but a source close to him said he has no intention of voting for it.

human: The F.D.A. announced today that it would allow Florida to import millions of dollars’ worth of prescription medications from Canada, where they are available at far lower prices than in the U.S.
llm: The F.D.A. announced Thursday that it had approved a company’s request to import an unnamed generic drug from Canada, the first such approval since Congress passed a law in 2003 allowing for the practice.
The decision was made after a review by the agency found “no evidence” that the imported product would not be safe and effective, according to a statement on the agency’s website.

The approval is limited to one supplier — the company’s name was not released — but the move could have broad implications for Americans who do not have health insurance or whose co-payments are too high to afford medications.

human: Three of the country’s major automakers are facing an expanding strike that started on Sept. 15.
Hollywood producers and screenwriters reached a contract agreement late last month to end a 148-day walkout, but striking actors are still locked in negotiations.
llm: Three of the four components of GDP rose at a slower pace, with consumer spending increasing 2.4 percent instead of 3.6 percent.
Business investment grew only 1.1 percent instead of 1.5 percent, and government spending increased 0.8 percent instead of 1.2 percent.

human: A change taking place right now has the potential to do more good within U.S. prisons than any policy in a generation — good that will extend far beyond the realm of criminal justice.
With a 2020 law finally taking full effect, people who are incarcerated can for the first time in decades get Pell Grants, the federal tuition aid for low-income students.
The grants are small, but they are critical to rebuilding one of the most important tools we have to reduce crime and mitigate the harms of mass incarceration: college education.
llm: A change taking place inside the U.S. prison system is being overlooked by both the media and politicians, says a former corrections official who has been inside prisons for decades.

human: The agony came in waves as the wounded Ukrainian soldier in the back of the ambulance slipped in and out of consciousness.
The driver, hurtling past cratered fields on roads thick with mud, was racing to escape Russian artillery fire north of the city of Avdiivka, while hoping he was not spotted by drones.
llm: The agony came swiftly.
It started with a rocket.
Then another and another.
Within seconds the 27-year-old volunteer from Kiev was dead, his body mangled in an explosion of blood and shrapnel on a road near Mariupol, the city under siege.

human: As dinner tables and snack menus feature far more chicken and cheese, farms are expanding where water is scarce.
llm: As dinner tables across the country become more and more crowded with pizza boxes, fast food bags, and takeout containers, Americans are increasingly relying on plastic packaging to store their food.
Unfortunately, that plastic is often made from fossil fuels, which means it has a large environmental footprint.

human: In a subterranean compound deep below Khan Younis, a Hamas stronghold in the southern Gaza Strip, the five cells with barred doors that the Israeli military says held hostages abducted from Israel had clearly been constructed long in advance.
llm: In a subterranean labyrinth of tunnels deep under the southern Gaza Strip, Israel has found evidence that Hamas is using the passageways to store weapons, train fighters and even hold hostages.
But Israel's military chiefs say they are still not sure if the tunnels are being used as escape routes for soldiers, or to abduct them.

human: Five hundred passengers were evacuated on Friday morning after a train collision near the Indonesian city of Bandung killed four crew members and injured 37 people, officials said.
llm: Five hundred passengers were injured and more than 100 others were killed.

human: When Iowa voters brave frigid weather to caucus on Monday, they will be participating in one of the coldest caucuses in decades — perhaps ever.
llm: When Iowa voters gather at their caucus locations on Monday night, they'll likely be greeted by temperatures well below freezing.

human: Their pink bodies began to wash ashore last month, startling locals and scientists in the remote Amazon town of Tefé, Brazil, who had never seen anything like it.
A crippling drought had sucked parts of tributaries flowing into the Amazon River nearly dry, causing some water routes to become impassible and turning other shallow areas into a hot bath.
llm: Their pink bodies had started to bloat, and their bellies were bloated with water.
They’d stopped eating, so they were starving, too.

human: The Senate on Tuesday took the first step in advancing a stopgap spending bill to avoid a partial government shutdown at the end of the week, buying time to enact a broader bipartisan funding agreement for the remainder of the year.
llm: The Senate on Thursday voted 81-18 to advance a stopgap spending bill that would fund the government through Feb. 8 and delay the implementation of Obamacare until at least 2015.
The bill, which now goes back to the House for approval, also includes a provision to keep paying interest on student loans.

human: Guy Stern, who fled rising antisemitism in Nazi Germany at 15 for a new life in the United States but returned to Europe during World War II as a member of a military intelligence program that trained him to interrogate prisoners of war, died on Dec. 7 in West Bloomfield, Mich.
He was 101.
llm: Guy Stern, who fled the Nazi regime as a teenager and later became an interrogator for the U.S. Army in Europe after World War II, died on Friday in Manhattan.
He was 101.

human: A former spokesman for Israel’s military gave a blunt assessment of the situation in Israel on Sunday, warning that it would take hours or longer to reclaim all the towns in southern Israel where the military was still battling Hamas militants.
llm: A former spokesman for Israel's army says that in any ground operation into Lebanon, Israel will likely suffer heavy losses.

human: The grandfather always feared this day would come.
llm: The grandfather always told him to be careful when he crossed the border.
If he were caught by Pakistani authorities, they would beat him and send him back to Afghanistan.
That was what happened to his father, who had tried twice before making it all the way across the border to Pakistan in search of work as a laborer or day-laborer.
The young man, now 23 years old, made sure to keep the border within sight at all times.
He did not want to end up like his father, who disappeared after being sent back to Afghanistan.
His mother never knew what became of him.

human: Colette Pierce Burnette, who was hired to lead the Newfields campus that includes the Indianapolis Museum of Art after a controversy about a racially insensitive job posting, has left the organization after 15 months on the job and shortly after the arrival of a new museum director.
llm: Colette Pierce Burnette, President and CEO of the Indianapolis Museum of Art.
(Photo by Gavin Evans for The New York Times.)

human: Aries, an Anatolian shepherd, warily watches a stranger approach a pen where he and other members of his family — including eight fuzzy, 2-month-old puppies — roam alongside a grunting pig and several bleating goats.
llm: Aries, an Anatolian shepherd mix who was born in 1995, has been living with the couple since they got her from a shelter in 2004.
She’s a calm dog who loves to play fetch and sniff around town.

human: I was irritated as I drove west from Nashville.
The sun was in my eyes, and I was holding the steering wheel too tight because the car kept getting buffeted by the winds of trucks passing at an astonishingly illegal speed.
At least I’m not heading east, I kept reminding myself, stuck behind one big rig trying to pass another on a steep mountain incline.
On the flat lands of West Tennessee, even eighteen-wheelers can pass going 90 miles an hour.
llm: I was irritated that my mother didn't even want to talk about the house.
I had been thinking of it as a place where we could go and hide from our lives, but she wanted to sell it right away and get back to her own life in New York.

human: Are you a fan of comic books and superhero movies?
Have you seen every film in the Marvel Cinematic Universe?
Do you eagerly mark your calendar when the latest release date is announced?
Or are you growing a little tired of the genre?
llm: Are you a Marvel fan?
Are you looking forward to the next Avengers movie?
What are your thoughts on the whole superhero genre in general?
Let us know below.

human: For four nights before the concert, the old master had trouble sleeping.
In his dreams, he was haunted by defeat after defeat — a failed exam, a knockout in the boxing ring.
During the day, an upset stomach reduced his diet to gentle soup.
llm: For four nights in 1937, John Gielgud took his one-man show about Oscar Wilde around the country.
The result was a tour de force of performance and an early example of the theatrical form we now know as monologue.

human: I started making this short documentary as a response to my mom developing dementia in her early 60s and forgetting how to read a knitting pattern.
After years of having her knit for me, I taught myself how to knit by watching YouTube tutorials.
As I learned more, and my mom’s health declined, I began to understand the solace that knitting brings.
llm: I started making my own sweaters, cardigans and hats in 2013.
My favorite part about knitting is the feeling of accomplishment I get when a project is complete!
I feel like it's a meditative process that allows me to connect with my creative side while also being able to create something unique for myself or someone else.

human: When Prime Minister Rishi Sunak said this week that he was not likely to call a general election in Britain before the second half of the year, he was trying to douse fevered speculation that he might go to the voters as early as May.
But in doing so, he set up another tantalizing prospect: that Britain and the United States could hold elections within days or weeks of each other this fall.
llm: When Prime Minister John Major announced on Monday that he would call a general election to be held on May 1, he also set in motion the prospect of an unusual political overlapping of elections here and abroad.

human: Global oil prices jumped yesterday after the energy giant BP said it had stopped sending tankers through the Red Sea.
The route has become increasingly dangerous since the Houthi armed group began attacking ships with drones and missiles.
llm: Global oil prices fell to the lowest in a year on Monday as concerns about a global glut outweighed hopes that output cuts by OPEC and its allies would reduce supply.
U.S. crude futures settled at $51.89 per barrel, down 47 cents from their last settlement, while Brent crude futures were down 62 cents at $59.30 a barrel.
The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed last week to slash production by 1.2 million barrels per day (bpd) for six months starting from January.
The group's biggest producer, Saudi Arabia, will account for most of the cuts with a reduction of more than

human: It’s good to be back!
Last week, I took a little staycation and spent most of my time reading, dog-sitting a very good boy, and seeing a bunch of movies at the New York Film Festival.*
But now I’m recharged, caught up on all the new music I missed — and, of course, ready to share it with you.
llm: It’s good to be able to tell your friends that you know about the latest music before they do.
But even better is when you can actually listen to the songs, and it turns out that you were right.
The best way to do this?
Read music blogs!
Here are nine new songs we think you should check out:

human: “Lovers in Auschwitz” is, as the title portends, a nonfiction account of two Jews who became lovers in Auschwitz.

The journalist Keren Blankfeld adapted it from her viral 2019 New York Times article and structured the book as a kind of braided biography; alternating chapters tell the story of David, a boy from Poland who dreams of becoming a singer, and of Zippi, a confident, talented girl from Slovakia.
llm: “Lovers in Auschwitz” by Shimon Adaf, translated from Hebrew by Steven Cohen.

human: Israel has agreed to put in place regular daily four-hour pauses in its relentless assault on Hamas in northern Gaza to allow civilians to flee, according to the White House.
llm: Israel has agreed to a 12-hour cease-fire in Gaza that is expected to go into effect at noon Sunday local time (7:00 p.m. ET Saturday), an administration official told CNN.

human: It’s Monday.
A trail near you may soon be named for Dianne Feinstein.
Plus, a state agency withdrew allegations against the video game maker Activision Blizzard in a $54 million settlement.
llm: It’s Monday.
A new week, a fresh start!
I hope you had a good one this past weekend.

human: I am a national correspondent on religion, faith and values.
Here are five things I'm enjoying right now.
llm: I am a big fan of the series.
I have seen all 7 episodes to date and will watch them again on my own time when they are available for purchase online or via Netflix.
The series is so moving because it shows us what life is like now, then and 56 years later.
It is a testament to humanity that we can be so cruel and yet so loving.

human: A video of a Hamas gunman firing his assault rifle at a car full of Israeli civilians was viewed more than one million times on X, the platform formerly known as Twitter, since it was uploaded Sunday.
llm: A video of an Israeli Arab singer singing about the murder of Jews in a Jerusalem synagogue has sparked violent responses, including a knife attack at the site where it was posted.

The 23-year-old singer from Abu Ghosh, located near Jerusalem, wrote a song called “Our Blood” following the November 18 terrorist attack that killed four rabbis and one police officer inside the Kehilat Bnei Torah synagogue.
The lyrics say, “They came with their blood-stained hands /
They stabbed our people to death /
Our hearts are crying out.”

human: Daphne Caruana Galizia was both famous and infamous in Malta, an in-your-face journalist who wrote that “the greatest enemy of freedom of expression” is fear, for it leads to “the dangerous situation where individuals are gagged.”
Being gagged was the last thing Caruana Galizia could tolerate.
Ultimately, fearlessness got her killed.
llm: Daphne Caruana Galizia (1964-2017) was a journalist who wrote about corruption in Malta and other countries.
On October 16, she was killed by a car bomb.

human: The holiday season is around the corner, and there are so many beloved rituals and traditions to look forward to.
llm: The holiday season is a time for giving and receiving, but it can also be a minefield of family drama.
This week on the show, we talk about how to navigate that tricky terrain with your loved ones.
From politics to religion, from childhood memories to in-laws, our hosts offer tips and tricks for keeping things civil over the Thanksgiving table (and beyond).

human: The facade of the apartment building was blown off, the remains sagging to one side.

Working together, the military police, the emergency services, the fire department and the explosives team cordoned off the scene, swept for other explosives, disarmed one, and searched for those still alive in the rubble with sniffer dogs, while removing the wounded and the dead.
llm: The facade of the building on Arbat Street in Moscow where former Russian spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia were found unconscious in March.
The Kremlin has accused Britain of “hysteria” over Russia’s involvement in the poisoning of Mr. Skripal.
Credit...
Ivan Sekretarev/Associated Press

human: San Franciscans don’t like outsiders bashing their city, but they’re also cleareyed about its biggest problems: homelessness, rampant drug use and leaders who can’t seem to fix those issues.
llm: San Franciscans don’t have to look far to see the city’s branding efforts, which are plastered all over MUNI buses and billboards across town.
But the ads don’t seem to be working anymore — if they ever did.
The latest numbers from the San Francisco Travel Association suggest that the tourism industry has been steadily declining since 2015.
Meanwhile, a new survey by Yelp reveals a troubling disconnect between what locals think about their hometown and how outsiders see it.

human: Priorities USA, one of the biggest liberal super PACs, will not run a single television advertisement in the 2024 election cycle.
llm: Priorities USA, one of the largest pro-Obama super PACs, will stop running television ads and instead focus on digital media such as social networking sites.
The group is shifting its spending from $30 million in TV to about $15 million on Facebook, Google search and YouTube.

human: A near-total communications blackout across the Gaza Strip extended for a seventh consecutive day on Thursday, leaving besieged civilians unable to call for help and aid workers struggling to reach them, as Israeli airstrikes continue to rain down on the south.
llm: A near-total communications blackout has left thousands of Palestinians with no access to the outside world since early Monday morning, leaving them unable to call friends or family abroad or reach emergency services.

human: For the members of Brooklyn’s Aleppan Jewish community, the tinier the meat- or cheese-filled pastry, the better the cook.
llm: For the members of a small, close-knit community in northeast Wisconsin, it was the ultimate betrayal:
In 1987, a well-known resident and former teacher at their high school was charged with sexual abuse.
Now, as the accused man prepares to leave prison after serving his sentence, a community reels from the lingering impact of that case and others like it.

human: Some new restaurants are opportunistic, the result of circumstance.
Others, like the Danish chef Mads Refslund’s new Brooklyn project, are years in the planning — eight years exactly, said Mr. Refslund, a founder of Noma in Copenhagen.
What he set out to achieve is a fluid fine-dining concept, where the cooks are the servers.
“Everyone is a cook,” he said.
“They can best explain the food to the customers, but turning cooks into waiters is a challenge.”
There are 26 of them, all dressed in black and rotating their stations.

They’re in full view at work: The dining room amounts to a huge square kitchen, surrounded by 58 counter and table seats, and a bar and a lounge in an industrial space — previously a rubber factory — with a white brick 1930s facade.
The restaurant’s menu lists ingredients, each of which can be ordered, in consultation with a cook/waiter, hot or cold, grilled or chilled, or, as the name has it, fire (ild in Danish) and ice (is).
The only meat options are sustainable American bison and venison.
Custom carts bearing produce and seafood snacks to start a meal (priced per item) patrol the dining area.
The menu is à la carte with a minimum of five dishes per person ($150); some are served family-style.
The 18-seat bar also serves food with no minimum requirement.

Among the dishes devised by Mr. Refslund and Bryce Shuman, his chef de cuisine (who knows his way around a grill if his food at Sweetbriar, his previous gig, is any indication), are Shigoku oysters with green almonds and cucumber, venison tartare wrapped in beet rosettes, tuna lightly roasted on kombu, grilled wild duck with plum juice, grilled sea scallop dumplings, surf clam shells sealed to form a vessel and filled with clam and tomato water to drink, and smoked barbecued eel.
On Sundays, meals are served family style, starting at noon, no reservations.
(Opens Wednesday)
llm: Some new restaurants are opening on the 21st Street corridor between Union Square and Tompkins Square Park.
A few months ago, we reported that the owners of Dovetail (the restaurant at the former Sons & Daughters space) were planning to open a new pizza place called The Woods.

human: Over the course of a few days this week, we got two pretty remarkable data points for the 2024 election.
llm: Over the course of a long political career, Joe Biden has had plenty of time to develop a deep well of wisdom on how to navigate a presidential campaign.

But as he launches his second bid for the Democratic nomination, Biden is now having to recalibrate that advice in light of a new reality: A 76-year-old white man can no longer simply coast through the primaries without serious scrutiny from voters who have grown accustomed to seeing women and people of color leading the field.

human: When readers receive their annual copy of Puzzle Mania in the Sunday edition of The New York Times, very often their first thought is, How am I going to get this done?
We offered some helpful ways to approach this humongous labor of love in this article, but we asked that no one post any spoilers in the comments.
llm: When readers receive a book like this, it is hard to know how to describe it.
Is it a novel?
A memoir?
A collection of essays?
A series of poems?
In the end, we decided to call it all that and more: a super mega support group.
The 134 pages are divided into three sections.
The first part, which comprises fifty-four poems, explores the author's struggles with addiction, mental illness, depression, anxiety, and PTSD.
The second section includes seven essays on recovery, healing, spirituality, love, family, and self-acceptance.
The third section features fourteen letters addressed to various people in the author's life who have supported her through difficult

human: With plagiarism in the news, here are five novels that show it's an engrossing plot device, too.
llm: With plagiarism in the news once again (the most recent case involving an assistant professor at Emory University), I thought it would be a good time to highlight some novels about plagiarism, including a few that feature writers as protagonists.
The list is by no means comprehensive—just my own favorites:

human: It’s a numinous blue that suggests the sky, the sea, the infinite.
It’s a field — poetic and abstract — that sets off the eloquence of dancing bodies.
The cerulean backdrop associated with the ballets of George Balanchine and New York City Ballet has come to seem so natural a setting for plotless ballet that we barely notice it.
llm: It’s a numinous thing, the way the light catches in the costume of one of City Ballet’s corps dancers.
It is something you can never really explain to someone who hasn’t seen it and it is something that makes you want to see more.
It’s part of what makes ballet such a visual art form, with its ability to move your emotions through the way it moves bodies on stage.
The glowing costumes are just one reason why, when I first saw “The Nutcracker” as a child, I knew that I would always love this art form.

human: The top Republican Senate campaign group filed a brief on Wednesday with the United States Supreme Court in support of Donald J. Trump’s appeal of a Colorado ruling blocking him from the state’s presidential ballot.
It is the latest sign of the rallying effect that the former president’s legal woes are having on his party.
llm: The top Republican in the state Senate filed a brief Thursday supporting President Donald Trump’s appeal to halt Colorado’s recount process, arguing that state law gives the presidential candidate the right to “choose” which votes are counted or not counted and should have final say over whether ballots are rejected for being unreadable or for other reasons.

human: The first several minutes of Adrian Murray’s cringe comedy take place in a single, uninterrupted shot.
Framed from behind, Molly (Molly Reisman), a 20-something woman in Toronto, and her new housemate, wait in a car by the side of the road as a cop issues Molly a ticket for reckless driving.
Even as the film eventually moves on to multiple other locations, including Molly’s apartment, her office and her ex-boyfriend’s home, we never truly leave those initial minutes in the car.

The incident takes over Molly’s entire life as she becomes increasingly obsessed with fighting the ticket — re-enacting the scenario repeatedly, doing the rounds of traffic court and talking her friends’ and co-workers’ ears off about the wrongs of the system.
llm: The first several minutes of this film are so beautiful and so heartbreaking, that I was prepared for a masterpiece.
But then the movie got too weird (even by my standards) for me to be able to enjoy it as much as I wanted to.
It's still very good and well worth watching.

human: When around a dozen reporters and editors on The New York Times’s Well desk sat around a long table in a conference room in July to brainstorm ideas for a challenge readers could complete to jump-start their 2024, a variety of suggestions were thrown out: How to live a more joyful life.
A week’s worth of decluttering exercises.
A relationship challenge.
llm: When around a dozen people were killed in the 1973-4 massacre of women and children at Wounded Knee, South Dakota, federal authorities decided it was time to take drastic measures.
The U.S. Bureau of Indian Affairs set up a camp for the hundreds of Sioux men, women and children who had fled their homes after being attacked by federal agents.

human: When she was in her early teens, Rokhaya Diagne would retreat to her brother’s room, where she played online computer games for hours, day after day, until her mother finally got fed up.
llm: When she was 15 years old, in the middle of her freshman year at an all-girls school in New York City, Anjali Joseph decided that the best way to spend her spring break would be to visit her mother’s family in India and work on a project for one of her classes.

human: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump filed an emergency request to a federal appeals court on Thursday seeking to lift the gag order imposed on him in the criminal case in which he stands accused of trying to overturn the 2020 election.
llm: Lawyers for former Trump campaign manager Paul Manafort and his business partner Rick Gates have filed a motion with the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit, asking that a gag order imposed by Judge Amy Berman Jackson on Friday be lifted immediately so they can speak publicly about the case.

human: Cari Beauchamp, a political adviser turned historian who documented the overlooked story of women in early Hollywood, when the film industry’s chaotic beginnings allowed them to assert a surprising amount of power, died on Thursday in Los Angeles.
She was 74.
llm: Cari Beauchamp, a film historian who chronicled the exploits and accomplishments of early Hollywood’s most famous women actors, died on Sunday in Los Angeles.
She was 74.

human: When Maira Khan’s boyfriend left her last year, she was desperate to win him back.
“I knew he was seeing someone else, but I didn’t know how serious it was,” said Ms. Khan, an influencer in Toronto.
“I kind of just wanted her gone.”
llm: When Maira Khan’s mother, Fatima, was diagnosed with cancer in 2017, she made an unusual request.
“She wanted me to make her a healing spell,” Khan said.
“I was like, ‘What?’
I thought it would be so cheesy.”
But Khan, who is Muslim and lives in Queens, New York, went ahead with the project.
She began searching for inspiration online, where she found a video by a witch named Melissa Madara, which laid out a simple incantation to cure illness.
“The first thing that came into my head was ‘My mom will never see this,’” Khan recalled.
“And then I was like, wait—what am I saying?”

human: Former President Donald J. Trump declared in the first rally of his 2024 presidential campaign: “I am your retribution.”
He later vowed to use the Justice Department to go after his political adversaries, starting with President Biden and his family.
llm: Former President Donald Trump will retain considerable power over the Republican Party in the next decade.
The party’s transition team is already working on a “transition manual” for his successor, whoever that may be.
It will include guidance about how to handle Trump’s political apparatus after he leaves office — including his social media following and campaign organization.

human: An urgent bid by the Biden administration to send a fresh infusion of money to Ukraine for its war against Russia has stalled on Capitol Hill as congressional Republicans demand sweeping changes to the immigration system.
llm: An urgent bid to stop the Trump administration from sending thousands of asylum seekers back to Mexico — where they face threats, extortion and violence at the hands of human smugglers and gang members — appeared to be collapsing on Tuesday night after a federal judge refused to temporarily halt deportations.
The ruling came hours after President Trump said he was “working on something very dramatic” to end what he called an “invasion.”

human: The sounds of battle echo on both sides of Israel’s northern border with Lebanon.
Sirens blare in Israeli towns, warning of incoming rockets fired by Lebanon’s Hezbollah militant group.
Lebanese civilians have fled their villages, fearing Israeli shelling and the possibility of a new war.
llm: The sounds of war have long since faded from Lebanon’s capital.
But they are far from forgotten.

human: Nearly $900,000 is guaranteed to be awarded to the top finishers in this year’s New York City Marathon, and additional prize money could be distributed if athletes break course records.
llm: Nearly $900,000 is on the line for this year's tournament.
The winner of the main event will receive a check worth more than $562,000.
There are also 18 other events with prize pools ranging from $33,470 to $215,000.

human: Welcome to a mammoth edition of our Teenagers in The Times feature.
llm: Welcome to a new series about the lives of teens.
This is an exercise in imagining what might be, not what will be — but it’s fun to imagine.
I’m interested in how this generation will live differently than my generation did, and also how they won’t.

human: The lament is as old as education itself: The students aren’t paying attention.
But today, the problem of flighty or fragmented attention has reached truly catastrophic proportions.

High school and college teachers overwhelmingly report that students’ capacity for sustained, or deep attention has sharply decreased, significantly impeding the forms of study — reading, looking at art, round-table discussions — once deemed central to the liberal arts.
llm: The lament is that today's media environment, with its infinite choices of information and entertainment, has led to a society in which we are all being distracted by the constant ping of our smartphones or the next viral video.
Too many people are addicted to their devices, unable to focus on one thing for more than 20 seconds at a time.
Even when people aren't actually watching TV shows or YouTube videos, they're still looking at screens:
It's become so easy to multitask that it doesn't even feel like multitasking anymore.

human: Sara Tavares, a Portuguese songwriter, singer and guitarist with a gentle voice and an ear for global pop, died on Nov. 19 in Lisbon.
She was 45.
llm: Sara Tavares, a singer and songwriter who became an unlikely pop star in Portugal with songs that melded her native Cape Verdean musical traditions with R&B and world music influences, died on Saturday in Lisbon.
She was 45.

human: Most prescriptions in the United States are handled by one of three companies: CVS Caremark, Express Scripts or Optum Rx.
These pharmacy benefit managers serve as middlemen between the drug companies that make the medications and the insurance plans that pay for your prescriptions.
llm: Most prescriptions in the United States are paid for by insurance companies, and a large portion of them are covered by Medicare.
But when your prescription is filled, you may not know whether you're being overcharged -- or how much it's costing.
A new Consumer Reports investigation reveals that even though many drugs are relatively inexpensive, pharmacists often charge more than what they should.

human: “Beyond Utopia,” a documentary on defectors from North Korea, begins by pre-empting the inevitable questions about how it was made.
“The film contains no recreations,” the opening titles explain.
The footage, we are told, was shot by the filmmakers, the subjects and operatives in the underground network that helped those subjects escape.
llm: “Beyond Utopia,” a new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, proposes that the notion of utopianism is no longer viable as a framework for thinking about art or society.
This might be because it has been subsumed by capitalism and its promises of infinite progress, or maybe it is just because we have learned how to live without it.”

human: The drive from Nashville to New Orleans is 533 miles.
llm: The drive from New Orleans to Baton Rouge takes about an hour and forty minutes, so you should arrive in time for lunch.
The 10-mile stretch between New Orleans and Baton Rouge is also known as “French Settlement,” named after the Acadians who settled there in the 18th century.
If you are interested in learning more about this history, we recommend stopping at one of two plantations: Laura Plantation or Destrehan Plantation.
Both are great places to learn about Creole culture and Louisiana’s past.

human: Just south of Baghdad, the urban sprawl gives way to glimpses of green, with lush date palm groves bordering the Euphrates River.
But few risk spending much time there.
Not even the Iraqi military or government officials venture without permission.
llm: Just south of Baghdad, the town of Mahmoudiya is one of the most dangerous places in Iraq.
The place where U.S. Marines were ambushed last month.
The place where Shia militias and Sunni insurgents are locked in a fierce struggle for control of a vital supply route to Baghdad.
And now the place where Iranian-supplied missiles have been fired into Baghdad’s airport, less than 30 miles away.

human: The word sentience has appeared in 22 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 15 in “Can A.I. Invent?” by Steve Lohr:
llm: The word sentience is a noun.
Sentience means (1) the quality or state of having sensation; awareness of something by means of the senses; sensibility, (2) the capacity for feeling pain or pleasure.

human: Vajra Chandrasekera’s THE SAINT OF BRIGHT DOORS (Tordotcom, 356 pp., $27.99) is the best book I’ve read this year.
Fetter, the protagonist, is one of several almost-chosen-ones who have shirked or sidestepped their spectacular destinies in favor of haunted and marginal lives in the city of Luriat.
The city has many “bright doors” that seem to open onto nothing.
Fetter’s fascination with them draws him into a web of Luriati intrigue involving his estranged and godlike father, the Perfect and Kind — whom Fetter has been trained since childhood to kill.
llm: Vajra Chandrasekera’s THE LONG WAY TO A SMALL, ANGRY PLANET is a novel about people living on the only planet in the universe with life.
The story follows a group of characters who are all trying to find their place in this new world.
One character is an alien from another planet who has been forced to live as an indentured servant on the human colony for twenty years after his own planet was destroyed by war.
Another character is a young woman who is part of the first generation born outside of a space station after humans began colonizing planets.

These two stories intersect when the alien and the young woman meet each other at the same time that they both decide to leave the spaceship colony where they have spent most of their lives and go out into the world

human: Before the war (the First World War, I mean; with so many wars one can lose count), Max Beckmann was painting clean, traditionalist self-portraits and lush pictures of bathers by the sea.
He was a neoconservative with no time for Matisse or Picasso, and certainly no interest in the coming of abstraction.
Then, when the war broke out, the artist volunteered for the medical corps of the Imperial German Army.
He got posted to Flanders, where he witnessed the murderous, meaningless second Battle of Ypres.
He sketched the Belgian landscape, and the doctors and orderlies.
llm: Before the war, he was a well-known German artist whose work had been exhibited in the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
He painted the “Four Happy Ones,” an image of the Weimar Republic that has become a classic, but after Hitler came to power in 1933, Beckmann fled Germany for Amsterdam, then Paris.
In 1940, with France about to fall to the Germans, he moved to New York.

human: Not without reason has modeling been termed the ugly business of being beautiful.
Opaque, barely regulated and often cutthroat, it is seldom viewed as an incubator of big-hearted altruists.

Yet when news came this week that Ivan Bart, the former president of IMG models, died suddenly at age 60 — following what was described as a brief illness — social media lit up with outpourings of praise for a man that Fern Mallis, a seasoned industry consultant and the author of “Fashion Lives: Fashion Icons with Fern Mallis,” called “one of the most delicious human beings you ever want to know.”
llm: Not without reason, the name of John Galliano is connected with the phrase “the best fashion designer.”

And although he has recently experienced a serious crisis in his personal life and professional career, we can’t help but remember his work as one of the most creative and talented people who ever walked the catwalk.

human: What do we do with the Oompa-Loompas?
llm: What do we know about the Oompa-Loompas?
They are short, funny-looking, and seemingly indestructible.
In fact, they have been around for a very long time—since the days of Lewis Carroll's Alice in Wonderland.
(And while we are on the subject of Alice, she was actually named after the heroine of another famous children's classic: Sir Walter Scott's 1837 romantic novel The Fair Maid of Perth.)
There are many references to them in literature and pop culture.
But who are they really?
And what can be said with certainty about their origins and history?
What follows is an attempt at a brief review of all that has been written about this enigmatic people over the past

human: The police chief of Marion, Kansas, who had ordered raids on the office of a local newspaper and the home of its publisher in August resigned on Monday, an official said, after facing mounting questions over his officers’ aggressive actions against the news organization.
llm: The police chief who ordered the deadly raid last week on a Kansas newspaper has resigned.

human: A team of researchers have announced the discovery of a new species of Tyrannosaurus from New Mexico, one that appeared in the fossil record five million to seven million years before the familiar tyrant lizard.
Their research, published Thursday in the journal Scientific Reports, suggests a new chapter could be added to the origin story of Tyrannosaurus rex.
llm: A team of researchers from the University of Alberta, the University of Calgary and China have published a paper in Nature Communications describing an alternative origin story for the largest land predator ever to walk on Earth: the tyrannosaurid dinosaur.

In their paper published in the journal Nature Communications, the group describes how they reconstructed the life history of a new species of theropod dinosaurs named Zhenyuanlong suni using a combination of fossils and CT scans of the bones.

human: When Mark Basa needed his next dose of Wegovy, he worked his way down a list of 10 CVS stores within a 25-mile radius of his Peekskill, N.Y., home — and struck out at every one.
In the 10 weeks he couldn’t find the drug, he regained the eight pounds he had lost on the medication, and his blood sugar rose.
He felt himself get out of breath more often.
His shirts fit tighter.
llm: When Mark Basa was diagnosed with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in 2013, he started a treatment called chemotherapy.
It was supposed to be temporary:
After six months of it, his cancer would have been cured and he could return to work as an IT consultant.
But the chemo made him so sick that he ended up having to stop working for more than three years.
When he did eventually resume his job last year, his employer said he had to go through another round of chemotherapy — this time a different one — before he could come back to work.
Mr. Basa declined.
He is still unemployed.
And now there is nothing left for his doctor to do but wait for his disease to get worse

human: “Right now, it’s worth $4 — and a cardboard box.”
llm: “Right now, it’s a bit like the Wild West.
It’s difficult to tell what is real and what isn’t.”

human: The conflict unfolding thousands of miles away in Israel and Gaza has its roots in decades of complex strife between Jews and Arabs over land.
But to hear the way it’s being described in American conservative media, much of the fault and responsibility lies with one man: President Biden.
llm: The conflict unfolding between Israel and Palestinian militants in Gaza is a “bloody mess,” but it’s not one that former Vice President Joe Biden created.

Yet this week alone, conservative media outlets have claimed just that: The New York Post asserted on Wednesday that “Biden blames Israel for starting Middle East war” and accused him of saying that “the Jewish state ‘provoked’ the latest round of fighting.”
Similarly, Fox News host Sean Hannity said that Biden was to blame because he “has been a major cheerleader for the Palestinians.”

human: Good morning.

human: Nearly 30 young people took refuge inside a grimy bunker on the morning of Oct. 7, hoping the reinforced-concrete shelter near the border with Gaza would fulfill its promise of protection.
llm: Nearly 30 young children and their teachers were killed by a suicide bomber at a school in the Russian city of Beslan on Tuesday morning (Sept. 1).
The attackers took over more than 1,200 people hostage in the gymnasium of School Number One.
As negotiations failed to produce a peaceful outcome, Russian special forces stormed the building late Monday evening.
The gun battle that ensued resulted in the deaths of an estimated 334 people, including 186 hostages.

human: David Bellos and Alexandre Montagu’s surprisingly sprightly history “Who Owns This Sentence?” arrives with uncanny timing.

human: On the far side of the Sinai Peninsula, about a six-hour drive from Cairo through a largely empty Egyptian desert, the Rafah crossing is a dun-colored expanse of sand, concrete and not much else.
Isolated from the rest of the Egypt by not only distance but also heavy military restriction, Rafah can feel as distant from world events as any place on the planet.
llm: On the far side of Rafah, in Egypt's Sinai peninsula, there are more than 10,000 Palestinians from Gaza living as refugees.
Many have been expelled from their homes by Israeli forces and now live in crowded camps, in tents or in caves.
Some have returned to their villages but cannot enter them because they are under curfew.
The people of Rafah live a life of poverty.
There is no work for them and little hope.
In the last three weeks alone, 25 Palestinians have died in the area from malnutrition, including 18 children.

human: During his wedding ceremony at a picturesque resort in the Southern California desert, Gerry Turner made his way down an aisle lined with roses.

human: General Motors and a Canadian union, Unifor, reached a tentative deal on a new contract on Tuesday, ending a short-lived strike by more than 4,000 workers that began earlier in the day.
llm: General Motors and the Canadian Auto Workers union reached a tentative agreement on a new four-year contract yesterday, ending a lengthy dispute that had threatened to shut down G.M.'s three assembly plants in Canada.
The deal includes a 3 percent annual wage increase for the first two years of the contract, followed by raises of 2 percent each year in the final two years.

human: How political should fashion get?
At least when it comes to acceptance speeches.
That was the elephant — or woolly mammoth, or orca — in the room Monday night at the Council of Fashion Designers of America awards, a.k.a.
the Oscars of fashion.
llm: How political should fashion be?
This question has been on my mind a lot lately.
I have been following the political fashion conversation that’s happening around the internet, from my Instagram feed to my news feeds and in the comments sections of online articles.

The conversation is all over the place: Some people are saying that the “Oscars of American Fashion” is the wrong venue for politics and some others are saying that fashion is an industry and it should not be exempted from discussing politics.
Some designers are taking sides – and so are their clients.
The whole thing feels very confusing.

human: Wall Street, the White House and the Fed will all be watching Friday’s jobs report for signs of how the labor market is holding up.

llm: Wall Street, the Federal Reserve and investors will be closely watching Friday's jobs report for clues about when interest rates might rise.

human: As children, Uché Blackstock and her twin sister, Oni, delighted in riffling through their mother, Dale’s, doctor’s bag, both at home and when they visited her at the Brooklyn hospital where she was a kidney specialist.
llm: As children, Uché Okonkwo and her mother were inseparable.
They played together, did chores together, and even went to the same schools.
But when she was a teenager, they grew apart as her mother’s health began to deteriorate.
Uché struggled to understand what was happening to her mom, who was diagnosed with sickle cell anemia at birth but had been treated by doctors for years without any long-term relief.

human: The tech start-up Humane launched a new device, an A.I. pin meant to be worn on our clothing.
