llm: It was a grim reminder that even as the Taliban have been driven from most of their strongholds in Afghanistan by an American-backed offensive, they have regrouped and replenished their ranks.

llm: The Hamas-run Health Ministry on Wednesday released a list with the names and ages of 6,747 people they say were killed by Israeli strikes during Operation Protective Edge.

human: In the last year and a half, New York City has scrambled to try and provide shelter and services to over 150,000 migrants.
“This American Life” takes a look at how that’s going.
llm: In the last three years, we have witnessed an unprecedented explosion in the use of surveillance cameras and video analytics by law enforcement agencies.
In the United States alone, 30 states now require that law enforcement agencies record all interactions with civilians.
And in the UK, the Metropolitan Police has begun to deploy thousands of cameras on the London underground.
The goal is to deter crime and catch criminals, but what are the privacy implications?
Are we being watched more than ever before?
How can we make sure our actions aren't recorded without our knowledge or consent?

human: Ava DuVernay’s “Origin” is as audacious as it is ambitious.
At its core, it concerns an intellectual argument about history and hierarchies of power, but it’s also about the fraught process of making this argument.
It’s a daunting conceit that DuVernay has shaped into an eventful narrative that is, by turns, specific and far-ranging, diagnostic and aspirational.
It is a great big swing about taking a great big swing, and while the film is more persuasive as a drama than the argument it relays, few American movies this year reach so high so boldly.
llm: Ava DuVernay’s “Origin” is a documentary about racism and the American prison system.
It’s an unsettling film, but it also offers hope — even if it’s not immediately apparent.
DuVernay’s goal with this film is to start conversations about race and how we can begin to heal from the wounds inflicted on us by centuries of oppression and violence.
She wants to help people understand their place in our country’s history.
And she does that through interviews with experts, activists, and former prisoners.
But while these voices are important, they aren’t always as effective as they could be.
That’s because “Origin” doesn’t just tell you what happened in the past; it shows you why it matters

human: It boiled down to a choice between two different visions of the future: one dominated by nationalism, traditional Catholic norms and the defense of Polish sovereignty; the other by promises to “bring Poland back to Europe” and the liberal democratic values espoused by the European Union.
llm: It boiled down to this: The Poles, and those in the West who support them, are fighting against the tide of history.
They have been betrayed by their allies; they have lost their way in a world that has moved on from the Cold War.
And it is a measure of how far the Polish nation has come since communism's fall 25 years ago that it now appears to be losing its grip on power.

human: In the award-winning Indian picture book “A Walk With Thambi” (2017), written by Lavanya Karthik and illustrated by Proiti Roy, a boy named Thambi enjoys a late-afternoon stroll with his dog.

Instead, we follow along as the pair listen to street sounds, smell the bazaar, feel the breeze and play with friends.
When they realize it’s sunset and past their curfew, they race home, eyes wide and legs (and stick) akimbo.
Thambi’s mother takes in the muddy duo and finally, humorously, it is revealed that her son is blind.
llm: In the award-winning series The Librarian of Basra, children learn to read Arabic through a magical story that takes place in Iraq.

Her teacher goes to find her and ends up getting kidnapped by ISIS soldiers who take them across the border into Syria.
Along the way, Zahra learns to speak fluent Arabic from two men they meet along the way, one named Waleed and another named Samir.
As they travel together for days and nights, they all become friends and learn about each other's culture and beliefs.
When Zahra finally reaches her home, she

human: Name a stamp.
Any stamp.
llm: Name a stamp.
What's the first thing that comes to mind?
Maybe you think of the USPS logo or maybe even the postage rates.
But if you were to ask someone about stamps in general terms, they would probably tell you that it is just an item used for mailing packages.
But there are actually some pretty interesting stories behind different stamps throughout history.

human: Ana Carolina Pejo Henderson and her parents were sure Jonathan Milam Walters would run the other way after spending a couple days in August 2022 wrangling, shearing and vaccinating a few hundred baby lambs on their farm in Artigas, Uruguay, bordering Brazil.
llm: Ana Carolina Pejo, the Brazilian artist who was born without legs and a right arm, is a whiz with her mouth.

She can blow bubbles so big that they look like balloons; she can make a noise that sounds like a train coming to a stop; and she can imitate a bird or a motorcycle engine just by making her mouth do certain things.

human: As Israel’s offensive pushed Palestinian civilians into ever smaller pockets of land with few supplies, Israel’s military said that Hamas militants had fired rockets from what it called “humanitarian zones” in southern Gaza, citing maps, satellite photos and footage as evidence.

See the latest news.
llm: As Israel’s offensive against Hamas in the Gaza Strip entered its fourth day, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Defense Minister Ehud Barak said that they have no intention of stopping their attacks until Hamas stops firing rockets into Israel.

human: At China’s top political gathering for women, it was mostly a man who was seen and heard.
llm: At China’s top universities, women outnumber men 3-to-1, but are far less likely than their male counterparts to pursue careers.
In a recent study by Chinese researchers, one of the main reasons for this discrepancy was that “women tend to be more sensitive about their family background and social status.”
This is not an insignificant point:

Many Chinese parents have told me that they want their daughters to marry well—that is, to secure themselves a man with good prospects and a successful career—rather than to embark on their own professional journeys.
And as a result, many young women in China will do what they can to help their families economically, even if it means sacrificing their own ambitions.

human: The trucks carrying aid for Gaza stop for exhaustive inspections by Israeli authorities.

llm: The trucks carrying supplies for the Palestinians in Gaza are being delayed at the Erez Crossing by Israeli security forces.

human: For month after endless month, nights in Kyiv were punctuated by the wail of air raid sirens and the sound of explosions from missile and drone attacks.

llm: For month after month, residents of Ukraine's capital have been waking up to a new sound — the roar of heavy artillery.
But now that the fighting has moved away from the city and Ukrainian forces have pushed rebels back on several fronts, life is slowly returning to normal in Kiev, if not to pre-war levels.

human: On the national debate stage, in interviews and at town halls, the message on immigration from every top Republican in the 2024 presidential race has resounded clearly: It is time to shut down the nation’s southern border.
llm: On the national stage, there is a lot of talk about closing the border.
But what would that mean?
It seems like we would have to round up millions of people and ship them back to where they came from.
That sounds expensive.
And it also doesn't sound like something that anyone wants to do.
So we asked White House spokeswoman Stephanie Grisham what she thought it meant.
She said, quote, "If you are saying that somebody should not be allowed in this country legally or illegally - if they are here now, we will work with ICE and DHS to close that person out."

human: Few filmmakers can claim the same heights of whimsy, artistry and storytelling as writer-director Hayao Miyazaki, whose modern-day fables seem to prove that having one’s head in the clouds isn’t a fault, but a virtue — in more ways than one.

From his 1988 breakthrough “My Neighbor Totoro” to his 2001 Oscar-winning animated feature, “Spirited Away,” the sky is one of Miyazaki’s favorite playgrounds, where flight is about more than just elevation; it’s about transcendence.
llm: Few filmmakers can evoke a sense of wonder in their viewers like Hayao Miyazaki.
The Japanese animator, who is best known for his work on Studio Ghibli’s “Spirited Away” and “My Neighbor Totoro,” has an incredible talent for painting pictures with words.
He creates worlds that feel so real it’s easy to forget you’re watching animated characters.
Even after years of seeing them, his films never get old because he gives each one a unique style and voice.

human: Ukrainian forces have stepped up assaults across the Dnipro river near the southern city of Kherson, carrying out raids into Russian-controlled territory on the eastern bank.

llm: Ukrainian forces have carried out at least three large-scale raids across the Dnieper River to take back territory lost during the conflict with Russian-backed separatists.

human: In June, a group of young people in Montana won a landmark lawsuit related to climate change when, for the first time in the United States, a judge ruled that the state’s failure to consider climate change when approving fossil fuel projects was unconstitutional.

With these lawsuits, along with social media activism and protests, Gen Z is making its voice heard.
llm: In June, a group of students from the Green Schools Alliance (GSA) attended the National Youth Leadership Council’s 2015 National Summit on Youth Engagement.

human: Happy 2024!
How did you ring it in?
Were you in beast mode last night, shimmying from one party to the next?
Or were you among those who welcomed the new year tranquilly from home?
My household is Team Tranquil: a classic movie, a glass of Champagne and bed by 12:06.
That means I’ve preserved enough pep today to cook something hearty and healthful to start the year — to set an intention, as they say, to widen my diet to include foods that aren’t cookies.
llm: Happy 2024!
How about some white bean soup with turkey and greens?
A little protein, a lot of fiber.
And if you're trying to lose weight in the new year, it's a good way to get started.
This is also great for people who are watching their sodium intake.
The beans add a ton of flavor without adding any salt.

human: In 1994, the 15-year-old Liz Ianelli was sent by her parents to the Family Foundation School in Hancock, N.Y., which claimed to treat her disruptive behavior.

While there, she was also raped by a kitchen employee, she said.
Then, as punishment for “lying” about it, she was bound in a blanket with duct tape and left in a boiler room for eight days.
llm: In 1994, the first time I visited a wilderness therapy program for troubled teens in Utah, the students were on a two-week hike in the mountains.
They were so tired that they had to be carried off their packs at nightfall and put into tents by the staff.
One of my daughters, then 16, was among them.
When she returned home, she told me about a boy who had died on the trip.
He’d fallen from a cliff while hiking with his counselor.
No one else witnessed it.
The counselor was not certified in wilderness therapy, as required by the program; he was a volunteer.

human: “For some reason I wanted to be a dancer,” Michael Keegan-Dolan said of his younger self.

llm: “For some reason, the Irish have been known for their dance since ancient times.
The dance was a way of communicating between people who had very little else to communicate with.”

human: The author of this newsletter takes a generally dim view of wealthy donors who give lots of money to America’s richest universities, and an especially critical view of those who do so despite harboring strong objections to the leftward ideological drift of those same institutions.

human: For four seconds, Nathaniel Veltman floored the gas pedal, hurtling his pickup truck toward a Muslim family of five out for an evening walk in London, Ontario, killing four of them.

human: Will technology — and the people who make it — lead us into a better future?

This week on “Matter of Opinion,” the hosts discuss Elon Musk, techno-optimism and the manifesto taking Silicon Valley by storm.
Plus, we learn that Ross wears dad drag.
llm: Will technology — and the rise of AI, automation and machine learning — really be a boon for humankind?
Or will it make us worse off in the long run?

human: On the day Judge Tanya S. Chutkan was randomly selected to preside over former President Donald J. Trump’s trial on charges of conspiring to overturn the 2020 election, she called a childhood friend in Jamaica, Christine Stiebel.
Judge Chutkan, who is not especially religious, said to her friend, as Ms. Stiebel recalled it: “Chris, please pray for me.
I’ve got the case.”
llm: On the day of her death, Tanya Chutkan, a federal judge who was appointed by President Barack Obama and had been on the bench for less than two years, had just returned to her office after a routine medical procedure.
Her husband, David L. Mills, arrived at work that afternoon expecting to pick up his wife at the courthouse.
Instead he found her slumped over at her desk, unresponsive, with no pulse.
She was pronounced dead at 4:28 p.m.
The cause was a brain hemorrhage.

human: Colman Domingo joined a rarefied club on Tuesday: With an Oscar nomination for his performance as the civil rights activist Bayard Rustin in “Rustin,” he became only the second openly gay man to be nominated for playing a gay character.
Ian McKellen was the first, in 1999, for “Gods and Monsters” and his portrayal of James Whale, the real-life director of the iconic 1930s horror films “Frankenstein” and “Bride of Frankenstein.”
llm: Colman Domingo joined the cast in 2015, and his nomination was the second-ever for a performance on Broadway.
(The first was for the actor's role in "Red Velvet," which opened in 2012.)

human: An unexpected chill can fall over the Florida Everglades late at night.
Stars speckle the sky.
Frogs croak and croak, their mating calls echoing in the air.
llm: An unexpected chill passes over me.
I've never seen a python, but I have heard stories from my father about their deadly bite.
They're notorious for wrapping themselves around their prey—a small animal or bird—and squeezing until it dies, then swallowing its victim whole.
A human would be no match for one of these snakes.
My hand grips the steering wheel so tightly that my knuckles turn white.

human: Just before 2023 gave way to 2024, my husband and I drove down a mountain, talking about how to manage election-year anxiety.
Specifically, my election-year anxiety.
We had just spent a few days in a cottage in the woods, and we were jazzed on silence and stillness and the obligation to do nothing but walk together among the trees.
To listen to the wind in the trees.
llm: Just before 2023, I was in the kitchen making my favorite candy.
It's an old family recipe that is actually quite simple: you take some nuts and boil them with sugar until they're hard and brown.
Then you pour them onto a cookie sheet and bake them for another hour or so.
The result is delicious—but not very healthy.
As I sat down to enjoy my treat, I wondered if there wasn't something better I could be doing with all those nuts.
Maybe I should make some of the things people usually eat as snacks instead of dessert.

human: It doesn’t come with a ring, but this week was still special for former First Fan George W. Bush.
Nearly three decades after he sold the Texas Rangers, the team that propelled him into politics finally brought home its first World Series title.
llm: It doesn’t come as any surprise that the first-place New York Yankees are favored to win the American League East again this season.
But I don't think anyone expected them to be priced at -250 on the money line by Bet365.
The Toronto Blue Jays are second in the division at +280 while the Boston Red Sox have been given a price of +700.
The Tampa Bay Rays have been priced at +1400 followed by the Baltimore Orioles (+1800) and the Cleveland Indians (+2000).

human: Four days after 40 workers became trapped in a Himalayan road tunnel, the Indian authorities were still trying on Thursday to find a way through debris and rescue them, as anguished family members and colleagues protested outside to demand faster action.
llm: Four days after the collapse of an elevator shaft at a New York City construction site, rescue workers have yet to determine how many people are trapped beneath 20 feet of rubble.
The workers are expected to begin drilling into the ground on Saturday.

human: Welcome to the Trump on Trial newsletter!
llm: Welcome to the Trump impeachment trial.
You're going to need a scorecard to keep track of all the players, witnesses and rules.
We have you covered.

human: When Yaneth Flores first moved to Albany, in upstate New York, in 2008, she needed some time to get used to the sleepiness of a small city.
She had been working at a fish market near Boston, where she lived after fleeing violence and a bleak economy in El Salvador.
She met her husband in Albany and eventually settled into life there.
llm: When Yaneth Flores, a single mother in Colombia, was diagnosed with tuberculosis (TB), she didn’t know what to do.
She couldn't afford the treatment and had no one to turn to for help.
Her husband had left her when he found out that he had HIV, which meant that he could not provide care or support for his wife and daughter.
In addition, TB patients are stigmatized in Colombia, so Yaneth was afraid of seeking medical attention due to the social exclusion she might experience.

human: A four-bedroom, three-bath house built in 1930, with an entry foyer, a wood-burning fireplace in the formal living room, an office, a den, an eat-in kitchen with a two-level island, a finished lower level with a summer kitchen, a wine cellar and a laundry room, on one acre.
Heidi Karagianis, Daniel Gale Sotheby’s International Realty, 516-467-9440; danielgale.com
llm: A four-bedroom, three-bathroom house at 570 Cedar Street in Stamford.

human: California is barred again from enforcing its ban on guns in most public places after a federal appeals court ruled on Saturday that a lower court’s block on the ban should stand.
llm: California is barred from enforcing a 2016 law that would have banned guns from most public places unless the owner has a concealed-carry permit, according to a federal appeals court.

human: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida woke up in Iowa with a familiar political headache.
llm: Gov. Ron DeSantis is a Republican, but he's also a former Navy JAG officer and an Army Ranger.

human: Fighting continued into the evening on Saturday in one of the broadest invasions of Israeli territory in 50 years, as Palestinian militants from Gaza fired another round of rockets at Israel’s central heartland, including Tel Aviv, and Israel worked to clear militants from Israeli towns and retaliated with huge strikes on Gazan cities.
llm: Fighting continued into a second day, with Israel pounding militant targets in Gaza and Hamas firing rockets at Israeli towns.
The fighting has killed 10 Palestinians and three Israelis so far.

human: I was born in February 1998 in Tuba, a rural shepherding community of 80 Palestinian residents in the South Hebron Hills of the West Bank, where my family has lived for generations.
Over the years we have suffered repeated attacks by Israeli settlers, part of an ongoing campaign to remove us from our land.
Still, nothing prepared me for what our life has become since the Hamas attack on Oct. 7.
In the last six weeks, the raids and harassment by settlers have become so intense that I do not know how much longer I and the other members of my community will be able to live here.
llm: I was born in the West Bank village of Beit Ur al-Fauqa, which is located 16 kilometers southwest of Nablus and about a kilometer from the city of Salfit.

I live with my wife, four children and two grandchildren in a three-story house that sits on top of a hill overlooking the Palestinian cities of Nablus and Ramallah, as well as Jewish settlements such as Ariel, Barkan and Shilo.

human: Body positivity was not at all the cultural vibe in 1990, when Josefina López’s play “Real Women Have Curves” was new.

There was a rebelliousness to its climactic strip-down scene, in which a group of Latinas sewing dresses in a roasting-hot Los Angeles factory peel off layers of their clothing and shed a bit of shame, reveling in their lived-in bodies.
llm: Body positivity was a big thing in 2019.
I'm not talking about the usual "fat acceptance," though.
Instead, this year brought us more women embracing their bodies as they are instead of trying to change them to fit some arbitrary beauty standard.
In 2019, we saw all kinds of body types — thin, thick, tall, short, young, old, curvy, flat-chested, muscular, plus size — being celebrated by both models and brands alike.

human: My partner and I were eager to take in the ancient Greek sculptures at the Metropolitan Museum of Art that have been restored with the painted colors they would have had when new.
The Greek sculptors adorned their work with vibrant colors that wore off over time.
llm: My partner and I are both in the field of education, so when we're not out looking for a new dog or at a show, you can find us on weekends hanging around with other dog people.
This past weekend, my partner and I attended the annual American Dog Agility Association (ADAA)
Region 10 Championship Show in Fresno, CA.
It was our first time attending this particular event.
We went to watch friends compete and have fun, but it turned into more than that.

human: When it came time to find a salon for her daughter with coiled hair, Aude Livoreil-Djampou discovered what many women with curly or textured hair in Paris already knew.
llm: When it came to curly hair, Ms. Barker said, she had spent years trying to tame the unruly frizz on her head with straightening irons and chemical treatments that she regretted afterward.

human: Anthony Soto, a 22-year-old baggage claim employee at the Dallas Fort Worth International Airport, crumpled to the floor near gate C15 after a seizure last October that he attributed to hot indoor conditions and strenuous lifting.
In record-setting heat in Texas this past summer, Mr. Soto, who has epilepsy, had four more seizures that left him speechless, his body unresponsive, he said.
llm: Anthony Soto, a 25-year veteran of the construction industry in Texas, is still recuperating from a heat stroke he suffered on his job site last July.
He was building a luxury hotel near Austin when he became dizzy and disoriented and collapsed into unconsciousness.
His boss drove him to an emergency room where doctors put him through a battery of tests.
They concluded that he had likely been suffering from heat exhaustion for days before he collapsed.

human: The Vikings now have only a 40% chance to make the playoffs.
llm: The Vikings now have a 4-2 record and sit atop the NFC North.
The Vikes are currently in first place, but they have had a few close calls this year with their opponents.

The Vikings need to make sure that they take care of business against teams like the Chicago Bears, Detroit Lions, Green Bay Packers, Seattle Seahawks, and Tampa Bay Buccaneers if they want to make it to the playoffs.

human: The Israeli military said on Thursday that it had apprehended hundreds of people suspected of terrorism, including wanted Hamas operatives, across the Gaza Strip in a single day, and that many had surrendered and been transferred to Israel for further questioning.
llm: The Israeli military says it has arrested hundreds of Palestinians suspected of terrorist activity during a massive operation against militants in the Gaza Strip.

human: The snack chips had become pretty pricey.
llm: The snack chips, which are sold in 15-ounce bags for $3.99 to $4.29, have been a staple of the store since 1968 and were named one of the best-selling items last year.
The store will offer its own Dorito brand, which will be priced at about $2 per bag, said spokeswoman Julie Huston.
She declined to say how many stores would sell it or when the product would go on sale.

human: She met the “johns” for sex in northeast Columbus, Ohio, then drugged them with fentanyl, stole their possessions, and left them for dead, state prosecutors said.
All told, they said, the woman killed four men from January to June.
llm: She met the men on websites including Backpage and Craigslist, investigators said.
She would lure them to her house under the guise of a massage and then drug them before robbing them, according to authorities.

human: France on Wednesday became the latest Western country to reject accusations that Israel is committing genocide against Palestinian civilians in Gaza, a charge that was recently brought before a United Nations court in The Hague.
llm: France on Wednesday rejected accusations of genocide by a French human rights group against Israeli military actions in the Gaza Strip, calling them "false and baseless."

human: Most of us don’t want to think too much about our hot dogs: what’s in them, how they were made, what “nitrates” really do.
In her new audiobook, “Raw Dog,” the comedian Jamie Loftus bravely rips off the Band-Aid of her own hot dog ignorance.

The audiobook is many things: part gonzo travelogue in which Loftus and a boyfriend spend the summer of 2021 traversing the country to sample its dogs; part cultural analysis of the tube meat as American icon; part takedown of the factory farming system; part memoir about a crumbling relationship straining under the weight of cheap motel rooms and indigestion.
llm: Most of us are familiar with the list of ingredients on a hot dog wrapper.
And most of us have no idea what any of them mean.
But it turns out that some of those things can be pretty gross.
We talk to two authors about their book, The American Cheese Project, which explores all of the components of the iconic frankfurter and what makes it so beloved by millions.

human: Georgia Dullea, a style reporter for The New York Times who chronicled, with sly bemusement and a miniaturist’s eye for detail, three decades of a culture in transition, died on Sunday in the Bronx.
She was 90.
llm: Georgia Dullea, a journalist who covered the civil rights movement for The New York Times and was a pioneer in reporting on women's issues, died Saturday at her home in Greenwich Village.
She was 90.

human: Respiratory syncytial virus, or R.S.V., is a nasty bug.
It’s the leading cause of hospitalizations among American infants and results in thousands of deaths among the elderly each year.
llm: Respiratory syncytial virus, or RSV, is the leading cause of lower respiratory tract infection (LRTI) in infants worldwide and the second leading cause of pneumonia in children under 5 years old in the United States.
Each year, about 20 percent of U.S. infants will get an RSV infection that requires medical attention.
The infections are usually mild, but they can be severe enough to lead to hospitalization.
Some infected babies develop bronchiolitis — inflammation of the small airways in the lungs — while others may have more serious complications like viral pneumonia and apnea (breathing interruption).

human: I have eaten sweet-and-sour pork out of takeout containers on the floor of apartments while moving boxes towered over my head.
I have plucked out its pineapple wedges and bell peppers with plastic chopsticks under strings of puffer-fish lights at long-gone Polynesian restaurants in New Jersey.
I have eaten sweet-and-sour pork in which sugar and acid were equally matched antagonists, and I’ve eaten it when the sauce looked and tasted like melted lollipops.
llm: I have eaten at 52nd St. in Chinatown many times and never had any problems with the food, even when I was there on my own, as opposed to with other people who might have been more particular about the quality of their meals.
I am Chinese myself
and I know how to tell if the food is good or not.
I hope this review does not discourage anyone from trying it out for themselves.
I can recommend this place without reservations.

human: In a city of sprawl, the 10 freeway is a main character, running across the belly of Los Angeles and offering a straight shot from downtown to the Pacific Ocean — with a hazy glimpse of the Hollywood sign along the way.
llm: In a city that has never had enough roads, the freeways are so much more than just roads.
They are symbols of freedom, mobility and a way to get from point A to point B without being stopped by a traffic light or red light camera.

human: After George Hawkins completed a 13-year term in a Virginia prison for attempted murder, he asked the state last spring to restore his right to vote.
So far, the administration of Gov. Glenn Youngkin, who has unfettered discretion over such requests, has twice turned him down with almost no explanation.
llm: After George Hawkins, a 62-year old retired electrician in Cleveland, Ohio was arrested for voting illegally, he sued Governor John Kasich to get his vote back.
The lawsuit is an interesting one; it's not just about Mr. Hawkins and whether or not he should be allowed to vote, but also about what rights voters have if they are wrongfully disenfranchised.

human: “Rot in hell.”
llm: “Rot in hell.”

These were the words of Rep. Debbie Dingell (D-Mich.) on Saturday, as she expressed her dismay at President Donald Trump’s response to a white nationalist rally in Charlottesville that left one counterprotester dead and dozens injured.
“I am so disappointed with our president,” Dingell told CNN’s John Berman.

Dingell was among the most vocal Democrats to condemn Trump after his remarks that there were “very fine people” among the white supremacists who marched in Charlottesville over the weekend....
As for whether Republicans will

human: In many Mexican towns where wars between drug cartels continue to wreak havoc, the sight of a young man at night dressed in black and donning a balaclava would be terrifying.
On a recent Saturday in Mexico City, Peso Pluma strutted across the stage in the same outfit, to excited cheers: It was time for the corrido tumbado concert.
llm: In many Mexican states, the corridos tumbados are seen as a form of protest song against organized crime.

human: The United States carried out two airstrikes against facilities used by Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps and its proxies in eastern Syria early Friday in retaliation for a flurry of recent rocket and drone attacks against American forces in Iraq and Syria.
llm: The United States launched airstrikes on Saturday against three sites in Syria that it said were associated with the production of chemical weapons, in retaliation for an attack last weekend that American officials say was carried out by the government of President Bashar al-Assad.
The strikes, which took place around 4 a.m., local time, targeted a scientific research center in the Damascus suburbs and two chemical weapons facilities near Homs, the Pentagon said.

In a statement, Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr., chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, called the strikes “a one-time shot,” saying they would not lead to further attacks unless the Assad regime continued to use chemical weapons.
“It is in our national security interest

human: The Biden administration has advised Israel to delay a ground invasion of Gaza, hoping to buy time for hostage negotiations and to allow more humanitarian aid to reach Palestinians in the sealed-off enclave, according to several U.S. officials.
llm: The Biden administration, which has been working to prevent an Israeli attack on Iran’s nuclear facilities, is concerned that such a move could set off a regional war that could draw in U.S. forces and lead to a wider conflict with the Islamic Republic, according to current and former officials familiar with the situation.

human: Food in video games is often referred to as a “consumable,” a resource that confers health or another perk on the player.
But in Venba, a narrative cooking game, food is something more: It’s something to labor over, to infuse with rich emotions, to savor.
llm: Food in video games is a fun topic, but I think you can take it too far.
When there's too much of it, the game becomes less about the story or characters (or even the gameplay) and more about the food.

human: The group discusses what the Democratic Party means to them, its current strategy and its future after Biden.
llm: The group discusses what it would take for a candidate to be included in the list, which is based on a survey of 400 people.
The goal was to create a list that represents the diversity of the Democratic Party and American politics as a whole.

human: The Opinion video above gives voice to the lonely.

We are publishing it at the end of a year in which loneliness started getting the kind of attention it has long deserved — an effort led, in large part, by the surgeon general of the United States, Dr. Vivek Murthy.
In a guest essay last spring, he revealed that he, too, had struggled with loneliness and said the nation was facing “an epidemic of loneliness and isolation.”
Several days later, he issued a surgeon general advisory about the problem, calling it a “public health crisis” and outlining a strategy to confront it.
llm: The Opinion video series continues with a conversation between artist Carrie Schneider and critic Michael Auping.
In this segment, they discuss the exhibition The Life Span of Loneliness, which Schneider presented at the Contemporary Art Museum St. Louis in 2016-2017.

human: Edward Bleier, who brought Bugs Bunny, Porky Pig and other Looney Tunes characters to generations of Saturday morning TV viewers before becoming a prime mover in the rise of cable television and the transformation of Time Warner Cable into an industry giant, died on Tuesday at his home in East Hampton, N.Y.
He turned 94 the day before.
llm: Edward Bleier, who oversaw the launch of cable television and founded a company that became a giant in pay-TV, died on Sunday in Manhattan.
He was 94.

human: The United States conducted a new round of airstrikes — the second in roughly a day — in Iraq early Wednesday, destroying two facilities used by Iranian proxies that had been targeting American and coalition troops, U.S. military officials said.
llm: The United States carried out precision strikes against three facilities belonging to Kata’ib Hezbollah, a militia group with ties to Iran and the government of Iraq, killing 25 fighters and wounding dozens more in retaliation for an attack that killed an American contractor in Kirkuk Province last weekend.
The assault was the first direct military action by President Trump against the Islamic Republic after he pulled out of the nuclear accord last year and reimposed sanctions on Tehran’s economy.

human: Fighting in Sudan has spread to the outskirts of a major city that is a refuge for displaced people and a center for aid groups, threatening to open another deadly front in an eight-month war that has devastated Africa’s third-largest nation.
llm: Fighting in Sudan's Darfur region has spread to the city of El-Geneina, where thousands of people have sought refuge from attacks by government forces and allied militias, residents say.
The United Nations says 200,000 people fled their homes this month, most of them women and children.

human: If abiding by resolutions were as easy as setting them, perfection would be attainable and the self-improvement section of the bookstore would be cobweb city.
Still, self-reflection can be a rewarding exercise at the beginning of a new year.
What better place to start than in the kitchen, where you have to spend at least a little bit of time each day?
llm: If abiding by your resolutions is not possible, consider making your own rules.

If you're trying to eat healthier but find yourself craving junk food, don't just go ahead and eat it; instead, create an allowance for that one meal of the day where you can have whatever you want — even if it means going back for seconds or thirds.
Or if you're trying to cut out sugar from your diet, try cutting down on how much sugar you add to coffee or tea rather than giving up these beverages altogether.

human: On a blustery December morning, the Rev. Nicky Skipworth is leading her congregation in prayer.
But the word of God is not being delivered from the pulpit of the parish church in Harworth, a village outside Doncaster, England.
It costs the church 200 pounds, or $255, to heat a midweek service.
To save funds, it has been moved to the local sports center.
llm: On a blustery night in the English city of Birmingham, 20 priests gathered at a pub for an informal meeting.
They were not there to talk about how to bring more people into the pews on Sunday morning or how to make their churches feel less like museums or how to preach better homilies.
No, these priests had come together to vent about the Church they serve—and to plot its demise.

human: Gary Wang, a former top executive of the failed FTX cryptocurrency exchange, testified that Sam Bankman-Fried, the company’s founder, was the final decision maker at the firm and directed a closely related hedge fund to misuse as it pleased billions of dollars in money from FTX customers.
llm: Gary Wang, a co-founder of the now-defunct Financial Textile Exchange (FTX), has written to members and former employees alleging that FTX’s Chief Operating Officer, Sam Bankman-Fried, had misused funds.

human: My earliest memories of late-night television shows are of the guests, not the hosts.
In the late ’80s and early ’90s, before the omnipresence of the internet, celebrities could promote their movies or sitcoms on talk shows with wild, unfiltered antics.
It was an era of late-night TV where anything could happen — and often did.
llm: My earliest memories of late night television are the likes of Leno and Letterman.
The first time I remember staying up to watch a show was in 2005 when Conan O'Brien took over hosting duties from Jay Leno on The Tonight Show.
As a result, I got to see some of the greatest comedians ever (Jimmy Fallon and Seth Meyers) who would later go on to their own shows or become Saturday Night Live cast members.

human: I almost can’t believe it, but 2023 is nearly over.
llm: I almost can’t believe this was a thing.

y
la fiebre amarilla
llm: Estos “Aedes aegypti” de los que hablamos son las moscas que transmiten el dengue.
Y no se trata sólo del dengue, también pueden propagar el chikungunya
y el Zika.
El dengue es una enfermedad viral que afecta especialmente a niños, adolescentes y adultos jóvenes.

human: The soldiers’ mission was as dangerous as it was audacious: a trek of more than 500 miles through mountainous jungle in northern Burma to seize a Japanese-held airfield in World War II.
llm: The soldiers’ mission was to cross the River Kwai and take back a Japanese-controlled railroad.
But after the initial push into Burma in February 1943, their attacks on enemy positions were largely unsuccessful.
The men suffered from tropical diseases and starvation.
In June 1944, they withdrew from the area, leaving behind 800 dead.

human: Satya Nadella, Microsoft’s chief executive, testified on Monday that Google’s power in online search was so ubiquitous that even his company found it difficult to compete on the internet, becoming the government’s highest-profile witness in its landmark antitrust trial against the search giant.
llm: Satya Nadella, Microsoft’s chief executive, testified on Tuesday that he had not seen evidence of the search giant using its power to stifle competition in other markets like social media and smartphones.

human: The evolution of Julie Taymor’s production of “Die Zauberflöte” from long-running hit to children’s-theater show at the Metropolitan Opera is now complete.

human: French investigative judges have issued an international arrest warrant for President Bashar al-Assad of Syria that accuses him of complicity in war crimes and crimes against humanity over the deadly use of chemical weapons against his own people, a judicial official said on Wednesday.
llm: French investigative judges on Thursday issued an international arrest warrant against Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, who is accused of crimes against humanity and war crimes committed by his troops.

human: Eighty percent of Gazans are displaced from their homes as Israel orders more evacuations.

llm: Eighty percent of families displaced by Israeli strikes have not yet returned home, and over 250,000 people are still homeless.

human: A foul smell led investigators to find at least 115 decaying bodies at a funeral home in rural Colorado that had promised “green” burials, officials said on Friday, describing the scene as “horrific.”
llm: A foul smell drew the attention of a passerby who spotted the bodies through a window.
A funeral home operator called police after discovering 115 decaying bodies inside his facility on Friday afternoon, authorities said.

human: Living alone can be a choice or a pit stop, but one thing’s for sure: The rent is on you.

Buying a home has been especially difficult over the past year, so more singles have been left to rely on leasing in a market where the typical renter is already rent burdened — that is, spending at least 30 percent of income on rent.
llm: Living alone can be expensive, but a new study finds that single women pay more than their male counterparts.

human: Astronomers have discovered six planets orbiting a bright star in perfect resonance.

llm: Astronomers have discovered a planetary system that includes six planets.
This is the largest number of planets ever found orbiting around another star, and all six planets are aligned in perfect synchrony.
The six planets are also very close to their parent star.
This means they could be warm enough for life, and possibly even habitable.

human: The Israeli military is preparing to invade the Gaza Strip soon with tens of thousands of soldiers ordered to capture Gaza City and destroy the enclave’s current leadership, according to three senior Israeli military officers who outlined unclassified details about the plan.
llm: The Israeli military is preparing for a major offensive on the Palestinian territory of Gaza, according to leaked documents obtained by the British newspaper The Guardian.

human: It’s January, a month that many would call the worst of the year.
What do you think?
Do you find January dreary and dull?
llm: It’s January, a month that can be difficult for many people.
The New Year has come and gone without any resolutions having been kept.
The holidays are over and we’re back to work.
Many people feel lonely or depressed during this time.
There is something about the cold weather and darkness that makes it hard to get motivated.

human: A judge in upstate New York was removed from the bench on Thursday, eight years after pointing a loaded gun at a Black man who appeared in his courtroom, New York’s highest court announced.
llm: A judge in Pennsylvania who pointed a gun at an African-American man during a hearing has been removed from the bench, the Philadelphia Inquirer reports.

The paper reports that Montgomery County Common Pleas Judge Mark A. Ciavarella Jr., 58, was charged with several counts of misdemeanor reckless endangerment and fined $200 for pointing his weapon at Robert Walker after Walker interrupted him during an August hearing.
The Associated Press reported that the judge had also threatened to shoot Walker’s attorney, John Morganelli, but the charges were later dropped against Morganelli.
“This is not what I signed up for,” Ciavarella told the courtroom as he resigned on Wednesday

human: Britney Spears’s much-anticipated memoir, “The Woman in Me,” sold 1.1 million copies in all formats in the United States in its first week on sale, the book’s publisher, Gallery Books, announced on Wednesday.
llm: Britney Spears’s much-anticipated memoir, “The Princess Diarist,” sold more than a million copies in its first week of publication, according to Nielsen BookScan, the industry’s best available measure of sales.

human: “Oppenheimer,” Christopher Nolan’s movie about the development of the atomic bomb, on Thursday received the highest number of nominations for this year’s EE British Academy Film Awards, known as the BAFTAs.
llm: “Oppenheimer,” Christopher Nolan’s 3-D space epic, is the leading nominee for this year’s British Academy Film Awards (BAFTAs), with nine nominations.

The film received a total of six nominations in the technical categories, including outstanding British contribution to cinema and editing, while it was also nominated in the best original music category for its score by Hans Zimmer.”

human: The five Republican presidential candidates on Wednesday’s debate stage gave staunch support to Israel’s invasion of Gaza, rejecting pleas to rein in the conflict and calling on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to destroy Hamas, the Islamic militant group that killed 1,400 civilians and Israeli soldiers in a surprise attack last month.
llm: The five Republican senators who voted for the resolution, McCain, Graham, Ayotte, Rubio and Portman, have been in the forefront of GOP foreign policy hawks.

human: In 1996, in a phrase that’s stuck with me, Richard John Neuhaus described the Holocaust as “our only culturally available icon of absolute evil.”

In the post-Cold War landscape, with American power seemingly occupying the stage of history by itself, the memory of Nazi Germany’s genocide came to play a special cultural role in the self-understanding of the liberal West: We might not agree on the highest good, but we knew the highest evil, and arguments about its memory and meaning and implications were absolutely central to politics and culture.

human: As 2023 comes to an end, there is a growing sense of panic in Europe.

Since the Russian invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, the European Union has been preoccupied with integrating the country — widely seen as a geopolitical necessity — and with the internal reform required to make that possible.
But over the course of this year, as the much-hyped Ukrainian counteroffensive stalled, tensions among member states have increased.
llm: As 2023 comes into sight, the world will have to reckon with a Europe that is no longer united.

The EU’s institutions will be unable to function properly because of the absence of a common foreign policy and a common military force; its member states will be forced to reconsider their commitment to the European project as they face a more assertive Russia; and populists will make new gains across the continent in elections this year.

human: These days, real estate imagery is often defined by staged hotel-lobby-style furniture and generic artwork, dramatic drone shots on unsettlingly perfect sunny days and a lack of human presence — almost never do you see any people or evidence that these homes have been lived in.

human: As Holly, the protagonist of Elizabeth Hand’s “A Haunting on the Hill,” approaches an imposing, deserted mansion tucked off a remote country road, she drives past a tree stump that’s “choked with poison ivy, a riot of scarlet leaves and white berries.”

Though she doesn’t know it yet, the tree that once stood there claimed the life of Eleanor Vance, the tragic lead from the novel’s antecedent text, Shirley Jackson’s wildly influential “The Haunting of Hill House.”
And so, a couple dozen pages into the book, Hand makes her first decisive mark on Jackson’s landscape, acknowledging her predecessor while making the house her own.
When Jackson left Hill House, the tree was still standing.
Hand is here to chop it down.
llm: As Holly, the ghost who doesn't know she's dead, says in the first episode: "I have a story.
I want you to hear it."
And that's what The Haunting of Hill House does so well; it has its characters tell their stories.
Each character's past is revealed as they relate how they got to where they are today.
This gives each character some depth.
It also allows viewers to connect with them on a more personal level.

human: “2024 is the final battle,” Donald Trump has said.

human: For years, a Native American tribe from the picturesque East End of Long Island has fought bitterly for formal state recognition, a designation that was stripped away more than a century ago by court decisions that are now widely considered racist.

human: The U.S. military program that provides leadership and civic values training for students in thousands of high schools across the country will have more oversight thanks to new legislation approved by Congress this week.

llm: The U.S. military's Junior Reserve Officers Training Corps (JROTC) program is an educational program that uses the structure of a military organization to teach high school students life skills and leadership abilities.
The program was established in 1916 by Congress, with funding from the War Department, as part of the National Defense Act.
Over 40 years later, the program was expanded through legislation to include all secondary schools across the country.

human: In the ancient city of Exeter, three women were hanged for practicing witchcraft in the late 17th century, the last of such executions in England.

Now, merely a short walk from where the hangings occurred, the University of Exeter will offer a postgraduate degree in magic and occult science, which the school says is the first of its kind at a British university.
llm: In the ancient world, magic and medicine were one and the same.
The term “magic” comes from the Greek word “magoi,” which means “to work with the gods.”
In ancient times, doctors and shamans used to cast spells on people who were sick or possessed by demons.
It was believed that magic could be used to heal people, so it is not surprising that there are many medical traditions around the world that still use spells and chants to cure diseases.
In fact, today we have two different words for these magical practices: medicine and witchcraft.

human: Ever since Israel withdrew its soldiers and settlers from Gaza in 2005, critics have accused it of blockading and immiserating the territory — turning it, as they say, into an open-air prison.
llm: Ever since Israel began its ground operation in Gaza, the Israeli press has been abuzz with reports about Hamas tunnels.
The tunnels are said to have enabled Hamas to carry out attacks against Israeli troops from underground bunkers or to be used as a way for Palestinians to escape the fighting zone.
But what exactly is known about these tunnels?
And why do they matter so much?
To answer those questions, I spoke to Shmuel Sandler, professor of political science at Bar-Ilan University and one of Israel's leading experts on Hamas.
The interview was conducted via Skype.

human: Michael Cunningham’s new novel, “Day,” visits a family on April 5 in 2019, 2020 and 2021 — before, during and after the onset of the Covid-19 pandemic, which shadows the book although the words “Covid” and “pandemic” never appear.
llm: Michael Cunningham’s new novel, The Snow Queen, is a book about books.
It tells the story of a young man named Walter, who has just lost his father to cancer and is trying to cope with the fact that he will soon be losing his mother as well.
In order to get through these difficult times, Walter begins reading—a lot.
He reads Proust (in French), Dostoevsky, Chekhov, Melville, Turgenev, Tolstoy, and, above all else, Henry James.
It turns out that the best way for Walter to deal with his grief over the death of his parents is to immerse himself in literature.
His reading helps him to understand and process what has happened to his family and what lies ahead.

human: The guys in Bad Dog, a folkie duo from Washington, D.C., weren’t hoping to get rich off the album they recorded this summer.

llm: The United States-led coalition has conducted 10 airstrikes against Houthi rebels in Yemen since the beginning of August, but much of their offensive capabilities remain intact after the attacks, according to the Pentagon and other officials.

human: David Ferry, a poet and translator whose direct, emotionally resonant work plumbing the chasms between the knowable and the unknowable won him broad praise and honors late in his career, including the National Book Award when he was 86, died on Sunday in Lexington, Mass.

human: Yes, we know, you get to Carnegie Hall with “practice, practice.”

The cafe area will be open to concertgoers during intermissions.
(Opens Jan. 20, 22)
llm: Yes, we know, you don't need a ticket to hear the New York Philharmonic.

These programs, which are curated by the hall and take place from 10:30 AM to noon, feature performances by musicians affiliated with the Philharmonic, including guest soloists and members of the orchestra's own chamber music ensemble.

human: Visits to the International Space Station are valuable, and would-be astronauts and their countries can wait a long time for the opportunity.

The three on the Ax-3 flight are: Alper Gezeravcı, who will be the first Turkish astronaut; Marcus Wandt, a European Space Agency astronaut from Sweden; and Walter Villadei, an Italian Air Force pilot who previously flew to the edge of space on a Virgin Galactic rocket plane.
A launch on Wednesday was postponed to Thursday.
llm: Visits to the ISS are also planned for 2019 by Excalibur Almaz and Orbital ATK, but those companies have not announced which nations' astronauts will fly their vehicles.
The only other commercial company with an active ISS-class spacecraft is Boeing Co., which plans to use its CST-100 Starliner capsule as part of NASA's Commercial Crew Program.
However, that program has been delayed repeatedly due to issues with the capsules and Atlas V rockets that were supposed to carry them into orbit.

human: TV in 2023 was like synchronized swimming.
Below the surface, there was roiling and churn.

The hangover from the corporate binge on streaming platforms led to cancellations and cutbacks.
A number of hall-of-fame series left the air, with no clear plan of, as it were, succession.
llm: TV in 2023 will be very different from what we know today.
The biggest trend of the next decade is the increasingly prevalent streaming services, which have led to a decline in traditional broadcasting.
As a result, there are fewer channels, but also much better ones.
In addition to classic American sitcoms like Friends or Seinfeld, there are also many shows with an international focus and more serialized storylines.

human: When scientists take a core sample of fiction from the post-Trump era, they will discover American novelists struggling to unpack the political and social repercussions of his reign.

human: Why is Donald Trump continuing to poll so strongly with voters?
llm: Why is Donald Trump doing so well?
The short answer is that he's tapped into a deep vein of economic frustration and anger among white working-class voters who have not shared in the nation's economic recovery.
In my view, these voters feel left behind by both parties over the past two decades.
Democrats are perceived as elitist, out of touch with average Americans and unwilling to address issues such as trade and immigration.
Republicans have been seen as willing to make deals with corporate America but unwilling to help workers and middle-class families.

human: In August 1944, in a city near Paris, Robert Capa took a photograph of a woman cradling a baby in the middle of a jeering crowd, her head shaved and her forehead marked with a swastika.
llm: In August 1944, a German officer in charge of a platoon of engineers was killed near the town of Chartres.

The Germans had been ordered to destroy all bridges and railway lines in their path as they retreated from France; these soldiers were executing that order when they came across a woman who had apparently tried to block them by standing in front of an explosion.
The woman, who was named Jeanne-Marie Regnier, was badly wounded but not killed, and after she recovered, she became famous for her wartime exploits.
In 1946, she published a memoir entitled Ma vie est une chanson de guerre (My Life Is a Song of War), which described how she had stood up to the Germans in order to save French lives.

human: Dorothy Hoffner, born in 1918, had survived both the Spanish flu and Covid pandemics, as well as her first skydiving attempt at age 100.

She made headlines around the world when she did.
Here's more...

llm: For over a century, the Great American Songbook has been one of our nation's greatest cultural treasures.

When she walks into someone else's house, she can feel what that person feels; whether they're happy, sad, angry, stressed out etc...

human: How do you sift through Mexico City’s roughly 57,000 places to eat — more than twice as many as there are in New York City — and choose the most essential dishes?
“In a city like Mexico City, how do you narrow it down?
It’s insane.

The exercise is absurd to begin with,” says Gabriela Cámara, the chef and owner of Contramar and three other restaurants in the Mexican capital, at the outset of the video conversation I’d arranged to do just that: identify the specific meals or bites (or drinks) that best represent the metropolis’s formidable food scene right now.

Nonetheless, Cámara was up for the challenge, as were the four other panelists I’d convened, all of whom live in Mexico City either year-round or part time: Ana Dolores, the chef and owner of Esquina Común restaurant in the Condesa neighborhood; Anais Martinez, who founded the Curious Mexican, a street-food tour company, and recently opened Manada, an all-Mexican cocktail and natural wine bar in Narvarte; the food writer Alonso Ruvalcaba, the author of the guide “24 Horas de Comida en la Ciudad de México” (2018); and Carla Valdivia Nakatani, T Magazine’s art director, who splits her time between Manhattan and Mexico City, where she co-owns a boutique in Roma.

Before we met as a group, I’d asked each participant to nominate around 10 dishes, including a sweet and a drink, from 10 different spots, ranging from fine-dining restaurants to street carts and market stalls.

Then we spent two hours and several subsequent emails and phone calls debating our choices, trying to whittle down the 50-plus nominations to 25 in order to produce a list like those in the ongoing T 25 series devoted to food in Paris and in New York.
llm: How do you know when a place is going places?
When the tourists start pouring in, that's when.
And when they start doing things like this:

But for a while now she's seemed to be playing variations on the same character — an imperious, sly woman who can effortlessly hold court at any social gathering and always has something witty to say about herself or others.
She does it so well that when you hear her voice, you know it's her even if you don't recognize her face; she could be saying anything.
That voice is one of her greatest assets as an actor, but it also means that she plays roles that are almost interchangeable with each other.

human: At least 40 percent of crop workers in the United States do not have legal immigration status.
Americans typically aren’t willing to do backbreaking work in the fields, farmers say.
llm: At least 40% of farmworkers are Hispanic and Latino.
However, the USDA does not collect data on race or ethnicity in its annual Census of Agriculture, which makes it impossible to know how many Latinos work in agriculture.

However, the Census of Agriculture shows that the number of farmworkers has declined by more than 10% since 2007, from nearly 3 million to about 2.7 million, according to the National Agricultural Workers Survey (NAWS).
The decline is due primarily to fewer people growing their own food.

human: In the 1970s, soft-shell clams started mysteriously dying off in Maine and the Chesapeake Bay.

llm: In the 1970s, scientists in Japan began to notice a strange phenomenon.
In coastal waters off the country’s northeast, they found that starfish were dying at an alarming rate, and the culprit was clear: sea stars were being attacked by bacteria called Vibrio.

But these weren’t just any old vibrios; they were a particular species of bacterium known as Vibrio fischeri, which can normally only be found in symbiosis with the light-producing tissue of the Hawaiian bobtail squid (Euprymna scolopes).

human: A few years after the Society for the Protection of New Hampshire Forests started a Christmas tree farm, Nigel Manley, who oversaw the operations, began noticing some interesting developments among the rows of fragrant balsam and Fraser firs lining the land.
llm: A few years ago I went to a wildlife refuge for the first time.
The place was teeming with birds of all types and sizes, butterflies, and dragonflies.
And then there were the turtles, frogs, snakes, and salamanders that called this wetland home.
As we walked around the ponds in the reserve, I heard the loud buzz of insects.
There were so many bugs!
When my husband asked if they were stinging or biting, I told him no.
He had to be assured that not every bug was out to get us.
But as we looked more closely at these insects, I began to realize that some of them might be beneficial.

human: The terms of the private loan were as generous as they were clear: With no money down, Justice Clarence Thomas could borrow more than a quarter of a million dollars from a wealthy friend to buy a 40-foot luxury motor coach, making annual interest-only payments for five years.

llm: The terms of a $150,000 loan that Justice Clarence Thomas received in 2008 from a friend were so favorable that the lender forgave the debt six months later, according to court records and interviews with people familiar with the arrangement.

human: “The Sweet East,” a shape-shifting satire about modern American subcultures, is a curious — occasionally delightful — object.

llm: “The Sweet East,” a new play at the Flea Theater, is set in 1953 and has as its subject the lives of three sisters — two of them white and one black.

human: Margaret Newcomb, 69, a retired French teacher, is desperately trying to protect her retirement savings by caring for her 82-year-old husband, who has severe dementia, at home in Seattle.

human: A volcano in southwestern Iceland, the country’s most populated region, began erupting Monday with lava fountains reaching high in the air and the glow lighting up the sky miles away in the center of the capital, Reykjavik.
llm: A volcano in southern Iceland erupted for the first time since 1973 on Saturday, sending a plume of smoke into the sky that could be seen from Reykjavik, the capital.

human: The original 2004 movie “Mean Girls” contained something unusual, both then and now: a main character who was home-schooled.

llm: The original 2004 film is a comedy that follows Cady Heron, played by Lindsay Lohan, who moves from Africa to the United States when she's 15 years old.

human: On Dec. 11, NASA engineers anxiously gathered at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., to view a cat video, wondering if it would be in the pristine high definition for which they had hoped.
llm: On Dec. 11, the space agency live-streamed a video of a cat from the International Space Station (ISS) to help launch a new website dedicated to celebrating cats.

The streaming event was part of an effort by NASA and the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (ASPCA), called #BeKindToCats, to raise awareness about the issue of homeless cats and encourage people to adopt cats from shelters instead of buying them as pets.

human: And just like that, Ron DeSantis’s quest for the presidency is kaput.

It wasn’t a terrible performance, especially under the circumstances.
But watching Mr. DeSantis’s now-famous awkward smile and listening to his unnatural cadence, it was hard not to think:
Yeah.
I can see why this guy’s candidacy is deader than disco.
llm: And just like that, Rick Scott is out of the Governor's race.
I have a hard time believing that he'd be able to beat Bill Nelson in November if this election were held today.
And I have an even harder time believing that Bill Nelson would lose to DeSantis in November, even with Trump at the top of the ticket.
But there are two things that we can take away from Tuesday night: 1) Floridians do not want Trump's wall and 2) Republicans cannot win elections without white voters.

human: Ask Minnesotans about the state’s official flag, and prepare for a crush of critiques.
llm: Ask Minnesotans about their state flag, and they'll likely tell you it needs an upgrade.
In fact, the current design is the second in the state's 152-year history.
The first flag flew from 1957 to 1973; the current one was adopted in 1957 as well, but has flown ever since.
It's time to change things up, according to many residents who have submitted their ideas to the Minnesota Historical Society (MHS).

human: At age 80, Byron Wien compiled “20 Life Lessons” from a long career as a Wall Street soothsayer.

human: Even in the Golden Age of musical theater, shows so commonly died after intermission that critics came up with a name for the disease.

Yet all those second act symptoms arose from the same underlying condition: first act ambitions.
llm: Even in the best of times, “Hell’s Kitchen” is a show that you love to hate.

It has all the hallmarks of a reality cooking competition – a cast of contestants who are competitive and dramatic, a gimmicky format that rewards those with the most natural skill (and not necessarily the most talent) and a mentor whose job it is to bark orders at them while they cook in front of an audience.
But unlike other shows like “Top Chef,” “Hell’s Kitchen” has no real-world reward for the winner except for their name on a restaurant sign.

human: Inside the “blueberry muffin” conference room, the walls are, naturally, painted blue.

llm: In a perfect world, everyone would have all day to prepare the most amazing meal for their family and friends.

human: What you need to understand about a sniper mission is that from the minute it begins to the minute it ends, everything you do is in service of killing another human being.

human: More than 1,100 are dead as Israel fights to drive out Palestinian militants from towns near the Gaza Strip, two days after hundreds of Israelis were killed or captured in surprise attacks.

llm: More than 1,100 Palestinians were killed in Gaza during last summer's war between Israel and Hamas.

human: Mayor Eric Adams of New York on Thursday ratcheted up his feud with Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas, filing suit against 17 transportation companies that he said had carried out a plan by Mr. Abbott to send more than 30,000 migrants to New York City and make the city pay for their care.
llm: Mayor Eric Adams of New York City has sued four bus companies that brought nearly 30,000 migrants into the city last month.

human: The House voted on Tuesday to oust Kevin McCarthy, Republican of California, from the speakership, an unprecedented development that plunged the chamber into chaos.
llm: The House voted on Thursday to install Rep. Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., as the next speaker of the House, a move that comes more than a week after Rep. Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif., withdrew his bid for the job following a coup attempt by members of the conservative Freedom Caucus.
The caucus was upset over McCarthy’s comments that he was open to passing legislation that would protect Robert Mueller from being fired by President Donald Trump.
That led to an outcry among some Republicans who said McCarthy should not be speaker because he had undermined Trump.

human: Ohio voters are deciding on a ballot measure that would amend the state’s Constitution to explicitly guarantee the right to abortion.

human: Britain’s Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that a policy to deport asylum seekers to Rwanda is unlawful, dealing a major blow to a Conservative government that has long described the plan as central to its pledge to stop the arrival of the small boats that cross the English Channel.
llm: Britain’s Supreme Court on Wednesday ruled that the government could not deport asylum seekers to Rwanda because they would be at risk of torture there.

The ruling was a blow to Britain’s efforts to manage its overflowing asylum system by sending some claimants back to countries like Rwanda, where the British authorities say they can get fair hearings and proper treatment.
But the court said it had found no evidence that people who went to Rwanda from Britain were likely to face inhuman or degrading treatment if they claimed asylum there.
Under European Union law, asylum seekers cannot be sent to a country where their life or freedom may be threatened.

human: In the most recent Modern Love essay, “When Your Search History Says What You Can’t,” Kassia Oset shares a cautionary tale of the heart and the browser.
llm: In the most recent issue of The New Yorker, there is an article called "The Last Days Of Yugoslavia", by David Rieff.
It's a long and fascinating read about how the country fell apart in 1992-1995, and it's pretty much my favorite piece I've ever read from that magazine.

He has some interesting observations on how the internet affected things during the war.
One thing he talks about is the fact that all the news stories were getting picked up and reprinted everywhere, so you could see what was happening anywhere else.
In a way, this was good for the war effort - people could see that their country wasn't being completely ignored -

human: The word ordeal has appeared in 291 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 31 in “I Was Trying to Build My Son’s Resilience, Not Scar Him for Life” by Erik Vance:
llm: The word ordeal is an old English word.
It comes from the French word ‘ordeal’ and is related to the Latin verb ‘ordo’ which means ‘to set in order.’
Ordeals were trials used by judges during the middle ages to determine whether a person was guilty or innocent of certain crimes such as witchcraft.

human: In “Oppenheimer,” the writer and director Christopher Nolan’s summer blockbuster biopic — three words that generally don’t go together — the character of Kitty Oppenheimer is effaced twice over.
llm: In “Oppenheimer,” the film is set in a future where we are all in danger of being taken over by artificial intelligence, and the world is divided into two camps: those who want to take over the machines, and those who are terrified of them.

The latter group, led by Blunt, has been working on an anti-robot weapon, but it hasn’t worked yet; the former is run by the government (and led by Jeff Daniels) and believes that the robots will be good for humanity.

human: In Weirton, W.Va., in the heart of coal country, a company started by MIT scientists plans to build a plant that will produce a metal and alloy critical for clean energy, fuel cells and cleaner steel.
llm: In Weirton, W.Va., a former coal town that lost thousands of jobs when the steel mill closed in 1986, a $50 million factory will soon make solar panels and wind turbine blades from recycled aluminum cans, tires and construction waste.

llm: Lawyers for former President Trump asked the U.S. Supreme Court to overturn a lower court ruling that he can be sued by prosecutors in New York, saying he is immune from such legal action because of his role as president.

human: Astrid Delgado first wrote her college application essay about a death in her family.
Then she reshaped it around a Spanish book she read as a way to connect to her Dominican heritage.
llm: Astrid Delgado first thought about attending the University of Michigan when she was in high school and saw its students protesting for affirmative action.
She said her family could not afford to send her to college without financial aid.
So she was thrilled when she got accepted at the university in 2013 with a full scholarship.
But after learning that Michigan had stopped offering some preferences based on race, Ms. Delgado rewrote her application essay several times.
When it came time to submit it, she decided to write about how she had been discriminated against as an immigrant.

human: When is walking in circles a good thing?
When following a trail through villages, forests and fields using open-access paths that begin and end at the same train station.
llm: When is walking in a circle acceptable?
When it's part of an art installation!
The latest project from the team behind Cities and Memory takes us on a circular stroll around the perimeter of London's former Olympic Park.
This circular walk, called "Round and Round We Go," will take you to 30 sites along the 4.5 mile path that encloses Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park (formerly known as Stratford City).
You can complete the entire circuit in about two hours.
Along the way, you'll find historical facts and stories about the park and its surrounding neighborhoods.
It's also a good chance to see some sculptures and other art installations by well-known artists like Yoko Ono and Antony Gormley
